full_transcript: Chris here is young he's what's hot he's what's new and he's going to be doing tonight's review whether you like it or not hello my needle drops I'm Chris Capello and it's time for an album review today's review sons the engine-room sons is a Fairfield Connecticut based four-piece band that have been kicking around the indie rock circuit here in Connecticut and the neighboring states for the past few years they the three original members were also members of a band called Midian the modern dance which is one of my favorite local bands and they are sort of on a hiatus right now but they're really great and so this sons record is sort of tiding me over basically until whatever happens with with MIDI and the modern dance next but anyway this uh this record comes on the heels of their 2011 EP be good boy and a demo that they put put out the previous year which just add three tracks on it but this is their first full-length LP the engine room so this record finds the band branching out from there indie rock origins into something a little more experimental and a little more hard edged they take a lot from 90s emo bands like sunny day real estate and mineral and also some elements from slow core and even math rock on this release the van mixes a lot of styles that should be familiar to any fans of 90s indie rock but they do it in such a way that keeps things constantly interesting and engaging and has a kind of experimental bent to it for me the real strength of this album lies in the instrumental backbone they the band was recently joined by a new guitarist Peter cats who is known for being the guitarist from the Massachusetts post-rock math rock band fugue who dis abandoned recently prior to him joining sons and his influence really shines all over this record you know he adds a lot of interesting chord progressions guitar riffs you know just elements that wouldn't necessarily be present in a typical indie rock record and it gives it this kind of progressive feeling to it as a whole cats seems to have this ability as a guitar player to balance out the other elements of the band he keeps the rawness in check and also adds you know aggression and noisy dissonant riffs when he needs to and so it adds another element to the sort of power trio sound that they had before and makes it a much more sort of engaging released it's really interesting to listen to the band you know write these really breakneck speed songs he's aggressive tracks and then go into more slow contemplative and minimalist songs you know you get tracks like the opening song repulse which is this very slow kind of page or the lion influence track and then you have songs like lover lover and I could have made time which are just these raw angry dissonant emo songs I mean really you know raw lyrics aggressive wrist this is intense riff in in lover lover that um it's like a harmonic balance between the two guitarists from the band and they just play so fast and with such intensity that it kind of sends chills down my spine but the best tracks on this record come when the band balances these two elements and combines them into the same song the highlight track for me is definitely crocodile the second song in the album it starts with this kind of soothing you know ethereal guitar riff and these you know airy vocals coming in seemingly from nowhere but then builds up to this dramatic climax before completely dropping off towards the toward the end of the song into this kind of modest mouse circa the lonesome crowded West irri instrumental part but then it all builds up back again into this angry dissonant mix of feedback and turns into kind of a cursive style song I mean we'll rutledge the frontman is just like shouting and screaming over these bursts of guitar feedback it's one of the most chilling and fascinating for me moments of any song from 2012 as far as I'm concerned they have a similar thing going on the title track the engine room it starts out kind of slow and no sad but builds up into this really anthemic chorus that reminds me of their earlier work the lyrics occasionally veer into you know teenaged conor oberst territory but on the whole I think that will Rutledge's lyrics are more developed and more poetic and have more you know lyrical merit than his previous work and so it's easier for me to appreciate them you know even though I can totally identify with what he's going for you know when he's at his most literal it's nice to have the sort of poetic elements you know this is symbolism his use of imagery to balance that and to keep things you know mature I mean as a teenager myself you know I feel justified in listening to this record because I've had you know all of the feelings that he's yelling and singing sadly about but I could see how someone might be sort of turned off by them anyway I'm feeling a strong 72 a light eight on this one I thought it was great but and it's time for a review creator phantom antichrist and ant antichrist these guys are German thrash metal heavyweights this is their 13th full-length album and with a few lineup changes they have been steadily releasing material since they started in the mid 80s and have released some pretty notable metal records in that time like pleasure to kill especially pleasure to kill and coma of souls just really bringing that speedy fast and ultra aggressive thrash metal sound from the late 80s and early 90s together with some really kind of sacrilegious imagery and messages and though they did start incorporating some elements of a very kind of dark moody gothic rock on some of their albums that were released in the 90s they never really ventured all too far from their renren rash sound they're certainly staying ahead of some of their more slightly over produced contemporaries like overkill or Megadeth they're even sounding better than some of their fellow Germans although I will say that last Sodom record had a really raw freakin badass rough-around-the-edges sound just really but anyway this new album from Creator is a bit of a change it's not really just the the thrash and bash of their previous LP they really do try to refine their sound with more melody more harmony some really kind of epic choruses a lot of the riffs and core progressions feel much more righteous this time around system feelings of justice coming from some of these songs and to mention it again the melody and the harmony that I feel like is so much bigger of an element on this album make some of the course is on this thing feel really kind of Flowery it actually kind of sounds like these guys are borrowing a lot of ideas from the world of of Iron Maiden to bring their sound a bit more diversity on this album and even though the b-side to the new single from these guys is a cover of number of the beast it sounds more like these guys or bar borrowing a lot more from Iron Man's newer records than they are their older records it does bring an element of melodic sweetness to some of these songs and really makes a few of the courses on this record really rock it off into something kind of exciting a lot like the title track to this album but some other moments where these guys will glide from a hard-hitting thrash riff to something that's just pretty it just doesn't feel that impressive or it's just kind of passable and I think that partially has to do with these guys writing these melodic courses or executing them rather just about the same way almost every time they come up and what's worse is that some of these courses can come off really kind of overblown a bit corny and to me kind of break the momentum of some of these tracks I prefer the increase in melody on this album when it's kind of used subtly into a track that is just totally badass and balls-to-the-wall like death to the world but aside from that increase in melody in that kind of embrace of Iron Maiden sound just kind of out of nowhere on this album there's not many surprises to behold with phantom antichrist and i'm kind of on the fence with the production too while I do think the guitar tone feels okay there's nothing particularly special about it and and the drums to me feel so mechanical they feel so robotic it doesn't really get me excited or pumped to hear these guys just riff on some of these grooves on these tracks rather it just kind of makes a lot of these songs feel very paced very kind of predictable and that just kills the excitement for me because thrash is all about a journal for me I have to give it to creator for you know not just trying to do the same thing over and over and over again but to hear them kind of jump ship a little bit onto another metal band sound and then just really kind of not even do all that much justice it feels even worse than it would be to just hear that put out another straightforward just fist to face thrash metal record I'm kind of feeling like strong five yeah about a strong five maybe yeah strong five on this record what did you guys think of this thing what did you expect from it did you love it did you hate it why and what should i in your opinion review next grabber

I got your replacement right here honey in turn Chris hi everyone Anthony my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review whoo-hoo this is the second installment of instrumental beats from music producer clams casino who has recently seen a nice rise to fame but not as nice when you compare it to a lot of the artists who rap and sing over the beats style has been essential in creating the spacious and Atmospheric approach to hip-hop music that a lot of people right now are calling cloud rap this free collection of instrumentals is basically your chance to listen to clams Casino in the raw no vocalist and really just come to understand what makes him stand out as a producer on this on that on this on that on this thing you're going to hear instrumentals that have been wrapped over or sung over by guys like ASAP rocky little B main attractions Mac Miller even the weekend with - with now with all these tracks with this instrumental tape you can kind of hear what claims casino has been up to within the year or so it's been since he dropped his last instrumental tape and he showed a lot of growth since then he's working with different artists he's producing for bigger albums now generally this guy's instrumentals are very lucid very dreamy it's like swimming in slow motion through an ocean of bong water that is floating through space and while keeping with that style clams Casino looks for new hurdles to jump over he is on these instrumentals not always shooting for that same kind of hey this is pretty hey this is glossy hey this is beautiful kind of vibe the opening track on your palace is easily one of the most epic productions that this guy is put together just with all these escalating chorus vocal samples that sound like they were recorded and one of the largest cathedrals on the planet the track was up which comes right after has these watery synthesizers and just these very spectral vocal samples and together they kind of make the sleepiest song this guy has ever made but sleepy in a good way it's very relaxing it's very intoxicating and the track bass brings just that and is really heavy with the low end it's it's pretty much a bad banger just such heavy rumbles and very crisp snare hits and the track the fall is easily one of the darkest and most textured songs this guy has made with all of these sampled birds chirping and disembodied vocals to those two things are just swirled into this mess of synthesizers of various textures sometimes they're glistening and echo Ian's and bouncy sometimes they're kind of distorted and over modulated to the track eventually fades and comes back more distorted than it previously was in kind of the first section of the song and it ends up kind of sounding like a cross between a rap beat and a Tim Hecker soundscape the first four tracks on this thing alone showcase more variety than what clams was doing on his previous tape though there are positives on here and really strong positives there were a bunch of tracks that I felt were just kind of passable maybe not maintaining enough detail to really kind of be an exciting or thrilling listen with no vocalist on it whatsoever and other tracks like angels and the serving remix definitely didn't have that strong of a flavor to me a personality comparison with other tracks on here and I did not like the washed out remix at all whether it's just the pulsating and forceful beat along with that relaxing atmosphere that just kind of puts me off or the arpeggios that the synths are playing if there's just a lot of things I don't like about the track but hearing the beautifully dismantled version of Born to Thai by Lana Del Rey was actually surprisingly awesome this thing is a solid listen for the most part I'm totally and just completely in love with this guy's production style but at the same time I have to recognize that not every track on here is that invigorating of a listen I feel not a decent too strong seven on this thing thought it was great what did you guys think of this did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana washed out forever [Music] continued to release full-length music videos as well as a live album - and every video just had man immaculate immaculate cinematography just beautiful images surreal images brought in a pastel color exactly what I needed to start enjoying what's actually going on here because while the music on this LP does feel simple Jonah Lee does bring a very odd and enjoyable personality to these tracks but like I said before this is basically pop music with very clear influences but let's not discount it because of that because making a catchy er version of the kind of experimental music that inspires grimy it's very kind of disturbed dark almost like industrial pop and the song rascal is very quiet its atmospheric and has this beautifully escalating chorus very bare-bones but I love that swell and the extremely dancey closer has almost a disco vibe to it and with that disco vibe Jojo Jonah Lee's vocals kind of gain us somewhat BG's quality and the production on here is really great as well lots of fat just thick synthesizers they're very colorful and they layer intricately on a lot of songs throughout this LP sometimes I wish Jonah Lee and her producers would kind of take it easy on the reverb there are some moments where I feel like her voice is so in so much reverb it really distances it for me and the instrumentation is as well the reverb can make it sound a bit too glossy at some some nice personality to it some interesting effects on these tracks - catchy catchy catchy catchy catchy catchy choruses and distinctly different songs I thought I was going to absolutely hate this thing to the point where I was throwing up violently on camera in every direction but I think this album is good feeling a decent - strong 8 on this thing I do feel like the vocals here and just the overall style will not be for everybody but if you can enjoy those and basically get past the knife and björk worship on this album you'll hear some really catchy songs and in the future we will you're super late like it was a superpower like laser vision hi everyone Anthony Fantana here my needle drops the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review the tallest man on earth there's no leaving now this is the third full-length album from Swedish singer-songwriter Christian Madsen the dude has been incredibly consistent so far in his career staying true to his troubadour sound very passionate singing with just a voice that is slightly raspy very strong impressive solo guitar playing he just time and time and time and time and time again write songs that sound like a dusty road going into a Setting Sun as the credits roll brought to you in bright exciting Technicolor color color now with this new LP Christian basically continues his consistency streak and mate and mate and makes another album with roughly the same sound and it's and it's mostly because this guy can pull that sort of thing off staying in one area with his music because he is so uniquely good and what he does a cut above just his finesse on the guitar is very captivating personality and his kind of moving lyrics that that are very flowery in their language but also having this feeling of being very personal and somewhat cryptic - if anything is undergone a slight change with the tallest man on earth it is the instrumentation on this album which does kind of have its positives and negatives with the cell P it does bring more variety on this album you do have your acoustic tracks you do have your electric guitar Foundation tracks you do piano ballad but you do end up getting moments on this album like the opening track to just grow away which kind of sounds like Matson's Nissen singing over a bunch of pre-recorded instrumentation played against click tracks you get a lot of layers a lot of color but the performance isn't that exciting you know there's just no momentum - and no electricity it's not bad but it's not exciting either to me the extra instrumentation on this album sounds way better when it is inserted into what sounds like just a solid recorded performance of Christian playing his guitar and singing at the same time like the really sweetly play pedal steel on the track winded whales or the extra layers of guitar the woodwind instrument and what sounds like a snare drum just galloping faintly in the distance on the song revelation blues I'm insane now what's nice about this extra instrumentation is that it hangs in the background very subtly it's it's the singing the songwriting the guitar playing that really steals the show and it should especially since between you know those several things there's so much to take in with the tallest man on earth like with the song criminals which has this very speedy finger picking and on top of the finger picking the really solid tempo that he's got going the groove that he's pushing forward and his singing he just sort of breaks down into a solo over the bridge and it's just a really nice clean transition I loved the imagery that his lyrics threw out there like going under and stuff like that - or when he directly addresses the mountain on the track bright lanterns you know the thing is about his lyrics like I said they are kind of cryptic they do seem very personal and I'm not completely into plugged into what the storyline or the progression of of the story is on a number of these tracks but still just the acting the acting that he does while singing these tracks just makes so much of these moments emotive for me jur mountain love that you know case in point the closing track on here which is really one of the more forlorn tracks the tallest man on earth has ever put out and he just cries out painfully singing during some of these verses is this album basically is the same tallest man on the earth that has made this project so interesting up until this point there's some new instrumentation popping up here and there like I said adds a nice variety to this album and it works more than a dozen so don't worry about that for me there's not much else to say about this album than just feeling a decent - strong heat on it thought it was a great album very great album you know like I said didn't really surprise me or bring this project and anywhere amazingly different but still I mean friggin enjoyable you know I can't say no you know I'm not soulless yeah I do love new directions and new flavors but there's just some stuff that basic foundational goddamn it's good gotta admit it kind of stuff what did you guys think of this album did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana the tallest man on earth forever

oh no it's perfect hi everyone Anthony Fantino here intranets busiest music and it's time for an album review re conduct on acid this guy this guy's a German producer this is his debut album he built up to this release with a few self-released EPS on a label that describes itself as a platform for deep in melancholic electronic music there eight tracks on the cell peace spanning around an hour of music but two of the songs are remixes by other artists of songs already on this album which is a bit unorthodox but we're not in Kansas anymore are we and the basic concept of this LP which is referenced in its title is to experiment with the basic sounds of acid house music alter it at its most basic elements which includes embracing beats and rhythms that are hypnotic and trance inducing and including the uniquely sharp sounds of the roland tb-303 bass synthesizer which was creating the extremely abrasive squelching sounds that were tearing ears apart years before people were complaining about all these distorted wobbling bass web webs in modern dubstep now the T V 303 was originally meant to be a practicing aid for solo guitarists but as somehow found a very cozy home in electronic music and it made a lot of noise on some pretty popular tracks including Fatboy Slim's everybody needs a 303 and futures acid tracks which is the single kind of credited with forming the acid house style the style that recondite is altering on this album and not only is his approach to acid house music very minimal atmospheric open kind of bleak simplistic but what sort of makes these tracks stand out is his use of that tb-303 how he produces sounds with this instrument is kind of surprising because the tracks sound kind of beautiful he sequences the tb-303 on this thing so delicately and and so sparsely on a lot of these tracks creating some melodies that have a very odd beauty to them almost like a fragility as well like on the track tie in which nears almost ten minutes the tb-303 sounds on that track just bounce on the tempo literally with a splash of reverb they bounce on the tempo so sombrely and the 303 phrases are even simpler on the track felicity where rekon die is kind of altering the tonality of the track but not over driving it to the point where it starts squelching or starts distorting for the most part he is bringing the sounds just short of that threshold just barely pushing it because he just wants to keep his sup on these tracks the track Harbinger sees him putting some extreme reverb on the 303 really making it cascade over itself as it's playing these sequences and the song of sultry is just that and he plays the three of three having it call out as if it were like a siren or something like it was really singing really changing the sustain of the notes as it is singing this one phrase over and over so he definitely knows his way around a 303 or a 303 mock-up or you know some kind of 303 program on a computer either way he is making really great use of it but his talents don't stop there he's no slouch when it comes to programming a beat to the beats on this thing are very quiet they're very subtle and extremely entrancing too and he progresses them very nicely across every single track whether the song's four minutes or it's nine minutes the six tracks recon back puts on this LP are very deep build and showcase a lot of finite differences between them but most importantly besides the mastery of the 303 and the very nice rhythms the extremely nice rhythms that then that are showcased throughout this album there is a very strong emotional palette coming from this album - this is very emotive electronic music it is very sad music beautifully sad forlorn slightly depressing it's very chilly it's it's kind of frostbitten overall I wish this album was longer I wish it had some more tracks the two remixes on this thing one from Tin Man and another one from scuba are pretty decent they showcase a nice subtlety to them just like recon Deitz productions do so it's not like when I come across them they really take me out of the mood of the album which is really all I can ask for while I do feel like recon died on this album showcases some really unique talents this album still just kind of feels like a collection of tracks and I feel like he acknowledges that with the remixes thrown into the mix feeling a light decent eight on this thing take a listen to it and when you do you know let me know what do you think about it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana recon died on acid forever

Oh No what are you doing back there what are you even you're not I mean I'm just gonna review with you like that hi everyone Anthony Pham tanto here Internet's busiest music nerd time for a review the new Liars album wish you woo now Liars is a group whose obsession with not being pigeon-holed and just drive to always bring the band's music in a different direction has made them one of the most well respected groups in experimental rock now despite the metamorphosis that Liars has undergone over the years across all their albums rock music has pretty much always remained a root influence but on wish you that foundation that rock foundation is dissipating a little bit and it's dissipating to make way for an album that is overtly electronic with synthesizers and drum machines coming from just about every direction although it's a very moody and it's a very quiet album kind of pulling from the bleaker moments from the band's previous LP sister world sister world which i really only liked a little for me those quieter more understated moments on there kind of clashed with the more visceral spots on the album the louder tracks on the album that just presented more energy but unwish you these difficult musical ideas run rampant throughout the entire album the song is on this LP are deceptively simple they don't carry a lot of volume they don't carry a lot of impact they repeat a lot of rhythms they repeat a lot of vocal melodies sometimes it really feels like Liars is trying to progress some of these songs as little as possible keeping things locked into the gray just everything on this album is just this endless grayscale grey grey grey just varying shades of gray everything is really dark really kind of grimy lightly glitchy at points just a lot of basic beats and musical phrases performed in this very unobtrusive way even the album's loudest track brass which is kind of punchy is a light breeze compared to songs from liars five previous albums even this album's first single number one against the rush is incredibly easy on the ear some very apathetic post-punk with with bare bones drums very smooth somewhat retro synthesizers very very light bassline I know a lot of what I'm saying about this album sounds maybe a little bad or a little overly simplistic but there is something about the grouping of sounds that liar's uses on this album just the rudimentary musical shapes and phrases the creepy vocal kroons and the eerie falsetto vocals the reverb effects on here too to me it's it's a recipe for musical paranoia it's got this creepiness to it that sneaks in when nobody's looking and it's really difficult to kind of expect it because the band presents it in this very emotionally drained way and I love how liars is able to present this same feeling the same kind of direction across a variety of sounds and and tracks though understated there is some clear variety on this LP like on the track octagon which has this really pulsating and nimble beat lots of detailing and these sour harmonies that come out from the the synths and the vocals kind of intertwining or a ring on every finger which has these noisy beats these noisy sense but still very light very easygoing and these dead tired vocals it sounds like something that would go over well in a dance party where everybody has insomnia and I guess the biggest surprise out of all these tracks is how Radiohead like some of these songs actually sound from the vocal melody to the falsetto that the vocal is singing in to the hot synthesizers and the bassline on on his and mine sensations it just kind of feels like something that might have been of Lim's inspire I feel the same way about the song who is the hunter and there are a couple spots on here that maybe kind of feel BEC like overall I do feel like this album is a more solid listen then sister world it's more consistent it feels like it has a more well-groomed concept however I don't think it's a concept a lot of people are going to enjoy hearing it's not an exciting album that you want to get comfy with if it's very much an unsettling album that is slightly tense and very cerebral I wish some of the tracks down here were longer I wish Liars dug into this sound a little bit deeper to the point where they found something that was more distinct and some of the songs on here could have been creepier because I do think that creepiness is one of the greatest things this LP has going for it but it's not something I see myself returning to unless I'm really kind of in the mood for it you know feeling a strong 7 to light 8 on this album enjoyed it quite a bit though it did take some repeat lessons to kind of get there what did you guys think of this album did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana liars forever

pretend there's an intro here hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review Japan droids celebration Rock these guys are a rock duo from Canada Vancouver specifically and this isn't a sophomore LP the follow-up to the 2009 album post nothing and if you take a listen to this album you are basically going to find a bunch of teenage angst and apathy anthems with blaring guitars and drums that take as much away from pop punk as they do indie rock and what defines this album from track one to track E is this exciting sense of just youthful righteousness it's the stuff memories from last summer are made of fists being thrown into the air and rock festivals where kids were coming of age our crowd surfing and forming memories that they may tell their kids about one day you know Japan droids is really great at conjuring imagery like this and they do it with very bright distorted guitars a lot of major scales and chords this really punked out energy some very relatable and in kind of poetic lyrics that talk a lot about navigating life and broken relationships and just the the confusion of youth their lyrics that embrace that apathy that I mentioned earlier and acknowledge that yeah things suck right now but kind of also see a brighter future ahead because even though this LP can be very negative at points there are all these really hyped up group chorus vocals screaming whoa whoa xand oh yes and all rights that on the flip side of things feel very uplifting this is an album that really sits down next to you puts an arm around you and says man I know that feel oh man do I know that feel I mean if this album was put out in the late 90s early 2000s it most likely would have been labeled as emo I think celebration Rock looks to strike many of the same chords with its listeners but manages to take all these kind of angsty feelings and turns them into a celebration like the title suggests however my appreciation of this album kinda stops there because everything else on here musicianship production songwriting variety every other characteristic of this album to me just isn't that fantastic I mean the guitar sounds on this thing are kind of plain even when they get kind of noisy they still come off a little bland for me on this album there's not an interesting sound in sight from beginning to end and these guys write all their tunes in a verse chorus verse structure for the most part and when they head into the second half of the song and repeat the chorus and the verse again I don't really feel like they change the song up enough for me to kind of kick the feeling of deja vu there's not really anything new or memorable about the melodies or the chord progressions on here and the the OO chorus is really just kind of bore me to be honest I really like the energy that these guys give off in their songs frontman Brian King talks a really liberating game with his explosive lyrics these guys definitely come off with a we're gonna give them hell kind of attitude I don't doubt their sincerity and I don't think anybody does which is why Japan droids music resonates with so many people but you know between the say me say me melodies and the songs that could have used more detail in my opinion the predictable chords and the okay production and the kind of common sounds this album really just leaves me underwhelmed I feel like in terms of attitude and just aesthetic this album would go over really well like a bonfire where it's you and all your friends on the night you graduated high school Japan droids are really great at making music that really feels like the soundtrack to a defining moment but musically there's nothing really definitive about what's going on here to me like I said some okay music with some really big feelings and that's pretty much it I'm feeling really on the fence with this album a strong five to a light six really to be honest but what did you guys think of this album did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana Japan droids thank you for watching forever [Music] you

I have outed you I have outed you is not a music lover or a music enjoyer but a contrarian while I still prefer old music you has opened my eyes to many a music Thank You Gyo Gyo Gyo Gyo hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review black breath sentenced to life this is a sophomore album whose album cover I could stare at all day visually this covers like a combination of black flags damaged and Anthrax's Fistful of metal but these guys definitely bring it in to over the top territory by bringing in a sledge hammer to get their point across now I first heard of these guys in 2009 on their debut EP razor to oblivion southern Lord Records released it and then and the EP was just a handful of songs that were a rough in raw fusion of hardcore punk and metal and around this time period southern Lords started picking up a lot of Punk and metal hybrids males all pigs must die track them the secret and black breath delivers this style with some extreme intensity now the band's full-length album that dropped in 2010 I wasn't totally into I felt like it lost a bit of personality that razor to oblivion had it was a little inconsistent in style too but it still had some great qualities the band definitely came through with thicker production this time around on out just relentless with these vocals that have become more fierce and buzzsaw guitar tones that really cut through your skull I still think it's an album that is a very nice stepping stone to what the band is doing on this new album sentenced to life on this LP just songs that are set to the speed of punk thrash riffs D beads come in every direction from the drums ferocious vocals tremolo picked death metal melodies and the occasional blast bein break down just to kind of add some variety to the album you know an LP that's this extreme can run into two issues one there's not enough change there's not enough variation all the songs end up sounding the same and it just becomes kind of boring another issue can be that it is too long and that issue becomes an even bigger issue when the first issue is an issue but black breath is able to keep things high-intensity high adrenaline while still adding some character to nearly every one of these songs just take the vocal break on the opening track feast of the Damned yes and the descending guitar lead on forced into possession feels like just being thrown into the pits of hell and I also love how the band can really kind of slow things down like on the track home of the grave or the really brooding dark intro on endless corpse but still keep things kind of interesting and while we're on the subject of endless corpse I love the syncopated drum hits that just fly in quickly to transition that track from this really kind of dark moody intro to just fast-paced and the song hits so hard the band plays so freakin fast really quick really accurate but far from robotic I love this on mother or piss off of this track too it starts off with this really fiery wailing guitar solo and it just feels like I am listening to a thrash metal song on steroids like I had grabbed a thrash metal album circa 1985 I've thrown it on the turntable crank the bass all the way up and then played it at 45 rpm now while there is a lot of just straight into the point aggression on this album there's quite a bit of detail to kind of like a spiked bat with a beautifully engraved handle there are a lot of layers to the madness on sentence to life it's just that the outside to this album is is that at first it comes off so overbearing it comes off so extreme all those details and the fact that these guys are blending so many musical ideas together in an interesting way does not become obvious until a few lessons in what does come off strong on this album is that these guys are a sheer force I feel like there are some tracks on here that could have used a little more detail to separate them from the rest like the song doomed and yeah admittedly this album is difficult to connect with on any other level than than vast spaces and pure aggression but it conjures those things so amazingly that I just have to give it up mmm kind of feeling a light eight to a decent eight on this album what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana black breath

hi everyone Anthony Fant no here laughing like a d-bag the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a question common thing this video is a response not formally not a response but a reaction to a video I saw in one of my favorite YouTube channels d dot respect run by a really cool dude but it actually was not his video it was a video made by another guy named North paw productions that got uploaded on his YouTube channel and he was talking about some stuff people limiting themselves to mainstream music and movies and television and culture and through that they're kind of squandering their freedom and not really thinking about what they're consuming entertainment wise yadda yadda yadda but I feel the problem he talks about is not really limited to people just going out to see a blockbuster or downloading some drake songs of iTunes for me the real issue is that music fans today in the Internet age during a time when you could explore any kind of music from any place from any artist or album people are still choosing to limit themselves period not just to mainstream music it happens in underground music - I see a big time in my comments people who get together in groups and they fight for and root for whatever albums are kind of big right now in their respective genres and they're like man god a lot of these same people will turn around and gripe when I review something they don't like I know it's not everybody doing this stuff but still in this day and age there's no excuse for that kind of crap are there some genres and artists that I'm not well versed in and does it show up in my reviews yes but how else am I going to learn and become semi knowledgeable if I don't try to listen and figure it out for myself because for me limiting yourself to a genre or two genres or even three genres of music is just about as ridiculous as limiting yourself to albums that only begin with the letter C I have preferences we all do and that's fine but I feel like somebody can only really be truly comfortable in those preferences unless they've explored their dislikes as much as they have their likes and I have to say there's a lot more to every genre than you think it's not just all the stereotypes that you hear people blurt out in passing without even really thinking about it and let me say through exploring my dislikes I have actually discovered that many of them were in fact likes but hidden under the disguise of a dislike I'm not trying to tell you what's good and bad all I can be honest about is how I feel about an album that's it how you feel you got to figure that out so explore explore explore explore everything explore music career opportunities alternative philosophies new places new people everything is at your fingertips right now when I was 14 all I had at my fingertips was Mortal Kombat you guys have a lot more even though finishing moves are really cool so take advantage of the morning go on Spotify hit up some classical works listen to some jazz blow your ears out learning the nuances of Noise music try some discos some Tuvan throat-singing and call me in the morning you've got my number mm-hmm love you exploration have a nice day for you [Music] [Music]

d like this do you like this you thanks haha I tricked you this is old music this music is all hi my needle drops Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and review time Big KRIT live from the underground Big KRIT is a Mississippi rapper who's been putting the south back on the map recently in terms of hip hop and not for bass heavy hooky club tunes or or trap rap but instead with a modernized version of the catchy soulful and poetic sounds with some of the best southern hip hop artists out there like outcast and goody mob and UGK Cray has kind of perfected his own sound inspired by these influences with three mixtapes he's released over the past few years he fills his lyrics with his personality and his passions like yes cars and girls but also family the trials and tribulations of making it his Southern heritage and poverty and Chris a producer as well always writing his own instrumental which has only made him sound even more unique in contemporary hip-hop and he's not afraid to sing on his tracks either and he does it well on top of all that big craze usually pretty meticulous when it comes to assembling an entire album you're not going to get a disjointed assembly of singles from this guy he's got his intimate tracks his party tracks as his conscious tracks his love songs and he makes sure to transition them all into one another in a very tasteful way really gives his releases the feel of a journey now this is big crits major label debut live from the underground and even though with this album he is sort of hitting it big obviously with the title he's still kind of looking to maintain his underdog image he still wants to be the Big KRIT that fans followed up until this point but this is a commercial record this is a major label debut all bets are off and change does come from a lot of directions on this album to start the production there are a lot of new additions on this album from the really glitchy effects in the female narrator that kind of starts the LP off the sound effects and the really short skits that kind of bring one track to another at some points there are horn sections on here guitar solos are Monica solo string sections and piano lots of guest singers and some chorus vocals too overall this album brings crit's usual mix of a very smooth melodic and soulful tracks and hard-hitting hyped up and jittery spicy southern hip hop tracks as well but with just a little more flow more sound and he definitely uses his label affiliation now to bring in some interesting guests Canadian R&B singer Melanie Fiona Anthony Hamilton another singer as well as blues legend BB King and some southern hip hop forefathers and influences as well on here like bun B and Ludacris which Big KRIT has collaborated with before 8ball & MJG - a lot of doors are open right now for Big KRIT with this LP and he's taking full advantage of them and even though this album by a longshot is not the first time he's ever brought a collaborator on to attract and something new add something different I'm not sure if every new sound on this album goes over all that well the track cool to be southern has these horn sections that feel okay they unfortunately don't really bring the thrill that you would expect from a horn section even as they are soloing underneath crit's verses and if i had to put my finger on a radio single for this LP it's got to be money on the floor and it's a really well produced track with some glistening sense and burbling bass lines however lyrically the song doesn't really add to much more than just a really tame strip club track none of the lyrics on this track really grabbed me outside of a 25 lighters references being very funny or very catchy or thought-provoking and as far as the handful of songs on here that have R&B singers on them go I just really do not care for a single R&B hook on this album and I have to kind of single out the Anthony Hamilton track I just did not care for his singing style on that song it kind of borders on like parody for me with him singing in this really kind of robust voice about coming home strong and that's another moment I didn't really care for now despite all of my complaints I do think Big KRIT writes some of his best songs ever on this album without question the album's first two singles I got this and yeah that's me are stellar both could have easily slipped into one of his past two tapes but feel completely re-energized new and fresh he's got these energetic chants this really hyped up flow and I love the really detail than just subtle vocal samples playing in the background of I got this that is the kind of layering that I expect from a Big KRIT instrumental really impressive stuff these two tracks are essentially just Big KRIT fight songs where you just cannot help but cheer him on the piano the vocal the strings and the song Rich Dad Poor Dad and the story is well are breathtaking quick basically talking about his father and relating his difficulties as a parent to the difficulties Big KRIT may face if he were to become one and from the marching snare drum to the really unique melody that leaves that track it is just a great great song I'm loving the live instrumentation on this track I wish more songs on here featured it if they were to be this powerful I love the song praying man which features BB King his voice on that track field so grainy and eerie I love the forlorn humming on the track it's just a really moody instrumental and Baker it gives this LP a really smooth finish with the last track with him singing quite a bit a lot like the song highs and lows from return of forever but with way more sounds harmonica and guitar soloing you know overall for me this is a relatively solid listen there are some moments on here that clearly move in a more commercial direction but not so far that they ruin the album really just kind of make it slightly underwhelming in some moments just kind of do you like this it stinks do you like this it stinks do you like this it stinks do you like this you think do you like this it's day today hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review from a piece of music and album from an Icelandic band whose name and album title I'm totally going to mispronounce like an American cigars Saguna no cigarettes felt re like I said these guys are from Iceland they're a quartet and one of the most highly regarded names in the world of post-rock and in almost 20 years these guys have been around they've played some of the prettiest and most uplifting music in this style and what helps make that happen are the band's boyish vocals they're really bright harmonious layers of droning guitars moving strings powerful swells very spacious drumbeats propelling the songs towards cinematic finishes and on this new LP Val tardy Seguros definitely keeps up a lot of its trademark sounds now this is definitely not a favorite of mine in the band's catalogue but it is a significant record for several reasons it comes after hiatus also a surprisingly poppy solo record from the group's frontman yangtze and it also follows the release of what is said to be this band's most accessible album with a buzz in our ears we play endlessly which is an album that contained a lot of tracks that abandon the really slow moving and long winding song structures that have made some of this band's past efforts their most popular past efforts so great now I wouldn't say this album completely gets rid of that style it's not like one of the biggest changes of band has undergone and I would say the same for vault re which I think in a way is comparable to the band's parenthetically titled third album and the only reason I compare the two is because that album to me is the closest this band has come to making an ambient music record unless you for some reason count this as a cigarette or something like that but what I'm trying to say is if Valtteri is moving the band in any direction in ambient direction is what it is on this L port on this LP Seguros is sounding much more syrupy formless with lots of repetitive piano chords some haunting chorus vocals and very powerful strings the band goes about creating tracks that feel as endless as possible Trek tracks that really reach out into the horizon where they blur beyond the sight of the human eye it's kind of like being out in the middle of the ocean and I mean in the middle of the ocean miles away from everything on a gray day where the sky is just a perfect layer of gray while the thought of the sight of that can be kind of repetitive kind of monotonous lacking in bold variation it's still so vast and so massive to the point where it cannot really completely be comprehended even with the human eyes staring directly at it but there are some things about this album that I think are going to turn longtime fans off for one this album is not as triumphant as past efforts not as grandiose and when Ciro's does kind of go for something like that like the third track on here which is the loudest on here and has the biggest climax it doesn't feel all that developed despite the very pretty sounds I actually prefer it when these guys head down the road of a track like the second on here the first single from this album which is a song featuring this deep beautiful wall of fluttering strings and yawns ease vocals on this track are great they don't really lead the song not a songwriting or ballad kind of sense they're just there to add another texture but they feel so young they feel so close they feel so intimate as far as other highlights go the fifth track on here transitions flawlessly into the sixth which has these kind of eerily beautiful vocals on them that are chopped and looped for a pretty haunting effect and the final song on here is easily my favorite it a very somber piano piece very subtle instrumentation in the background a very slow pace lots of room in between the notes and despite being one of the quietest moments on this album it is strikingly beautiful and it kind of made me realize that even though a lot of the songs on this album are pretty and I like them very few of them actually touch me in an emotional way none of them really pack the power of this last track I think and I think it's mostly because they're so heavy they're so layered they're so thick with no one thing popping out of them in a really obvious way which i think is a cool dynamic but maybe not what I want to hear throughout an entire album but on this last track the piano is really the star of the show and because of that it feels so lonely it feels so sad it's a real tearjerker and a great finish to the album like I said I wish there was a bit more variety on this album in terms of how these guys executed these ambient pieces and as far as an album from Seguros goes this thing is a little short of breath I think though I do like this LP I don't love it I think there is the possibility for a lot of gold in a strictly ambient album from this band but Valtteri kind of sounds like these guys are just starting to dig for it kind of feeling the light 7on thus album what did you guys think of it have you heard it did you like it did you hate it why what should i review next and yeah that's it so good rows pronouncing things felt re pronouncing things album reviews iceland bro [Music]

it's track review hey Anthony Fantana here the Internet's sweatiest music nerd and it's time for track reviews where we talk about the latest in rapaho um is of the independent persuasion the track that I'm going to be talking about in this review is from a new duo by the name of oxygen they are dropping a brand new debut EP on Jack Jack you are later this year in July July 24th it's tight tight titled take the kids off Broadway Fox's j'en is basically the songwriting duo of Sam France and Jonathan Reed oh and the multi-talented Richard Swift actually mixed quite a few tracks off of their forthcoming EP if you're into him you should also check these guys out vice versa because they do have some similarities in their styles now the first track the label jag Jaguar has thrown out there from this EP is make it known and it was really love at first listen being serious first listen listen to it first time love all the influences in forming this track were just so familiar and have hit it big with me in the past these guys definitely have in art rock and art pop and experimental rock sensibility like The Velvet Underground but their production on this EP despite the fact that it's a little lo-fi it's a little muddy is very refined and detailed and at some points a bit overblown in a really fun kind of bombed bombastic way like a kinks record but there's also that kind of Rolling Stones bravado that Mick Jagger swagger and I'm sure you could also liken some of the music on this EP to Neil Diamond you know just some singer-songwriter music that is very dramatic and nicely arranged these guys II these guys really load on the instrumentation from piano to organ and synthesizer to horns truly wacky and kooky background vocals that range from being coral and and tonal and very beautiful to just noisy and then weird some drum machine some handclaps as well as guitar drums bass all the usual suspects and like I said the production here it's a little muddy it's a little low fine has a very kind of vintage quality to it if you know this was not being released this year I would have assumed this had come from the 60s which is not surprising considering Richard Swift was in on the mixing process of this EP he too has an ear for recreating old style recordings now what's nice about this track lots of change lots of variation the song opens up with these really moody keyboards and this kind of seedy vocal melody that has this splash of reverb on it that really reminds me of like a doors record some upbeat drums start popping in and the song really begins to rock and the vocal delivery builds up with the extra instrumentation really starts delivering vocals and in a very Mick Jagger type style the lyrics play this very confessional role about one's father the hook eventually comes up and just explodes really dramatic really nice stuff the track goes back into a verse but these guys start changing the instrumentation up a little bit adding more detail so the song does not feel the same as it did in the beginning but I especially love is toward the end of the track the band takes the hook that pops up in the middle they revamp the lyrics they change the instrumentation and for the final bow they throw in lots of horns and it turns kind of jazzy it really feels like a stage show like the Rockettes are dancing out in front of everybody and kicking their legs in unison as the song comes to a close in a way these guys really remind me of Ariel pink in that they're taking all of these older sounds and mutating them into something that's just really weird but also accessible so between the messy yet detailed and very interesting production the catchy song writing the fun melodies the nice references to rock and roll's biggest names and the new youthful and weird energy that they're putting into the sounds that influence them this track is just fantastic I love it so take a listen to it let me know what you think did you guys enjoy it did you hate it and yeah why let me know phox phox oxygen hoping to review this EP when it finally drops forever fox again

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd now doing a question comment thing a bit of a hip hop drama occurred this week and I am NOT talking about the Pusha T Drake little Lane thing what was interesting is when Lupe Fiasco dropped a new track titled around my way and when the track first hit me I thought it was a pretty refreshing departure from what Lupe was doing on his last album and for me it was kind of nice hearing Lupe Fiasco bring his usual politically charged lyrics over a classy horn phrase some really crisp drums and paired them both with a pretty nice hook but there was an issue with the track with the instrumental Lupe Fiasco always having instrumental trouble the beat on this Lupe track is pretty much a modernized version of the Pete Rock and CL Smooth track they reminisce over you now Pete Rock heard this Lupe Fiasco track and then he took to Twitter he called the song wack not only does this Lupe track revamp the Troy instrumental in a pretty unimaginative way but like Pete Rock says the track Troy has very personal significance to him a tribute to an old friend who passed away but what I'm here to say is that I really don't see what the issue is here outside of any possible legal problems that could have come from this because there was some stipulation originally as to whether or not Lupe actually had permission to do this track with this instrumental all that BS aside this is how music moves everybody we're all constantly recontextualizing things we hear and love just like Pete Rock did when he sampled that Tom Scott song today for the song Troy off of that album the honeysuckle breeze did Pete Rock sample TomSka in a much more interesting way than Lupe Fiasco's sampled Pete Rock yes but Lupe Fiasco was a new young rapper he is not only detached from the rap scene that Pete Rock originates from in terms of decade and location but loop 8 really has nothing personal that attaches him to the emotions of that song - just like you and me if Lupe listens to that Pete Rock and CL Smooth track he's a voyeur he's looking into the minds of Pete Rock and CL Smooth at that point in time when they were making that song and feeling those emotions we're hearing the story secondhand and it couldn't possibly affect us as just visitors to this story as much as it does them the creators so because of that it's impossible impossible to expect total and complete sanctity going into the future when it comes to classics like this track and it brings up the question does the new generation respect the art and the expressions of the past generation and I would say yes but the thing is this new generation is going to define respect by its own terms they're going to pick the parts of the past they like they're gonna forget the ones that they don't and they're going to reinterpret a lot of parts of it for themselves as well so now mirroring their influences they're sampling what has influenced them making the first generation of hip-hop artists sampling victims of the second haha and this stuff happens all the time it happens when Lupe did this song it happens when Danny Brown says Ryan so real thought I wrote it in POC blood it happens when he mum - racist says I'm at the pizza I'm at the Taco Bell the combination made my eyes bleed and the numerous lyrical references to it was do I think all of these references are respectful do I think all of these samples all of these revamps and visions are tasteful no but these artists are reliving what has put them on the path that they're on today and you have to let them do that they're doing it the way they want to do it even if sometimes it's not that good the first generation of hip-hop artists had to step on a lot of toes to pioneer and do what they did they made music the way they wanted to make it back when sampling was perceived as ridiculous and bad business in the music industry and they did it whether it made their influences happy or not do you think every single jazz or soul or funk artist that got sampled by a hip-hop artists in the 80s and 90s was happy about it there's gonna be both good and bad samples and revisions going into the future and let's just concentrate on praising the good and forgetting the bad so what did you guys think of this whole for a lack of a better word fiasco is this just the natural process of doing things or are there legitimate reasons for anger let me know thank you for watching Anthony Fantana sampling future next generation classics and the past forever

LP cancer 4 cure LP is a producer and rapper and CEO of definitive Jux records he got his rap career started in the 90s as a member of the hip-hop outfit company Flo they released a very fondly looked back upon album by the name of fun crusher plus and took a pretty experimental and and sometimes dark angle to boom-bap style hip hop and then he did what is probably his most celebrated achievement ever producing the instrumentals for the cannibal ox record the coal vein which even after ten years of it being released has stood up as one of the most significant modern underground hip hop albums from producing that LP moved on to his debut album really kind of came into his own started making his instrumentals even more eccentric and building on his experience and company flow to make his rapping much more forceful lyrically dense and highly referential since the release of that debut LP LP has experimented with jazz released tons of b-sides and instrumentals put out a second full-length album where he built upon the sounds on his debut LP and he has now been embracing this new generation of experimental hip-hop artists out of New York as well collaborating with dass racist and mr. motherfuckin ex choir 2 and most recently he produced that badass new killer Mike record that I love the hell out of now this is lp's third album cancer 4 cure it's been years since he has released a full-length rap album but cancer 4 cure continues the sound of that album as if that gap wasn't even there this album has a slightly more alike tronic feel which comes out in full force right from the get-go on the opening track the song request denied features this break beat rhythm that totally has this prodigy smack my bitch up kind of vibe to it but the song is more of a show of production strength for me with tons of pulsating sense and organ solo and some pretty nice drum fills too now the LP that I'm actually looking for comes through hard on the second track the full retard bangin beat bomb squad noisy like version 2.0 SiC groove Fett synthesizers really grainy drums and a catchy vocal sample all make this instrumental awesome LP comes in thrown out versus bragging about his emceeing skills and he proves them with really dense tense verses referencing everything from zombie creating viruses to Greek mythology and throwing some really great rhymes at the end of every line and doing tons of internal whines they're more strong very muscular tracks like that drones over Brooklyn true story the Danny Brown and mr. motherfuckin ex choir featured track oh hell no there are a lot of high points on this album but I feel like there are some let downs to a big gripe for me on this album the hooks for example the track from my upstairs neighbor if you kill him I won't tell I just cringe a little bit every time I hear him repeat that melody and just that that lyric it just breaks the momentum of what would otherwise be a pretty intense topical song dealing in your upstairs neighbor murder and not snitching on that person sadly I was not into the hook on the song tougher colder killer either with killer Mike and despot the chorus on this thing is so long and fits over the groove so awkwardly it's one of the bulkiest choruses I've ever heard the only hooks with melodic choruses that I think go over well on this album are the ones that feature guests singers like Paul banks from Interpol Pernik diamonds of the band Islands with the song stayed down which actually has a great melody on the course it's a long melody but does not lose direction and resolves really nicely at the end of the chorus so I'm now following LP on some of these courses and I haven't even tougher time following him on some of the more conceptual tracks the song that jig is up is definitely one of the most awkward interrogation sessions where LP seems to be kind of prying into this woman's mind trying to find out why she's romantically interested in him it must be because of some other kind of subversive reason and the song sign here is kind of a continuation of that track and is just really painful I imagine for the person sitting through what's being rapped about in the track and just for me listening the last track on here a lot like the intro has a lot of production ambition lots of colors lots of sense really heartbeat tried and true chord progression a nice driving baseline however the song doesn't really have a lot of momentum to me it doesn't have a lot of viscera a lot like the ending of the song drones over Brooklyn where you kind of have these heavy drum hits and it seems like it's supposed to be really powerful and dramatic and heavy but it doesn't really end up being that way you know on this new album LP is definitely as wordy as ever definitely layering his production a little bit more than usual incorporating new elements and some really nice vocal guests too none of which who I think room in this album or take away from it in any way however it's not like this album isn't without its potholes for me on this album LP sort of comes off like an actor who only delivers one single emotional response in a myriad of different situations so for the most part the production on this thing is great the verses are are very much worth reading into and most of the time LP does stick to what he's great at on this album I'm kind of feeling a decent two strong six on this thing what did you guys think of it if you gave it a listen I'm sure a lot of you did did you love it did you hate it one of your favorite hip hop albums of the year so far or maybe not let me know Anthony Fantana LP how nice day forever [Music]

I don't like new music new music is bad it is not good to listen to all music is better old music is good hey shut it up shut it up you oh man it's late because this mount jiri album has been keeping me up hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd tired but passionate still and ready to do an album review Mount Erie clear moon mount Erie is the self recording project of singer-songwriter Phil elrom who once recorded under the name the microphones and put out some of his best material under that moniker the globe part 2 the mount Erie album itself before he went on to change the name of his project and it was hot we stayed in water but under the Mount Erie name to fill has been putting out some fantastic music whether Phil is singing side by side with one of his musical influences Jew lead Warren on the lost wisdom album or if he's embarking on some directionless abstract bare raw acoustic songwriting on the album dawn right there a series of tracks he wrote while in isolation in a cabin in Norway during a winter from 2002 to 2003 whether he's doing what are doing the other he's captivating me I even followed him on his black opening EP where he was laudanum his songs with sounds from the world of hardcore punk and he got even louder on one of his last full-length albums winds pomor he was incorporating elements of black metal into his music over the years i mean phil has just become one of my favorite songwriters however it's really difficult for me to justify that to other people because he does not go by the same rules as most singer-songwriters he doesn't shoot for the same goals he doesn't try to make the same accomplishments which can be a blessing and a curse his music is just undeniably unique but what might bother some people is that sometimes his songs are extremely long or drawn-out sometimes they're very short and have abrupt endings that come out of nowhere rarely do they ever adhere to a verse chorus verse structure and lyrically most of Phil's songs are obsessed with things like death life nature like literally nature like getting down to the specifics of of rocks and streams and wind and trees and mountains fog and oceans as well showcasing this very deep emotional and and almost spiritual connection that phil has with these things some - some - sometimes talking about these things so compulsively it feels as if phil is inventing his own kind of world where these things exist outside of the rest of modern society and when film mentions these things or this other world where these things exist he does not talk about how they inspire him emotionally in a very explicit way or anything like that he keeps his lyrics very obtuse he does this so consistently that his music seems like this intentional challenge to the listener to get some kind of deeper meaning out of what he's saying and follow him down this dark wooded path into this forest like abyss and then just get stuck in this other world like like he is and what makes Mount Erie even more unique is just phil el room's production style the way he records mixes and just produces his music he loves panning the acoustic guitars left and right wildly he also mixes his very shy voice notoriously low especially when the instrumentation surrounding the vocals is getting loud and for the most part instrumentally filled deals in a lot of soft and acoustic sounds but they still manage to have a very kind of rugged quality to them but when Mount Airy does manage to put out a piece of music that is loud and is distorted and is abrasive it is going to be one of the most rough tumbles you've ever had with music period which brings me to this new not Irie LP clear moon fill al-rahman this album goes for roughly the same experience that you will get with just about any Mount URI album but approaches it from a different direction and what that overall feel of this album is that I feel nearly every Mount URI album shares is just that feeling of water tutoring with no real direction or purpose into a forest on a moonlit night this music just has a real sense of isolation and distance from the usual everyday lives that most of us live and that is spelled out perfectly with the opening track which has these really raw acoustic guitars being strummed very hypnotically playing these beautifully embellished chords some soft drums very deep bass jeroni keyboards it's a slow-growing ballad with the instrumentation getting more dramatic toward the end of the song especially with these clanging bells toward the end of the track that are a really nice touch the next track down here is even more beautifully produced the place lives where it sounds like Phil did about 12 or so takes of him strumming these guitar chords and then layered them over one another through some effects on a minute ended up sounding kind of like a guitar Orchestra like this wall of chords that really don't even resemble guitars anymore there's distorted guitar on the track with shots of feedback coming in here and there but that guitar is mixed quietly in the mix as well as the drums - and over that some very light airy keyboards just another example of how weird the mixing can be on a Mount Erie album the track house shape has a very repetitive quality to it especially with the drumming and in a way kind of feels like krautrock a little bit and I love how the since they're just kind of like a rollercoaster going up and down in volume so fast and it just makes this track feel so hypnotic the track over dark water has this really nasty distorted rumbling set of guitars bass as well and it is just a rough sandpaper rough but that kind of fades away a little bit and gives weight to these vocals both Phil's vocals and some female vocals as well later - over one another in this just beautiful chorus that is almost gospel like it is a religious experience just around the middle point of this album the title track on here is a vocally fronted drone Odyssey that lasts seven minutes the longest track on this album 50 Phil actually Auto Tunes his own background vocals and layers them with some untreated lead vocals in a pretty bony ver kind of way overall with clear moon Phil elrom manages to change things up do something slightly new for longtime fans but still keeps his style very potent very experimental and enchantingly strange for newcomers there are some surprising moments on here like the sinister saxophones toward the end of the track lone Belle but the biggest change on this album is the overall tone and the use of synthesizers in comparison with winds poem which really was a storm this is way more serene I think this is the most serene album Phil has dropped under the name mount Erie so far and it's all because of the sense it's come to fruition because of the sins which come in and thicken a lot of these tracks up to the point where they pretty much are drones I mean this album even ends with a three-minute long since piece that kind of burns things out like a dying candle nearly every track on here has a drone equality to it whether it starts as a drone or it progressively grows into one toward the tracks end as far as gripes go there are some songs on here like lone Bell that I wish had a little bit more detail to them especially with the horn phrase toward the end getting a little repetitive just a little over long and in comparison with winds poem and and then other Mount Airy albums as well this album is definitely not that urgent or that gripping I don't see myself putting it on as often as other Mount Erie LPS though it is really beautiful for I see people who are more attracted to drone and ambient music gravitating toward this I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this LP thought it was great but uh what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana thank you for watching Mount Erie clear moon [Music]

do you have a drinking problem it's worth that I bought hi everyone Anthony Santana the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review best coast the only place best coast is a California all these other groups chasing after this certain sound this summery fuzzy upbeat vintage girl group and garage rock inspired sound now my first impressions of crazy for you was that it was very light it was sweet it was fun had a couple really great singles but the more I listened to it the more tired I grew of it and and and this album just makes me think you know there are reasons we have terms or phrases lying around like bubblegum pop it's quick it's easy its sugary it picks you up fast puts a little bit of a pep in your step no consequences no requirements you just chew it and then you chew it and when it loses its flavor you just spit it out but with this new LP it does not feel like a fresh stick of gum this album to me feels like that same old piece of gum that I spat out in 2010 and now for some reason I don't know why I've decided to pull the gum out of the gum wrapper that I rolled it in after I was done with it and just start chewing it all over again this album definitely is a lot less fuzzy grainy or lo-fi there is less of a rock attitude on this album and Best Coast kind of settles into a much more paced spotless and and out delivery the overall sound is clearer the
