the internet the Internet in my hand I've got the Internet cow has a drinking problem hi everyone Anthony Phan 10 the tan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review dope body Natural History dope body is a rock quartet from Maryland and if I'm not mistaken this is their third full-length LP and first for the legendary underground record label Drag City records now Drag City has a very long-standing history of fronting for some pretty experimental bands in the worlds of rock and folk music as well and dope body is no different so let me try to describe their latest LP as kind of a hole to me natural history has an even blend of sounds from the worlds of hardcore punk sludge metal noise rock as well and post hardcore but the album doesn't really have the brooding and intense and just angry attitude that sometimes is tagged on with those genres because blended with these very intense styles of music is this upbeat fun-loving party rock attitude that that comes with a song like Twisted Sisters basically shining through all the aggression on this album are some really nice dance grooves and a little bit of cowbell and some really staccato quirky guitar leads it's just they take all these abrasive sounds and execute them with the most primal simplicity imaginable but then still end up making this album feel like a celebration these guys will put out a track on this album like the song beat which is slow in heavy and lumbering crashing riffs drums and guitars syncopated every hit feels like a ball-peen hammer on the top of your skull but then they'll kind of turn around and do a track like twice the life which has these bouncy guitars with this really bright sheen on them that makes me feel like I'm listening to some calypso music some kind of tropical island punk rock to go further into this good mood kind of feel that this album has the song weird mirror has this chord progression and wailing guitars over the chorus chords that I feel like I've heard somewhere else and some kind of classic rock song something that makes me go whoo yeah yeah well and the song the head of my mind has these very sludgy heavy riffs but they're surrounded in these very newly bouncy kind of silly harmonized guitar leads it's kind of like seeing the the darkest most brutal metal band you can imagine in your head this visual playing in front of you but then mid set all these balloons and and this multicolored confetti just comes raining down onto the crowd and someone appropriate do you know what I'm getting at I mean yeah this album is rough it's tough it tumbles but it still ends up kind of feeling like maybe maybe the most fun exciting sweaty take your shirt off basement rock show you've been to in a while and then afterwards everybody goes outside and starts lighting a bonfire and then dancing around it in unison and some kind of underground rock pagan ritual and every track out here is fronted with these vocals man these vocals it's like a cross between listening to Andrew W K and a cave man the vocals on this thing scream and they grown and they bellow and they go but not in anger my friends not in anger out of liberation instead I would say it's centric it's a rock monstrosity it's a rock-and-roll mutant it feels very modern in that it takes ideas from so many styles and blends them to the point where it's difficult to tell where one ends and another begins the this is made even more difficult because the band really does have a strong personality that permeates every single track but despite this modernist don't body manages to just tune into a wavelength a very primordial wavelength now even though nobody does progress across Natural History with a good amount of variety nearly every track on here functions on a basic principle find a groove that's gonna make people move and then hit it in the weirdest way possible like the song Road Dogg which has these sliding guitar noises all over the track just emphasizing the rhythm as well as in the song powder which has these guitar sounds and then they could be harmonics it could just be a weird effect that bounces throughout the track dance grooves on this record are so herky-jerky and just contorting in ways I didn't think dance music usually did if you would even go as far as to call this album that and there's some great interplay on this record too I mean on these songs it really sounds like the band is playing live they're really rocking out together and there's an indescribable energy to that on the track out of my mind toward the end these guys are really hitting it hard on the climax of the song tendineae neighbor and the track lazy slave when that ends the band is played together just so tightly and building the song into this mountain of drum fills and guitar noises and shrieking vocals the production on this LP is pretty good it pretty much just gets the job done it does have a nice heaviness to it so that when the band does do something slow and just lumbering there is that beef there is that pump to kind of really bring the track home there is also a smidge a smidge of reverb on a lot of the sounds here which doesn't drown anything out it's just an extra sound but when the band really starts jam and hard it allows everything to kind of bleed into one another very subtly the production on this thing is pretty basic but I would argue it doesn't really need to be much more than what it is because dope bodies vocals their grooves their songs and their guitar riffs don't really need any window dressing because they are so eccentric and strange to begin with as far as issues on the self ego you know I didn't really care for the first track all that much it is slow it is heavy and it does have some very interesting chimes kind of just twinkling away but the noisy guitars making these indescribable sounds at this very slow pace as well as the very lethargic vocals it just didn't do too much for me it just felt a bit directionless dragged on and the track just kind of fades out in a very underwhelming way before I really feel like it did much of anything to make it all that memorable other than start the album I guess the cellphone is just fantastic it's just fun it's just fun to me it's just freakin fun it's fine I just want to put it on and go kind of feeling a strong e2a like 9:00 on this album damn it's good but what do you guys think of it have you heard it if so did you love it did you hate it why and what should I take the time to review next thanks for watching Anthony Fantana dope body

Oh whee hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest ignored my needle drops it's time for a question statement comment thing hipster you know the word i know the word and i've received a few passionate comments asking me what I think about the word itself its usage and the culture of people it describes now even though the term hipster describes something very specific even a counterculture of people that dates back to the 1940s that actually philosophically has a lot in common with the modern hipster these days I would say the term is used pretty liberally even though you can use a quick google search and find an encyclopedic definition of the modern hipster with bullet points talking about a huge emphasis on authenticity a carefree attitude or lifestyle and a certain kind of fashion and love of underground music but your average person using the word hipster is not going back to one of these dictionary definitions to double-check what exactly it means before they use the word instead when I hear somebody say the word hipster to me to someone else whether it's online or in person it's an insult it's a cultural slur and I feel a bit bad for the kind of person that uses that word in this way because the sentiments behind a usage like that is usually pretty nasty and in most cases when somebody uses the word hipster maliciously it's 2d legitimize the said hipsters preferences and clothing music or lifestyle making fun of somebody and putting a label on them just for liking a certain kind of music in a in a very malicious way is kind of stupid to me especially since when you do some light research it's it's very easy to find information showing that someone's preferences in music has so much to do with their race their age where they come from their gender their genetic makeup in general and on someone's taste with a one-size-fits-all label to me usually says more about the insult her than it does the person who's being insulted because usually the word hipster is thrown as an insult at someone who is enjoying something the insult er can't appreciate understand or derive joy from and the greatest irony in the use of the word hipster and hipsters love irony the usage of the word hipster especially in a negative light is limited mostly to people who would most likely be considered hipsters by those who thrive more off of a mainstream culture meaning that what is a hipster is relative everybody including you is somebody else's hipster and you know when you insult somebody for thriving within the same web of underground culture that you do you're just kind of where you eat and that's not a good thing you're making things a lot more negative you're alienating people you're just kind of being a jerk moral of the story don't try and trick yourself into thinking that you can just label somebody as a punk a metalhead hippie a hipster whatever and then just cast what they value aside as being worthless you may have had a bad experience with a metal snob or a hip-hop or some shallow hipster but it doesn't mean everyone in that subculture is like that come on don't be stupid and that's it I'm sure many of you have used the word hipster negatively before and believe me it's okay the world is not going to end everything's cool let's just learn from this it's now the time for healing let's realize the real deal be ourselves and concentrate on just being the best people we can be sound cool to you sounds cool to me have a nice day Anthony Fantana the needle drop hipsters forever

now you order some manners oh I look tired it's been a rough week my needle drops it's been a rough week time for a review LP and killer Mike rap music killer Mike is a Georgia rapper Outkast cohort and he's been putting out albums and getting some nice feature tracks for well over 10 years now he even actually put out an LP last year that I regret not reviewing titled pledge mike is such a forceful rapper he doesn't have a really intricate flow for the most part or anything like that he's very much to the point Mike is great with topical songs not only great with topical songs and painting pictures but he's one of the few rappers that I know who can just switch gears so easily without grinding the clutch from a track that is just conspiracy-theory laden just distrusting of the government distrusting of society to a love song or a song about chasing your dreams and then back to a song about some hardcore gangsta rap rhymes another great thing about Mike is that he's got a lot of charisma and for a guy like that I imagine it's easy to network because he has made some really great connections with some of the biggest acts in hip hop in the south from Ti to bun b 3 6 mafia paul wall gucci mane as well but his connections very obviously reach outside rappers with a southern style because because this new project is an album length collaboration with hip hop experimentalist rapper and producer LP best known for his solo work is her ship accompany flow and his beats for the project cannibal ox LP has been really successful in the underground just like mike has for sure these guys are both very aggressive and very visceral artists just looking to make music that grabs the listener shakes them and just warrants some kind of very fast and adrenaline pumped reaction but they both got their different ways of going about that mic NLP do make some notable changes but the biggest surprise on this thing is how natural this collaboration feels it was just a match made and you know for the most part on this LP Mike is himself maybe there are a few more stories and there are brags on this album but this thing is still a pretty even mix of not only hardcore and gangsta style Rhymes but some very socio-political and personal tracks on here as well even when Mike is doing something very aggressive and action-packed like on the track don't die where he's sort of on the run from the police and bullets are flying by his head he will drop some personal information like how his father is a cop now not only is Mike making some minor concessions but LP is too because some songs on this album as far as production goes have a very southern style to them with the clickety and clackety trap style snares and hi-hats like I'm don't die big beast southern-fried a few other moments too Mike brings an entirely different brand of aggression to lp's hard-hitting beats the track big beast paints the Atlanta landscape where he's located with gunshots cocaine wolves grimy streets and bun B&T I dropped by to kind of put together the lyrical puzzle the track untitled has Mike showing this this fear of death being singled out and killed for rapping about what he raps it out and leaving his wife a widow whether he's rapping about his their roots or telling a story about a guy doing some airport drug trafficking Mike is always tough as nails sometimes he's busting at the government with conspiracy theory specifically the Reagan administration but kind of fast forwards to the Obama administration and just kind of sees them as a the puppet for a corrupt government it's not the first time stuff like this has been wrapped about obviously sometimes I wish Mike was a little bit more original with the story brought a different perspective to it but I will say he is a bit more grim than most when it comes to talking about this stuff and the title track the final track on this album which which is amazing is this hard-hitting and personal painting of what rap music is to killer Mike to make a long story short the genre is basically Mike's religion and he raps like it which is what makes him such a captivating emcee throughout this album now as far as LP goes his instrumentals on this album just bring Mike's style a completely different dynamic a different angle for the most part LP has built a reputation on his production as having a nice combination of not only hard-hitting sounds but kind of kooky sounds to which is portrayed perfectly on the track big beast we're matched up against these huge base hits and in southern style rhythms are these kind of silly and and farty synthesized hurts it's gritty but it's also kind of cartoony it's it's kind of like reading a hardcore hip-hop comic book or maybe better yet a graphic novel and as if it wasn't already a surprised LP showcases some really great versatility on this album - whether he is putting together a short and just straight to the face banger on the track go which has the skipping vocal samples the track don't die explodes and just bangs even on a higher level and makes my story about just being on the run from the cops feel kind of like an action movie and that tranquilly Berkshire would that I mentioned earlier the instrumental on that just hits the perfect sad chord that the lyrics do I mean there's just a range of emotions hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review a real-life actual review not Chokin marilyn manson born villain this is the latest LP from the band / songwriter / singer frontman musician Brian Warner and a lot of people may look at this review and ask Anthony why do you even bother you don't usually cover music like this you are someone who has a huge crush on on rock pop electronic experimental metal and hip hop music for the most part of the Independent Business Assistance or suasion don't you have some kind of natural hatred for Marilyn Manson deep inside you that cannot be shaken well the truth is back in the day when I was a teenage fat non music nerd guy who wouldn't know a punk band if he heard one I thought Marilyn Manson was awesome now what's his influence on me and my enjoyment of his music due to me being young and naive I would say yes to an extent but I think his music and his message had a lot of merit to it from about the 90s up until the year 2000 I think at the time when he was at his hottest he was writing some of the catchiest industrial and alternative metal out there and even though I wouldn't ever say one of his albums topped the music of one of his biggest and earlier supporters Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails Marilyn Manson's place in alternative metal and industrial metal is not going anywhere for a while because he definitely had his own approach to this stuff sonically and philosophically albums like Antichrist Superstar were a nice mix of just abrasive hard rock elements and electronic music - most time the selfie is extremely raw noisy and just grim and if you could see yourself getting past a Marilyn Manson stigma I would definitely try checking out this album because if you really look into it it is a very well produced and extremely textured album and is very much powered by Marilyn Manson's greatness as a front man he is just the high priest of everything offensive on this album from his really low gothy kroons to his throat shredding screams he is just a great singer on this LP though the darkness on this album is kind of melodramatic and it always has been with Marilyn Manson the production and the songwriting makes up for it in a big way for me now the only thing that I think could potentially overshadow Marilyn Manson's music into the future if it hasn't already is his image his message because Antichrist Superstar was not just an album it wasn't just music it was a slap in the face of religion of censorship of conformity you could boil it down to shock rock but Marilyn Manson definitely had contemporaries that were trying to push buttons as well like Mudvayne and Slipknot Rob Zombie - but Marilyn Manson definitely proved to have stronger tunes on his side thanks to the collective writing abilities of him and his band and you can argue that there are plenty of artists out there who pushed the boundaries further than he did whether it be just visually and aesthetically or just philosophically or politically I would say a guy like GG Allin definitely went a lot further than Marilyn Manson did in terms of lyrical content and stage antics - but Marilyn Manson understood that there is a balance here if you're going to affect a widespread audience there's only so far you can go before you just start alienating people he just found this pocket where he was able to throw atheism and war and violence and sexuality drugs into the public consciousness with this weird white-faced lanky lipstick wearing image but was still appealing and catchy enough from a musical perspective to appeal to an audience large enough to just keep his message into the mainstream now Antichrist Superstar which which gained I think the most attention out of all of his albums was easily the freakshow in his discography his next LP mechanical animals was somewhat of a retreat still push buttons but was much more of an introspective look themes of conformity Fame drug addiction sonically the album had more since was more palatable catchy er a lot less noisy and some people would even call it his glam rock album it was an interesting transformation and to me after this album comes my favorite in Manson's discography hollywood on this album anthem goes back toward shoving all of these taboos and everyone's faces but with a bit more refinement definitely not as harsh as Antichrist superstar but in a lot of ways just as grim and dealing in death Fame and again religion but once we just cracked the barrier of the new millennium I fell out of favor with with Marilyn Manson personally for a lot of reasons first off Marilyn Manson's next album the Golden Age of grotesque was so repetitive and filled with so many bad and just fluffy pointless hooks that even his most hardcore fans had to recognize there's a bit of a fall from grace going on here not to mention it really lacked the variation and the ambition of his previous three albums it seemed like his crusade to shock in his fight against censorship was kind of dying actually I would I would say it kind of succeeded because people in general and even in the mainstream media were just no longer repulsed by Marilyn Manson's favorite buttons to push kind of wore off which really took away Manson's bread-and-butter maybe his his muse the album's eat me drink me and the high end of low definitely tried to fill these gaps with tracks that that described violent sex fantasies or maybe some hoax that had more profanity in them musically Marilyn Manson was definitely revealing some some personal music influences a track would pop up and had a strong blues influence that would be songs that had an even stronger New Wave influence maybe even an old-school post-punk influence to them Plus around this time I had just gotten into punk music and had decided that it was just nothing else in the world worth listening to instead and I don't think that it's any coincidence that Marilyn Manson's fallen popularity correlates directly with most of his core audience graduating from high school and going on to college but born villain Marilyn Manson's new record and his first since being let out of his contractual obligations with longtime label partner Interscope Records is not really sitting all that well with me and the biggest and most obvious reason right off the bat is that with Interscope Records leaving so did Marilyn Manson's production budget it's not an unlistenable album but Marilyn Manson has not been sounding this raw since portrait of an American family he continues on this LP to kind of show his love for very early goth rock and post-punk it most definitely shows up on the track the gardener which has this this dance beat this groovin bass line as well some shots of guitar noise and Marilyn Manson doing this very kind of cocky spoken word piece I actually think it's pretty great and the song murderers are getting be every day has a very harsh ministry style industrial metal quality to it that is just very abrasive however there are moments where the stripped back recording quality does not do this album any favors whatsoever like on the song pistol-whipped you hear fingers sloppily rubbing against the guitar strings as they go up and down for riffs and the song no reflection I'm surprised it's a single off of this album because it is just so badly edited and produced it just feels like a really nasty demo and there's not much subtlety or detail or variety on this album outside of a few slower ballads toward the end that may feature keyboard or acoustic guitar I mean Marilyn Manson has really really reverted back to a simple structure of just drums vocals and guitars and that would be fine if I felt these tracks for the most part had that energy and had that Drive of early Marilyn Manson but it doesn't so it just ends up making these very simply built songs that last four to five minutes each dragged on especially the song slow motion Manson's usual melodrama and his trademark kroons are on here but I'm just in no mood to deal with it with all this weakened production and undercooked songwriting there are moments on here where I think a track will emulate his older style and it will feel pretty good like hey cruel world badass riffs and Manson doing this insane vibrato on his vocal and that is one of the things that I would say actually advances and becomes interesting on this album Manson's voice he's still a great screamer and still a great crooner but he's also experimenting with doing some shrieking doing some whispered vocals singing in different registers more vibrato spoken-word like I said - he still got personality but this record just does not feel all that pleasing I like some of the post-punk vibes coming off this album but it feels like the further we get away from the 90s and and the further we get away from Manson's relevancy as a crusader against censorship just the more off the mark his music kind of feels I think eventually like Arthur Brown or like Alice Cooper Marilyn Manson will go down in history as one of the greatest shock rockers to ever dominate a decade but still if he keeps putting out albums like this I think what I mentioned earlier will most definitely happen and his image will just drown out his musical contributions kind of feeling a strong three to a light four on this album but what did you guys think of it if in fact you listened to it it was - it was Anthony Fantana Marilyn Manson born villain forever

my Death Grips tickets hmm hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review absol control system absol is a California rapper this is his second full-length album it's out now on rapper Jay rocks label Top Dawg entertainment and he's also a member of the rap collective black hippy which is kind of just his cohorts on top dawg dawg including j-roc schoolboy q and my favorite Kendrick Lamar now I first caught absol like I'm sure a lot of people did last year on the Kendrick Lamar album section 80 a fantastic conceptual mind-bending hip hop album that you must check out if you have not one of my favorites of last year an absent one of my favorite verses on the entire LP on the track absol doubt row and I thought it was funny that a guest rappers verse pretty much summed up the entire emotional package of section 80 in one single track I had to check the dude out and I found out that his debut full-length album long-term mentality was dropped earlier that year so I took a listen and overall I thought it was decent it wasn't really impressing me to any great extent and I guess my biggest disappointment about this LP and this is just from hearing him first on Kendricks album it didn't feel as deep I guess as what I heard him spitting on on Kendricks album now control system is out absol sophomore album release 17 tracks on this thing and overall more length more energy more variety and more topical songs too as far as rapping goes I feel like absol is coming off way more passion on this LP whether he's telling a heart-wrenching story getting wasted bragging or attacking societal norms he just sounds just upfront Center attention demanding relentless there are just too many sides to his personality on this album to attack in one brief review sometimes he's clever and cocky and blunt blowin and rapping in this upper register vocal delivery that actually reminds me a lot of Danny Brown he actually resembles Danny Brown so closely at some points it's almost impossible to tell the difference between him focally and Danny Brown on the Danny Brown featured track terrorist threats now when AB is kind of on this trip I feel like his personality pretty much boils down to a line from the hook on the second track to this album track to abyssal abstract asshole an abstract asshole it's pretty much a perfect depiction of the personality that he displays on control system but just when absol may seem like he is the most egotistical guy in the world he will spit a line about how poor he is or just say something proving that he doesn't take himself too seriously now the free range tracks on this album are really great absol just brings one unexpected juxtaposition after another but the topical tracks on this thing are pretty great too absol can tell a story or really getting the gist of the meaning behind the track or his personal philosophy the track terrorist threats with Danny Brown is kind of about personal freedom and achieving that through some kind of the Warriors style gang collaboration revolution the track double standards is about exactly that but in relation to gender and kind of having this personal desire to respect women but then realizing that's not exactly the societal norm that we're dealing with here and the book of Sol is is one of my favorite tracks on here comes up toward the end and is about this really long time love interest who had a huge impact on his life but then of course she passes away and not only is this track about the personal story of him and her but just the emotional terror the aftermath that comes with losing that person now the production to me isn't amazing it's for the most part a lot of traps Stiles snare drums and high hats just clinking and clicking away against some really refined samples and then glassy keyboards again it's not something I would rave over if this were an instrumental album or something like that but I do think absol sounds great over these instrumentals the Aries string sections on track 2 are really great I love the muddy jazz sample on the song bohemian groove the very pretty piano melodies on the track double standards are a perfect foundation for that song there are a few surprises kind of like the track terrorist threats which gets especially dark bleak and kind of weird the instrumentals on here go hard when they need to they get very pretty and emotive when they need to but still despite the subtle detail there is something about these instrumentals that feel kind of messy feel kind of rough around the edges something that kind of gives this album a street vendor soul mixtape grittiness to it overall I feel like this album's greatest asset is personality just add souls personality and lyricism - to me there's no extremely strong concept or narrative that brings all the tracks together into a tightly packed punch the intro this album would have you believe that this album is about control systems mind control wanting to live your life the way you want to live it without the influence of laws or societal norms and while those themes are on here I feel like the biggest theme is just the many sides of rapper absol the features on this thing are pretty great for the most part it's it's just the top dawg entertainment crew and friends that appear on this album there's a great black hippy pasa tract on the end of this thing I wish the album had a bit more originality to it you know there are definitely contemporaries of absol that you could easily compare him to that he just has a little bit of in his style like Kendrick Lamar like Danny Brown and there are even some spots on here where he will embark on a swag rap track like little B or ASAP Rocky I wish there were more topical tracks I wish the production was a little bit more adventurous too but still despite all of that I felt that this was a really fun and engaging listen kind of feeling too light too decent eight on this album what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why what should I be reviewing next Anthony Fantan oh absol forever you

I've been dying to review that record show it to me ah yeah my needle drops hi Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and review time beach house bloom these guys are a Baltimore duo and they play some of the most dreamy and seductive pop tunes out there hmm and the centerpiece of their music is the vocal of frontwoman Victoria Legrand it has a very soft quality to it it also has a very nice range it's not just one of those voices that hangs in the upper register while Victoria can get up there and just belt out some really high and an emotional notes I feel she is at her most haunting when she's kind of hanging in those really deep smoky lows backing up that vocal is Alex Scalia tar which is usually played with a root note octave being very pleasantly bounced back and forth sparkling with reverb and against this guitar and the vocals are layers and layers of synthesizers whether they're cute little arpeggios atmospheric droney synth chords that that sound so blissful or some pretty deep resonant bass notes that that are very subtly giving thing a nice fleshed out feel now the band used to be back to simply by some pretty old-school sounding drum machines but the band now kind of broadens the rhythms on their albums out with some acoustic drums which they started doing quite a bit on their last LP teen dream and they continue to do it on bloom but the rhythm is still hanging in the background very subtly and allow the guitars the synths and Victoria's voice to just enchant now sound is very important to beach house really important there are a lot of bands out there right now working with a similar sound just writing catchy pop or rock tune slathered and reverb slather an atmosphere and to me beach house is one of the few groups that despite all the effects that are clearly a pivotal part of their music they still come off very warm very loving in everything that they do very intimate not distant not obscure to the point where they feel alienated if you throw a ton of effects on a song you're essentially putting a barrier between the listener and the song and of course I mean song and a more traditional sense notes lyrics chords but even with all the effects beach house still comes off very potent very melodic and showcases some fantastic songwriting they have a personality that I think would ring true if the effects weren't there but the effects are important if they weren't I don't think Beach House would be working with roughly the same sound for four albums now and I would actually say that there are less differences between bloom and its predecessor than there are in the two other gaps between Beach House albums I'd actually say the band experiments a little bit less with this LP bloom is definitely not the surprise that teen dream was with its extra instrumentation and and a few left hooks as well especially with the track ten-mile stereo with its throbbing pulsating rhythms and in fast pace was a pretty standout track for me so while I do not find bloom all that surprising beach house does make a clear difference between this album and team dream with songwriting not necessarily better but different songs the track the ours is is a standout for me and has a slightly lightly fuzzy guitar or a riff that kind of shows beach house just rocking out very gently Victoria's vocal melody on the verse is catchy enough and for me it gets even catch here on the chorus don't care about me it has this really nice descending quality to it that I think is just it feels like a lullaby and yet it just kind of sucks me in the opening track myth on here starts off with a pretty simplistic rhythm like a lot of beach house songs do but they managed to change things up just a little bit with this metallic clang that is pretty sharp and attention-grabbing and I just get this field from Victoria's voice that I'm being sung to directly the groove is great but I love the way the track just changes pace and explodes with the sparkling guitar cort toward the middle of the track it actually reminds me of the way the blondie song atomic changes up from its verse to its chorus not only is the change very musical but it's also very emotional it's a huge mood change for the track it's impressive and the thing is with beach house especially on this album I especially get this feel here there's nothing on this LP that's all that loose or thrown to the wind or just left up to chance a lot like a Beatles album or a Beach Boys album to me everything feels so crafted every note every rhythm every chord though I did say beach house sticks to their guns on this LP that's not to say that there's no variation on this album certainly each song is different melodically but there are differences production-wise to the track wild easily has the quirkiest drum machine on the entire album the track lazuli has easily the quirkiest synth on the entire album troublemaker is one of the sadder tunes on here new years one of the faster tunes on here on the sea is a beautiful piano ballad and Irene the closer on this album is if I'm not mistaken the longest song beach house has has written which builds up to a really huge just emotional climax for about six minutes there are more differences to be noted but the thing is you have to kind of dig those up for yourself because yeah they are here physically and musically and emotionally those differences but most importantly those differences between this album and Teen Dream for you have to be personal if this is your first time listening to Beach House great this is a great introductory album everything I said in the introduction about the band's style if that appeals to you try it out but as far as the personal thing goes again though some of Victoria Legrand's lyrics do stand out it's more the emotion of these tracks that appeal to me and that's why I think it's kind of easy to forget beach houses songwriting and just kind of let your ears glaze over and just listen to the very atmospheric and hazy tones however I would say somebody that feels that way is maybe missing out I'm not trying to tell you what you should or should like but each houses means it can be very engaging if you just dive into and actually think about what's happening these guys are dream pop but they're the last band you should sleep on honestly though I do wish beach house ventured out into the unknown a little bit more with this album experimented more surprised me more it is a great LP because they are kind of working with a perfected formula and the songs on this album don't feel like deja vu to me in fact they're great songs and I would say all the extra instrumentation that beach house has been using for their past couple releases is executed with a bit more finesse with a more tasteful ear this time around with another record for me beach house continues to kill it with this style of sound there are a lot of bands out there playing gentle dreamy pop and rock music that appeal to me on the level that beach house does so I'm kind of feeling strongly to a light 9 on this album what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why what should i review next and what did um ah I think I think that's all my questions yeah it is should I ask another question let me know Anthony Fantana beach house bloom [Music]

melodic and poetic post-hardcore with with heart wrenching storylines and lyrics if you said that I would recommend this band's first three albums keep in mind this group's material gets more raw and aggressive as you go backwards through their discography incorporating more elements of hardcore punk but me without use 2006 album brother-sister is really the crown jewel in the band's discography easily their most blended effort right here showcasing a variety of different styles from indie rock to post hardcore to folk rock and just folk music slathered in horns and accordion and even though there is quite a bit of variety it all is held down through this common thread frontman Aaron Weiss's vocals he's very overly emotive on a lot of me without using material and will morph quickly from this just impassioned aggressive scream to these whisper quiet murmurs and verbally he will always be doling out these very sad and personal ultra personal and sometimes extremely painful and detailed lyrics now the band's next LP it's all crazy was a pretty big change for them stylistically basically me without you allowed the full keyer side of their style to just overtake themselves completely not only was this album much more acoustic but the lyrics changed a bit too borrowing a lot from folklore to develop its storylines and using some really funky rhyme schemes as well now after the shift with it's all crazy we now have this new album ten stories it's a self released LP and I think a lot of older fans are going to see this album as a little bit of a return to form for me without you it definitely rocks out way more than it's all crazy but does have its shots of folk music just like brother/sister but the storylines feel nowhere near as heart-wrenching or depressing or really the most part on this thing he is either straight singing or just delivering these spoken word vocals in his trademark murmur a murmur that reminds me a lot of like listening to slit a bit of a detour but whatever now another thing besides some folk influenced that me without you maintains past its previous album is just simplicity simplicity in its song structures most of the songs on here are pretty straightforward you do have the occasional change in direction the occasional surprise like on the end of the track nine stories where the track really changes completely and I love the lyrics in this spot of the song if the weather withers up you're fine Jacob knows a ladder you can climb for the most part this album is very hooky like on the track grist for the melody mill and Cardiff giant that folky simplicity is not really completely lost on on me without you and that would be completely fine with me and it in fact it is completely fine with me what ends up bugging me about this the track eastenders wives for me is a prime example there's lots of very pretty and flowery language being thrown in every direction and the lyrics are telling a pretty esoteric tale I would say but it's track review hi everyone Anthony Fantino here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a track review where we talk about the latest in rock pop electronic and experimental music of the independent persuasion sometimes metal and hip hop is well and after many many comments many radio edit requests asking you to do so I'm going to touch down via video the new animal collective single honeycomb / Gotham as many of you may remember back in 2009 the New York experimental psychedelic and electronic music outfit animal collective dropped its breakthrough full-length LP Meriweather post pavilion and between now and then a lot has happened to the group they released a full-length feature psychedelic experimental art film titled odd sack they had an EP come at the end of the year after the release of Meriweather post pavilion that was pretty great also there were two Animal Collective related solo records released by panda bear a navy tear unfortunately I was not really that into either of the albums both of them felt kind of underwhelming for me I caught a lot of flack for really not being on board with these albums but to me they just kind of felt like Animal Collective records but with with less and when I say less I mean the elements that the other members would have brought to what this one member created in his solo release so now this outside of a record story release that the band had out recently is the first major piece of material to come from the band in a wild it's got two tracks a side honeycomb b-side Gotham and I'm really enjoying both of the tracks actually I'm enjoying honeycomb the most i love the track and what's so great about this song and just animal collective new material in general since Animal Collective blew up with the album's strawberries Merriweather Post Pavilion there have been a lot of copycats coming in and just biting their sound and with this song at least Animal Collective has managed to stay innovative fresh new and fun honeycomb starts off with a peculiar vocal sample and then it just erupts into these rhythms that feel faintly African but also kind of Caribbean there are these shouting group chorus vocals in the background that are usually featured and Animal Collective tracks that kind of harken to that of the Beach Boys you know some kind of experimental weird Brian Wilson production which is a more relevant comparison than ever since those smile sessions came out last year and even though I wasn't totally in love with them now head over heels with them like a lot of people were it was interesting to see the musical madman inner workings of Brian Wilson's head around that point in his career the vocals are really fiery and really impassioned all these noises are just so rich and bright and fun I love the addition of the horn on this track and there's this synth line over the hook that kind of sounds like a pan flute or something it's really fun noisy upbeat track and the drums on this thing had this interesting effect on that makes them feel like they are maybe it's some kind of strange phaser they are being stretched and then sort of returned to their original shape it's like I just see this multicolored field with with all these shades and hues and tones just bleeding into one another and then over this Hill is this kaleidoscopic sky and it's just changing colors and shapes and Merriweather Post Pavilion was definitely animal collectives most accessible effort to date but they went down an accessible route by making an album that really kind of bordered on overproduction really glossy hi Sheena on this LP with honeycomb I feel like the band is reverting a little bit back toward that more mm simple chaotic feel of songs on strawberry jam but they're definitely being a bit more straightforward with it production-wise this does not feel huge or over-the-top it's at a really nice middle ground as far as goes on this single definitely the more chill of the two tracks the grower of the two tracks it starts off with this sun-baked introduction that feels like just being left for dead in the middle of a hot desert and then these very simple drums come in and they are playing in three and the track kind of progresses into this slow psychedelic Waltz the vocals on this track have these short little bursts of of screaming in them too and I'm not even screaming but just gruffness of aggression of just intense emotion but the overall emotional package of this track is much different than honeycomb honeycomb is an upbeat this is a lot sadder especially when you start catching little whiffs of what the vocals are actually saying and in regards to not being given feelings you're saying goodbye this track is in a lot of ways just as sound rich as honeycomb but it doesn't feel that way at first because it's so much more spaced out it's not as dense but sonically there are just as many strange things going on I do think the vocal melody rings through a little clearer on this track and while it does not feel as fiery as honeycomb it's just as pleasing but in a completely different way so what did you guys think of this single did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana honeycomb and Gotham forever

you went to the record store what did you buy yeah what did you buy hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd time for a review b.o.b Bob Bobby Ray strange clouds this guy is an Atlanta rapper producer and singer and this is his official full-length follow up to the 2010 album The Adventures of Bobby Ray which was a huge introduction for him went to number one in the u.s. sold gold had a really big Bruno Mars featured single with the track nothing on you and on this album Bob Hurley built himself up to be a really versatile artist who kind of reaches across genres and this kind of played out in the features that he got all over his debut album with Bruno Mars Lupe Fiasco Janelle Monae Rivers Cuomo of Weezer Hayley Williams from Paramore and Eminem and Bob continues that trend on this new LP with a really diverse set of features coming from Ti Chris Brown little Wayne Nicki Minaj Taylor Swift even Morgan Freeman does this really dramatic monologue to open up the album the array of artists this guy attracts is really impressive but you know the thing is that the music to me is not just the 15 tracks on this new album pretty much add up to a lowest-common-denominator pop rap album that does not really focus on anything except just trying to create a load of carbon copy tracks tracks that follow the blueprint that usually gets songs played in heavy rotation on pop and hip hop crossover radio stations nearly every track here kind of has its own little modern radio pop motif that it appeals to the track so hard to breathe has these really vague notions of being drowned in the pressures of life with this bursting rock chorus singing it's so hard to breathe there's a track on here with a Taylor Swift chorus acoustic guitar in the background not a bad song at all but Bob kind of goes in wrapping on this track asking sincerely I think why people are so greedy why they're so shallow good question question worth exploring but a question that kind of baffles me because Bob will kind of turn around and do a track where he's talking about poppin bottles or a pretty girl or money or cars there is a little wayne feature on here with a lot of corny punchlines coming in left and right and kind of further that Young Money brand Nicki Minaj comes in on a track on this LP as well a song where Bob is going crazy and the mantra seems to be out of my mind him and Nicki kind of have fun with the track and and I do like the very wobbly beat on the song it's it's got a weird groove to it that I think is pretty interesting and a lot of the other tracks on here just kind of have okay hip hop beats but then we'll kind of shift gears into a very bright pop or R&B chorus tracks like castles just a sign or chandelier where the hook is like my heart keeps pumping heart keeps beating shining like a chandelier yeah but I like Bob's positive attitude and his fast flow on the track there's a lot of personality there sincerity I thought I think the outside of some corny punchlines and some corny hooks I don't really take a lot away from Bob as a rapper because he has a great flow for the most part art art art I just don't like how this album consistently doles out one spoonful of sugar after another after another after another I seriously don't like my coffee or much of anything that sweet to kind of make matters worse Bob will do a track that kind of throws out a vague love song story like on the track circles one of the more personal songs on this album though that I did think was great was the closer where are you Bob versus Bobby gray where he raps from the standpoint of an angry fan who kind of perceives him as selling out sounding different losing touch with his family it's it's a good song but the thing is I guess Eminem totally did something like this better who would stand for sure that because everything on here feel so formulated for wide consumption the overall taste of this album is just really really mild and you know that's Bobby's goal this album pretty much does everything in its power to avoid anything lyrically musically that will require a second listen to understand pretty much what Bob does on this album is use the colors normally found in mainstream pop rap today and then just kind of uses them to paint a portrait of himself and I do feel like it's easy to kind of sit here considering the kind of music I usually review and usually enjoy pointed this and then say oh this is mainstream ooh this sucks but really I didn't find too much on this album that I hated or just enraged me so to me this thing is just kind of really middle-of-the-road just middle of the road so I'm kind of feeling a strong four to a light five on this thing what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana b.o.b forever [Music] [Music]

I'm home from the record store hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review loan galaxy garden loan is the recording pseudonym of uk-based electronic music producer Matt Cutler this is Cutler's fifth LP and a lot like another electronic music producer featured on this album Machinedrum his LP last year rooms I refute it a lot like him color has toyed with a lot of different electronic music styles on past releases everything from house to acid house and instrumental hip hop and glitch hop wonky downtempo to but I feel like his last album his last collection of tracks in a full-length capacity city struck an interesting retro nerve definitely a 90s House vibe coming off on some of these tracks with really bright punctuated synth chords and melodies definitely music I could see playing against some sort of video montage promoting an all-expenses-paid vacation to some kind of a beachside resort but I do mean that in a good way and had a few points on the echo locations EP that loan dropped last year he walked down that road as well but with some some glassy er sounds and now this new LP is out and to me it's it's an interesting spot in the evolution of loan there are still flashes of that really fun upbeat dance floor ready hard-edged and let loose 90s house vibe but the sounds on this thing are produced with a much higher Sheen everything on this album is so shiny and so rich it's like a color gradient of classic cars spit-shined - spotless perfection all kind of lined up and parked right next to one another going on in this line and it looks like it goes on for infinity or you could liken it to a really massive laser lightshow or being about 12 or 13 and 1996 and first laying your eyes upon some Nintendo 64 games these are pretty much images this album draws up for me experiences that this album reminds me of and it just has an immense emphasis on funky grooves and tons and tons of synthetic colors the since on this thing really do glisten like sun rays shining through an island waterfall it actually reminds me a little bit of that rusty album glass swords that drop last year but does not overdo it it does not get so bright and so sweet that it starts to kind of give me cavities and like that rusty album glass swords and and like that machine drum album two rooms this LP incorporates some elements of footwork and future garage music into its rhythms it's a clear influence on a good chunk of these tracks and it's led to some really intricate beats as far as I can tell this is relatively new territory for a loan to be this rhythmically dense and I think this is just what he needed in order to produce a new album that felt fresh that felt fun and I think this new direction this change in direction is implied with the opening track new color the title another kind of sound or just feel that kind of pops up on this album for me is just this sense of being really sunny and tropical and yeah it does partially have to do with the sense but I think it has a lot for me to do with the Jerome's not only the poly rhythms they're playing but the tambour of the drums listening to the drums and a lot of the grooves on this album to me it just feels like calypso music on steroids and just sped up immensely this sound does not come out too strong on some of the harder tracks on here like crystal caverns and 1891 but if you take a listen to the second track off this LP the animal pattern it's really strong and of course it does not help that there is an array of sampled sounds playing in the background that sound like they have been ripped from a jungle so I mean I've pretty much laid down the influences and the sounds in this album and for the 12 tracks that it lasts with the exception of a few interludes it pretty much plays with varying combinations of these sounds of these styles but there are some highlights along the way producer machine drum has really nice not even a production credit but a vocal feature on the third track there's a nice stuttering synthesizer on the song too that I think is pretty great and Machinedrum has featured a second time on this album on the track of tulu toward the end of this LP and while I do like the track I don't feel like it adds as much to this album as the first feature did the tranq lying and reeds is definitely one of the slower grooves on this album and when it comes up it it comes up it's great because it really hits me just how fast a lot of the tracks on this album go crystal caverns 1991 easily the hardest track on this album I love these synthesizer chords when they start hitting in the same the same this really aggressive way in today dude it's really punchy feels so much like an old-school house track and I really love how lone we'll start layering these really sweet synth leads over that rhythm the track Earth's Long's has one of the fatter heavier synth bass lines on this entire LP which really makes a stick out for me a really spacious introduction to and the album ends off with a nice vocal feature from anikó which is one of the more soothing tracks on here did not really hit me as being as fiery as some songs on this LP but it is a track that I do think will grow on me more as I revisit this thing there were a few tracks on here like radiance and dream girl that I thought were okay but didn't really add a new dynamic to this album for me I mean Dreamgirl skysurfer but overall this album is just so right and just so intensely fun that it's hard for me to take my eyes off of it it's hard for me to take my ears off of it but not really bright or flashing in in a cheap or simple way because the production chops and the detail is here it's here in spades just great tracks great grooves fantastic production nice variety between these songs and just a style that I'm very much into feeling a decent - strong 8 on this LP if you guys have heard it what do you think of it love it hate it why and what should i review next thanks for watching anthony Fantana loan

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busy and it's time for a review album review off self-titled this is a California punk band featuring vocalist Keith Morris best known for his roles in the band's Black Flag and Circle Jerks I reviewed offs first released a few years ago first for EPS which sits proudly in my collection and was definitely one of my favorite releases of 2010 gave it a glowing review but this project has a bit of a catch to it not only is it punk music but it's an intentional throwback to Keith Morris's days in the earliest years of Black Flag's specifically you know around the nervous breakdown EP time and everything from the riffs to the vocal style to the cover art to even the band's name points in reference to that point in Keith's career and the first impressions on on this LP off is definitely keeping things raw it feels and sounds like they recorded this album in half the time they recorded the first four EPS sometimes Keith's vocals hardly even sound eq'd on a few tracks here they are so much louder than everything else that when Keith screams everything is just drowned out sometimes the drums are really buried - I can hardly make out what they're doing the guitars feel kind of muddy here and they're just just from time to time but but the energy is still behind these songs they're still performed with a lot of intensity those somewhat thrashy California skate punk riffs are still there they're still all over this record but the overall package is definitely not as bright or as crisp as it was on first for EPS it's very claustrophobic album there's not a lot of space between the instruments in this mix some things drown out other things but it kind of has this very overwhelming charm to it at some points I guess and yeah maybe I am being a little nitpicky about the sound of this album but to me it kind of ruins the momentum of these songs to not hear the drums and the bass really shoving the tempo along like they should on the cell P off sometimes will deliver tracks that feel like slight variations of ideas that were on the first four EPS like the intro track wiped out which is this rock-and-roll riff that is sped up to a punk rock fury or on the song cracked actually this happens on a lot of songs where the drums the bass and guitar riffs and Keith's vocals will all kind of syncopate in unison off is one of the few punk bands to use this technique as much as they do and sometimes I guess even though it does kind of bring them a distinct flavor I do feel like they can be a little heavy-handed with it sometimes with his vocals Keith will come through with a really snarky and personal message that is so just nasty and and focused but vague in in some ways I'm just dying to know who or what he is singing about like on the track I got news for you where he directly addresses someone who thinks they're the the king of the scene of course keith has tracks they have a really strong political message behind them to like borrow and bomb or toxic box and sometimes they'll throw in a bit of very dark humor into the song - like on vaporized baby punk may not be your thing you may think Punk is dead you may think that this album does not add anything wildly original to the world of Punk but you do have to admit that over the years Keith really has maintained his his charisma musically I feel like off tries a bit to be less one-dimensional this time around Keith has some points where his vocals are narrated or he's singing a little bit these can be kind of hit or miss for me especially when I don't feel like his vocal is mixed all that well but I do appreciate the variation there is a really nice slow-building guitar intro on the track King Kong Brigade and I like the heart dissonant chord hits in the middle of jet black girls that really kind of breaks the song up and adds some really ugly colors to the mixture this album does not really where it's welcome and it's it's difficult to pull tracks out at first at first when listening to this because it's all just this flurry of varying degrees of just intensity for 16 tracks that run roughly 16 minutes the style of this album is so close to the blueprint of the first four EPS that if you missed the first four EPS and check this out you will probably like it maybe even love it and think it's one of the most badass punk LPS you've heard in a while but if you really loved first four EPS like I did it may be easy to like this but maybe difficult to love it mostly because this is so similar it's impossible impossible for it to make the same shocking impact that this sound first did when first four EPS came out there may be some mixing issues on this LP for me but the tunes on here are good and I think Keith's vocals are still great kind of feel them a decent too strong seven on this thing what did you guys think of it did you like it did you hate it why what should i review next and thanks for being awesome love you see you later bye

part people are legally legally streaming new albums and songs or or their favorite albums and songs from the past now I mean I actually use Spotify personally when it comes to reviewing albums sometimes if a new album has come out I haven't got a promo for it or I haven't picked up a copy of it myself I will just go try it on Spotify if it's available for streaming and then maybe even go listen to their past records on Spotify if those are uploaded as well and even try out some artists that influence that artists or similar to that artists and of course there are other similar not forget that I also think YouTube itself is kind of a music streaming platform you guys know that that there's a lot of music streaming on YouTube that I have streamed that you have strained artists and record labels even upload songs and music videos to YouTube to just tease toward forthcoming releases or just give fans a taste of what an album is going to sound like now I'm not against the streaming music model I'm not against the streaming platform I don't think it's going to destroy the music industry I do not think it's going to destroy the physical side of music either but it could definitely give mp3s and downloads a run for their money if services like Spotify become as II easy quick and simple as just kind of going into your iTunes folder and then just grabbing a song that you have bought or downloaded and then just listening to it right there and as the internet speeds up and these services become faster and programmed more efficiently of course that's going to happen unless some kind of legal issue gets in the way but the thing is stuff like free music streaming services that are legal is something people kind of want people don't want to have to pay to try music anymore and part of the reason this is because there's the sheer amount of music out there right now there's so many artists that are price gouging their albums letting people sort of pay what they want and then get them or just giving them OI entirely for free and of course all of this competition to the bottom just to be heard just to get some buzz and get a fan base and get people megaupload have been restricting access or just shutting down completely piracy is still rampant the government can't even stop drugs from being trafficked into the country how can they stop ones and zeros from being trafficked across the internet now the beauty of this new system though this new streaming music platform system could be a solution to actually getting artists paid okay look at this this high on fire record I bought this record with my own money but the thing is high on fire only gets paid one time when I buy this one record and some in the current state of the music industry would even argue that the amount of money that they make off of this sale is not even that much now if I take that high on fire record and I listen to it once a day every day for the rest of my life high on fire does not make any more money they just make that one record sale and that's it but if I'm listening to them on a streaming service if I listen to that on a streaming service every day for the rest of my life they get paid for every single stream that I make now even though there have been articles that show that the amount of money artists get paid from streams on Spotify is horrible something around 10 pounds 10 dollars or so for around 100,000 streams there will be a lot more options out there if we embrace this model and allow companies other than Spotify to do this kind of thing if there were other legal streaming services out there then they could possibly offer competitive rates to artists to have their album exclusively streaming with them premiere streaming with them whether it be through in advance of money or through a higher pay per stream rate so yeah even though at this very moment the whole pay artists side of this model sucks there are lots of ways this system can work and we're not going to find out a way to actually make it work in favor of the artists if we just sort of reject it and stamp out the spark before it even becomes a flame and even if the record companies sort of take their medicine and then just spit it out it's not going to make a difference because if we get rid of streaming services people are still going to pirate music the best thing to do now is meet this compromise and actually create that listening booth experience that people are always likening piracy to streaming an album off of a website where you don't technically own the mp3s and maybe the artist gets paid every single time you stream one of the songs that is more listening booth like to me of course the revenue for this money will come from ad sales it will come from subscription payments and that's just the model that we're facing at the moment like I said I want artists to be paid but you know we're just gonna sit back and see how it pans out do you use Spotify or music streaming service is do you prefer them to downloading music pirating music have to go look for music whether you're torrenting it or you're sort of downloading it off
