it's be making time hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and time for a review The Flaming Lips and Hedy Twins The Flaming Lips are a psychedelic rock band with plenty critic and fan acclaimed albums under their belts they're a band that's kind of built a reputation on making music that is in a lot of ways fun very colorful sometimes very accessible and catchy especially in the case of the soft bulletin or Yoshimi battles the robots but the band is also wildly experimental now while most bands tend to kind of settle into a sound or an idea or a style in their old age The Flaming Lips are doing the exact opposite after about 30 years of making music together instead of trying to maintain their career by being as predictable as possible to their fans they are embarking on all these strange projects that make me wonder whether or not any of them are suffering from the beginning stages of early onset dementia ever since the release of embryonic great album by the way Wayne Coyne and the band has just been focused on not really putting out full-length studio LPS but just doing things I'm not sure they would be able to sustain if it were not for the fact they have so many great albums celebrated albums and their back catalogue like an album length cover of Pink Floyd's Dark Side of the Moon these short collaborative releases including artists like Neon Indian lightning bolt Yoko Ono and the Plastic Ono Band and a 24 hour song encased in a mini harddrive encased in a gummy candy skull but out of all the band's latest exploits this The Flaming Lips and Hedy Flynn's is the most sort of approachable somewhat accessible and album like thing that they have released but it hasn't really been garnering that much attention outside of hardcore fans for several reasons in a way it's sort of a compilation featuring tracks from these previously released collaborative EPS if you want to call them that that featured artists that I mentioned earlier and this thing was pretty much a vinyl only Record Store Day release which from what I understand is sold out right now so good luck getting a copy plus I'm sure some of the collaborators on here just the sheer number of them might have intimidated some fans not only because of who they are but because of how an album like this might be perceived oh it's filler it's just a bunch of crummy songs why would the Flaming Lips have this person on this record and how do they even get this person to agree to be on this album and perform to their specifications in this given track lots of guests on this album raised those questions not just a few Biz Markie Kesha Erykah Badu Chris Martin of Coldplay essentially this album is 13 tracks with a handful of interludes and each song has its own little special musical guest and like I said some tracks on here have been previously released but others are entirely new but but but Flaming Lips really structured this album to flow as a very cohesive project and all the guests on this thing appear on these tracks in a very Gorillaz album style capacity where they kind of play an actor role and The Flaming Lips are doing their best to direct this person through the madness they have written and overall I think they do a great job of that because there's not one single song on this album where I feel like the star power or the image of the guest taking part in the track overpowers the song itself believe it or not I think Kesha is actually fantastic on the opener she adds a really kind dark and sinister vibe to an already dark and sinister song 2012 where the lyrics are kind of about becoming obsolete and maybe the world coming to an end the track just seems so apocalyptic especially considering how noisy it is just these guitars to sound so freakin distorted and abrasive I really would not recommend turning this album up to loud because to me just the guitar sounds especially on this opening track are like razor blades getting shoved directly into your ear canals but the groove and the melody and the hook on the song are just kind of so fun and catchy I can't say no despite the the very slight pain there's this very jungle primal garage rock beat to the song and these very kind of psychedelic ah whizzing by in a very colorful way the bony bear track right after this one I thought was great too I love the the muddy drumbeat on the song how it felt so obscured and and just the very airy atmosphere of synthesizers that are slightly distorted to kind of just coloring everything surrounding the lyrics and the song itself and Boni Vera forces is locked in the background kind of vocalizing in a very slightly auto-tuned kind of way and I like the emotion that he adds to this track kind of about a romantic relationship where one person has up and so is the other person but one person just happens to be up in a good way while the other in a bad way the track helping me retard it to find God featuring Edward Sharpe I thought was okay I didn't really feel like the song itself in terms of the chord progression or the melody or anything like that was was all that unique the sounds surrounding the track were certainly strange certainly quirky but the tune didn't really hit me as being all that fantastic I guess I kind of felt the same way about the tame impala track on this album while I am pissing and moaning the Yoko Ono tract to me felt a little too repetitive in the Erykah Badu tract though very beautiful and pretty with her vocalizing in this in this very distorted sea of ambience is little daunting at ten minutes in length but really those are my only issues with this album the track supermoon made me pee featuring preview 73 is really awesome and how it builds up in this very intense way they're these shakers kind of splashed with it with a nice touch of reverb buzzing guitars and since lo-fi drums kind of playing this very fast roll and I love how everything is so obscured by this lo-fi and grainy recording and yet it is so just enthralling and exciting and colorful the track that ain't my trip with Jim James from My Morning Jacket is heavy and just kaleidoscopic with color and the lyrics are hilarious right at the first line he's singing about this person who is singing to wanting to shave his balls but batting his trip I love Nick caves mad man's style rant on song you man human he just comes off so intense and attention demanding as usual it's to be expected from the guy and the lightning bolt feature on the track I'm working at NASA on acid has a very nice David Bowie Space Oddity esque intro where it's kind of funky kind of psychedelic very spacious and dramatic but then lightning bolt kind of interjects right in the middle to build things up to this really epic explosion the track becomes hectic and pummeling just as it sort of fizzles out the same way it kind of started the track is David Bowie dying which features in the on Indian has this heavy guitar on it that twangs and echoes like something out of a spaghetti western it's kind of like tripping on acid in the middle of the desert and the track girl you are so weird with new fumes is I think one of the most fun songs on here I love the way the keyboards kind of dip and out of tempo on the verse but then when the chorus comes around everything tightens up and just explodes in a really aggressive way and the final track on here with Chris Martin is actually kind of hauntingly beautiful his voice sounds so just pitch perfect and shellack I would say sort of reminds me of something off of that first perfume genius record overall I thought this thing was really great listen I know the other collaborative releases that Flaming Lips put out recently did not go over too well but taking all of these songs released an unreleased and placing them together on one album has made all of them really really potent I think you don't really get an opportunity to have a dream fantasy of what you think of Flaming Lips collaboration with a certain artist should sound like so it's definitely easier to go into this album without any kind of preconceived notions and just sort of enjoy it for what it is there are lots of variety among these tracks tons of highs and lows beauties and uglies and everything in between but kind of feeling as strong I wish time machines existed so that I could go back in time and force myself to buy this on vinyl like I should have on Record Store Day what do you guys think about this album did you love it did you hate it why was it surprisingly consistent considering the sheer amount of guests and varying musical minds on this LP to you let me know Anthony Fantana The Flaming Lips Eddy Flynn's

Hey still mad yes what you did was unforgivable hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd it's time for a review billy woods history will absolve me billy woods is an elusive DC MC and according to his label backwoods studios this is his second official full-length solo album and his first in 8 years of course between the releases of these two albums he spent a good deal of his career being one half of these super cron flight brothers but now he is back at sort of a lone wolf capacity with this album and i would say a lot about what Billy woods does has progressed since his last LP the chalice pretty much everything from the recording to the beats to billy's personality and flow it's it's really an improvement on all fronts now even though this album does have great great production ultimately it's Billy what attracts me to this LP he's got this really tough as nails persona but it does not feel like pointless posturing throughout the album which I really hate but he doesn't really spend all that much time bragging anyway where I get all this toughness from it's just the really gruff and raw vocal delivery that he has in his rhymes he's just really attention-grabbing to me as soon as I heard him I just figured man a guy this angry and emotive has got to have something important to say something interesting to say and thankfully that is the case between the 20 tracks on this album there are some songs on here that are kind of loose in terms of subject matter just kind of all over the place throwing out lots of just sharp criticisms lots of punchlines and plays on words and these days when a lot of MCS try to embark upon that kind of thing I end up kind of tuning out the MC and just vibing with the B but I don't really feel that way with Billy woods because even when he is all over the place lyrically he's still dropping gems like the opening line on the track crocodile tears which is clearly aimed at other rappers 32 bars and how you rob and kill your neighbors and still have the nerve to ask God to save you and the problem with the army is they want to be the boss the problem with secret police is they're like a dirty gun you can't toss so yeah there is some really great smart free-range lyricism on this album that that ranges from being pretty hot to good but for me Billy is at his most potent when he has a subject matter he's focusing on and there are a lot of odd about tracks on here doing that like the track cash for gold which miracle II paints a portrait of strip clubs strip club life these women who are kind of subjecting themselves peddling their bodies for just chunk change and then kind of talking about the guys who go to these places and depicting them as just being soulless apes with no compassion who are kind of there to just pretend they're rich and make it rain and and put their child support money into g-strings or the track Bill Cosby which is about this father who shouldn't have even really been a father in the first place and wished he never had kids or gotten in this relationship and now he's just growing to be this bitter freakin jerk the track DMCA is really sharp criticism of the music industry and music fans and the Internet age kind of just downloading uploading and then deleting from their computers every piece of music that they listen to kind of this really disgusting purge cycle the track Pompilius is really intense track talking about just war crimes and military violence and injustice now billy has this flow where he doesn't really ride the groove the track he's on too hard but he is on tempo the Rhymes and his verses just kind of come together like part rapping part ranting making him sort of a combination of an emcee and just an all-out madman in a way he kind of reminds me of MF DOOM and that he has really dark and gritty personality with a very very consistent flow but Billy woods also kind of reminds me of guys like del the funky homosapien where he's very up and in-your-face making these just unapologetic tell-it-like-it-is observations left and right and he's got this really kind of forceful delivery and this affinity for very unorthodox instrumentals that also reminds me of guys like LP or projects like cannibal ox to me the guests on this album can be kind of hit or miss some of them just indulging in the kind of posturing that Billy does not do hence why I like him now the production on this thing to me is just stellar but Billy has a history of rapping over unconventional stuff on his last album he rapped over a Velvet Underground sample of all things and I'd say he's even getting more adventurous this time around with guys like Willie Green am breakups Marmaduke NASA and man mantas on the beats the opening track is really kind of dark and murky and gives the feeling of Billy woods kind of crawling very slowly out of this swamp to return to hip-hop again in a solo capacity and the track crocodile years is the ass-kicking face-punching track that this album needed to really get things started I love the skipping guitar leads on the tractor we sharp synthesizers the track body of work has this really slow lumbering tempo that goes along with the vocal sample really well the vocal sample is this woman's voice singing about breaking rocks in a chain gang and just the tambourine on the track resembles that of a chain rat in just the heaviness of the bee just feels like you're slaving away breaking rocks I love the mournful strings on the opener the really quirky piano on the track Bill Cosby adds to the comedy of that track in a big way and the track headband is just one gigantic Led Zeppelin sample there's not a beat on this thing that I didn't think was at least good the only spot on this album instrumentally that I didn't care for as much was the track pump up the volume where the singer Lorenz is featured on the track and her voice just kind of flies out of nowhere against another sample and that kind of feels like it's just thrown on to the beat in a really sloppy way though that seems to have been done purposely I still don't really love it outside of that there's not really much I could say that's bad about this album I do think it tends to drag on a little too long maybe a leaner album would have hit me with with more force but there are so many great lyrics on here and fantastic instrumentals that re listening and relisting and re listening can be extremely rewarding kind of feeling a late decent 8 on this thing what do you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantan Oh Billy woods forever [Music] [Music]

hi everyone the Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review torch her mana craft I'm saying a torch it's how I'm gonna say it torch these guys are a florida-based doom stoner sludge metal band that I've been a fan of for years now around five years or so but this is the first time I'm actually reviewing any music of theirs torch does not really have the best or most celebrated sound in this style of music but nonetheless they are in their own lane especially on this new album hermano craft torch is a part of this new breed of metal group that emphasizes thickness heaviness just brutal rumbling guitar riffs just the kind of sonic frequencies that specialize and just reach down in your gun shakin everything up but I would not say especially these days with with this album torches style does not come off brooding or dark or overly aggressive like a lot of bands that perform this kind of music and a lot of elements add up to this feeling for one instead of very screamed or forceful vocals frontman Steve Brooks sings in a very clean delivery and he always gets his vocals mixed in a way where they just soar over the mix leaving this jet stream of of firework explosions and rainbows behind the distortion on the guitars isn't too abrasive it feels much brighter this time around in comparison with the band's last full-length LP meander fall the band pumps out a lot of songs and a very punked out manners sticking to lengths that are around sometimes one to two minutes and the hooks this LPR extremely catchy which is to be expected with torch and even though their brand of stoner metal has always had a really strong early strong element of melody in some songs that is just increased tenfold on this album and it's kind of added up into some tracks that to me feel a little bit like a power ballad or like an arena rock song something that I really see like lighters blazing - specifically the melodic bridge on reverse inverted or the introduction on the track kiss me Dooley I mean the overall mood of this album is really uplifting and just positive even the slower and heavier moments on this LP have a very positive vibe to them I think like the track solitary traveler which has these numerous layers of guitars just creating a really heavy atmosphere and the song actually reminds me of a few tracks from torches previous LP me and earth all but it uses its heaviness to be heavenly the volume of this album the ribs the solos all of it brings together this feeling of just overwhelming joy rarely is an album this loud and this pummeling is throttling joyous and I like how torch work to really make every song on here have its own personality to an extent the track letting go which is the intro on here sets the really bright uplifting tone for this LP the drumbeat on the song and the vocal melody - just makes me feel like I'm about to embark on this epic metal fantasy journey the track kicking right after it is one of the catchiest tracks on here very melodic guitars over the verse and the the build-up up to the hook is just massive and when the hook finally kicks in and just slows everything down and brings those massive guitar riffs and it's just pure ecstasy and the track reverse inverted as a fan to cook and is very much one of the slower and heavier songs on the album but throws out this off-kilter sort of groove this off time signature that is played out very naturally by these guys yeah the track sky trials is the shortest on here for me just just over a minute in length and extremely faster to the point really epic vocal part at the end and I loved how it segues into the song roaming right after even though a lot of these songs are very catchy very very poppy torch really has an obvious focus on the overall flow of the album with how one song will sort of hit just as another one meets maybe a sudden stop the title track on here is a really tight instrumental and just like on me and earth all torch saves its heaviest and darkest moments for the end of the LP the closer which it's pretty heavy in comparison to other tracks on this album but the band has definitely been heavier in the past and I think the band replaces that darker and just more brutal mood with something that is adequate for me in a way and I feel like a lot of people could come by this and say hey you know what this is just kind of a torch as usual album even though the group is making efforts to change its sound up a little bit to the point where I think people who are not even into metal and loud rock can enjoy this thing maybe I am splitting hairs a little bit and separating torch from the rest of the pack more than some people would but the only album in in recent memory for me that has taken such a heavy sound and tried to make it so easy and fun to listen to is possibly that last Mastodon record the hunter and and I was really into that record as far as sludge stoner doom metal whatever you want to call it goes torch for me is the sweetest band out there it's pretty much like doom desert not something I'd want to eat every single minute of the day this album is by this music standards pretty sugary still very pivotal part of the meal if you've got a room for it kind of feeling a light to decent ate on this thing you guys think of this LP do you love it do you hate it why I think you should try it out and maybe try to answer some of those questions for me be nice love you Anthony Fantana torch forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review actress our IP actress is the pseudonym of music producer Darren J Cunningham and so far this guy's musical career has been consisting of producing tracks that play toward the the settlers side of electronic dance music relying more on interesting sounds and textures to make his songs powerful as opposed to high volumes and and really hard-hitting rhythms his music definitely has a magnetic pull for fans of guys like Nicholas Jar Pantha do prints and going back to listen to his old work I really love the the very grainy quality to his 2008 album haze evil it was energetic enough to just make me want to move but also quiet and experimental enough for my own private dance floor now two years ago the album splash that actress released had much more variety not only taking sounds from from old-school Detroit techno but also the UK electronic music scene where actress comes from as well and the project also started incorporating some heavy heavy influences from ambient music too and on this new LP actress is sounding more ambient than ever really taking it back with the drums and the Bryson's there's nothing very overt about this album much of what happens on this LP is very implied an example would be the second track on this ms/ms miss thing ascending there's this very very lightly lightly pulsating rhythm in the background against use these glistening synthesizers it sounds like listening to a techno song on the radio but you're sort driving out of the range of the radio signal so you're losing a lot of the lows and the mids and only really getting some of the highs of course there there's some sort of some rough washes of white noise swallowing the music a little bit obscuring it to me this track represents just house music that feels so apocalyptic it paints pictures of of barren landscapes and desolate cities the first track to really win me over on this album though was the song jargon which is easily one of the most ambient songs on here it lasts around six minutes and it is not as constant as some of the other songs on here not really focused or hard-hitting rhythm or anything it pretty much sounds like a muddy metronome keeping time for this very spacious open and shy piano phrase just sort of blinking around in a really meandering but endearing way and there are these very soft electronic glitches kind of keeping tempo for the song as well and they are just whisper quiet I really feel like actress is just releasing his inner Brian Eno and the track serpent and shadow from fry fry fry fry from guitarists those tracks bring the fort of the floor beads back that you would normally expect from actress assuming you've heard his previous two LPS but I would say here he does it with some much weirder sounds now even though I am going gaga over some tracks on this album I'm not in love with this thing by a long shot because to me this is very much an unwelcome kind of 180 for actress and I'm not even talking about this album being slightly more ambient than usual for actress the some of the more ambient tracks on here are my favorites what I'm talking about is I feel like a lot of the songs on this thing I think are not as developed as material on splash and Hayes evil there are a lot of great sounds and ideas on here but a lot of the tunes that those ideas are in come in and fade out so quickly they don't really leave an impression though the sounds on our IP and holy water and aerials Blackheart though those tracks appeal to me sonically how quickly they're over just does not mmm sit well other tracks on here that managed to breach that three or four-minute mark just kind of fade out in a really lazy way without having developed a climax or much of anything I guess it's great that actress wants to step outside the traditional expectations for a song you know who says a song has to be a certain length but me personally I only wish that some of these songs were longer because some of the ideas they put forward are so good and I wish that they would go deeper progress more and then I mean I'm sad to say but this LP does not really feel like much of an album to me at all it feels more like a compilation of rough ideas sketches few b-sides actress is able to pursue so many sounds in electronic music and and conjure up some really interesting ambient hybrids too but there's no real common thread bringing all of these tracks together for me nearly every other song kind of feels like a detour a departure that's that's my main gripe with this album plus there are a few tracks specifically that I do not care for at all the really slow spaced out groove on the track tree of knowledge is kind of interesting at first but waiting for that track to go somewhere is really you like waiting in line at the grocery store to get checked out and the synthesizers on marble plexus I don't like it at all they just kind of stumble across the really constant rhythm in a very clumsy way kind of like a drunk guy trying to find his footing on his walk home from the bar at 3:00 a.m. there are some highlights for for fans of actress but but but but I'm kind of feeling that a strong five to a lay six on this LP what do you guys think about it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next any Fantana actress r.i.p forever

you are just laying there you've been laying there for a while well I'm gonna do something about it hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's white son's sinews white Sons is a Brooklyn mouth noise punk trio and this is their sophomore LP it's out now on load records it's six tracks lasts around 30 minutes and despite the brevity it is a very intense listen now despite this being noise rock noise punk it's not really your very rockin with heavy catchy blood pumping side of this style of music white Sons is much more heavy much more artsy not really looking to rock you but instead perform brain surgery on on anyone willing to listen to their music through the ear canals with tons of ear piercing guitar feedback improvised drums and some very disturbing abstract lyrics if I had to boil this album down to a phrase it's kind of like a really raw chaotic noise rock poetry slam and for a three-piece that is guitar bass they come up with some pretty interesting sounds there are lots of low-end drones feedback that flies into various pitches there are some sounds that I'm not even sure how these guys are even making them to be honest like I'm a song see know where there's this guitar kind of hanging in the left channel that's lame it kind of brought me back to the first time I heard Health another noise rock band that is much catch here than white Suns by comparison but I was pretty perplexed by a lot of the sounds they were producing too either I am perplexed by the sounds of a given track or I am just so in love infatuated with how jagged and how angular some of the and quickly strum guitars whose chords I think are like the key of Z the next track has these floor tom drum rolls that I love that are constantly speeding up or slowing down and there are these very twittering guitar noises that make me think of like metal hitting glass or like a swarm of spiders heading toward me or something it creeps me I'm just thinking about it the track footprints fill the third song on here is easily the most Rocking on this entire thing it just has these relentless syncopated drum and guitar chords hitting together over and over and over and over it is like getting bashed over the head with a hammer until your skull caves in one thing I do think is is kind of exceptional about this record is the band is always changing the shapes of its riffs or they're building a song up they're winding it down there's always some kind of shift going on they're basically saying hey you know what true traditional song structures screw courses and refrains we don't want any of that but even though these guys are really working hard to to be outside of that that structure they do organize their songs white Suns really places all of its ducks in a row on a lot of these tracks with some very clear and impressive transitions linking one section of a track to another I like the feeling of intensity why suns has that but I also like the feeling of progression of going somewhere and white Suns has that his well however I'm not saying this album is going to be a walk in the park it may not necessarily click the first time around it didn't with me but the sounds were so interesting that that I continued being intrigued and wanting to return to this album because I've been listening to it on and off for a little bit so though it may not all appear in a really obvious way at first there is a method to the madness of these songs and if you want to talk about madness the vocals on this album are pretty maniacal pretty twisted now I can't really say hey on this track the vocal delivery was was especially Minaya no I can't say that because that's the case with every single track here I do wish the vocals did present a little bit more variety either you're hearing these these really extreme ragged screams or a very kind of deadpan narration but despite the fact that I may have wanted a little bit more these two you know styles do match what's going on with this album very well the song temple picks things up with this really kind of slow crushing groove yeah I kind of imagine in my head that this is what it's like to be very slowly eaten alive by something that is around two or three times your size with these giant metallic guitar cort teeth crushing down on you with every bite the closer is great to with with these very kind of primal drum beats that to me just stopping and starting and stopping and starting and then eventually it just kind of all ends as the big fat noisy broken sounding bill kind of clang even though it is noise rock music and sounds very modern there's something so kind of ritualistic and ancient about this particular track I did come at this thing with a few gripes I do feel like the production the recording on this thing could have been better could have added to the intensity of the sound um a lot I do think white Suns is sounding better than ever their production that recording is definitely of a higher quality in comparison with their first album the sounds are definitely brighter more resident bolder but the vocals were a little more distanced that I would have liked him to be the drums were much more distanced than I would have liked them to be they kind of sounded like they were recorded with two or even one microphone placed far away from the drums just with a lot of ambient noise and everything but the guitars felt so close this album just has an incredibly dark and sick energy to it that I love that I think has made a lot of the the best noise rock records out there great I'm not necessarily saying this is one for the history books but this was definitely an incredibly solid listen with some great songs that I'm going to remember by the end of this year and a nice little detour a nice noisy detour for me in my listening trajectory kind of feel a little strong 7 - a light 8 on this thing what did you guys think of it if you've heard this album did you love it did you for a review jack white blunderbuss jag white is a detroit singer-songwriter detroit originating singer songwriter he currently operates out of Nashville Tennessee and between his record label Third Man Records and all of the artists he's collaborated with over the years released records for over the years and celebrities too not to mention the numerous bands he's been in this guy has a nice little musical Empire for himself and it's all fueled by his great songwriting and strong guitar playing and his love for blues rock and garage rock gospel and soul and vinyl records now I know jack best as one half of the white stripes I assume that's how most people know him best with the very bright and rich guitar leads that were all over those white stripes records with huge huge guitar chords just smothered and distortion as well as some really fat husky drumbeats coming from from egg white it was hard not to feel like they were simultaneously saving old-school rock and roll but also presenting something completely new after the fantastic album elephant though I kind of fell off the wagon with the white stripes between get behind me Satan the rat count tours the dead weather Jack was just not making music that I cared for but this new LP new solo LP is a little bit of a return to form that I think a lot of fans and rock writers who have followed Jack for a long time are going to enjoy tracks like I'm shaken and 16 saltines will most definitely appeal to an old-school White Stripes fan who really loved the harder side of the duo 16 saltines has these booming tough-ass drums and these amplifier on fire guitar chords that just make me wish I had really long hair so that I could throw it around in every direction as I do this and the track I'm shakin is is really tough as well that has a huge gospel trip going on especially on the vocal breaks between the guitar parts when Jack is singing it sounds like it could have been a white stripe song but it is fleshed out with these very dazzling female background singers it's it's a nice touch and that's another thing that may appeal to people about this album hearing Jack White's usual songwriting style completely unadulterated in the way that it would be in the white stripes but fleshed out a little bit more with extra instrumentation whether it be synthesizer organ electric piano some saloon piano background singers some pedal steel as well the song on and on and on has this really elegant string introduction on it and the song take me with you has this very Dave Brubeck take five piano groove going on I love love the jazzy woodwinds on the track love interruption one of the first singles from this album and of course Jack continues evolving his more experimental guitar sounds like on the track wheat themselves to sleep on the bridge there are these dueling guitar solos and the left and right channels but they both sound like they're being played out of these busted glitchy stuttering amplifiers and it has this really disorienting effect that I love jack is just a musical madman and no matter how poppy are just accessible his songs gay you can always look forward to little weird detail like that to pop up in his songs now despite some new production sounds on this thing overall this album kind of makes me feel like it's 2003 all over again spots on blunderbuss feel so close to moments and I mean specific moments on the White Stripes sophomore album on white blood cells on elephant I mean like songs I'm bound to pack it up dead leaves in the dirty ground I'm finding it hard to be a gentleman I just want to be the boy to warm your mother's heart the balance but it's close to his his old sound because I mean let's face it it's not really that old as close to his old sound as Jack gets on this album there is still mmm something about it that feels less wild less free less exciting less dangerous I guess and and kind of rehashed like a White Stripes Chop Suey with you know the occasional fresh ingredient added here and there just to make it feel different I would say Jack keeps up his lyrical game though by talking about some really strange relationship dynamics dangerous love interests and infatuations as well as some characters who just kind of live on the fray like the girl he's singing about in the track 16 saltines and the falsetto vocals on that track just kind of add to the eccentricity of the persona being sung about I love the lyrics on the track missing pieces where Jack is talking about how when someone exits a relationship with you they essentially take a piece of you with them but Jack kind of literally talks about like missing body parts freedom at 21 kind of talks about how because this woman Jack is with has freedom in in the 21st century because of the suffrage well it seems that this has made the tables turn according to Jack and and now he is is suffering physical violence from from this person he's loving and of course the song love interruption has pretty much the the idea the concept of love being very physical and violent with Jack and he's pretty much welcoming it even when I'm not really into the melody of song or the chord progression or whatever I can usually rely on Jack to continue to be clever and entertaining with his words which is great Jack still manages to you know kind of surprise me in that department but he doesn't really push me or much of anything musically on this album like I said there are some extra pieces of instrumentation here and there but to me it's it's just a little bit of window dressing because a lot of these songs that they're core don't have a lot of mm to them like the pedal steel performance on the title track just felt so plain I kind of feel the same way about the the piano playing on the track hypocritical kiss because there are more instruments to keep track of I feel like nothing is really being played in a really strong or standout way on a lot of these songs same thing with the drumming the groove and the monkey on the bed lyrics on the track trash tongue talker - I'm not trying to say good chunk of this album is bad or anything just very underwhelming but like I mentioned earlier some of the extra instrumentation that lands onto this LP does knock it out of the park like the huge climactic ending on the closing track here and then again those woodwinds on love interruption are great I guess there just weren't enough rockers on on this album for me more ballads than I would have liked but the balance to me didn't feel especially moving or anything like that nothing in in the league of of Apple Blossom or I think we're going to be friends though track like hip eponymous poor boy does come really close that is a that is a cute and pretty heartwarming song and the track weep themselves to sleep I I do love that piano is so dramatic on that track and it is a heavy song I feel like I really can't say too much about this album on the side of positivity without still having these thoughts kind of twittering away in my head reminding me that oh yeah I don't like this part I don't like this part I think a lot of the songs toward the end kind of taper off and a really Oh kind of way I feel so on the fence and aggravates me because I thought this album was going to be just great given the the first two singles to drop from it before the release were we're stellar in my opinion yeah I know especially sixteen saltines sounded maybe a little bit too much like old school white stripes but the energy is there and that's ultimately what makes it so appealing for me and makes some of these songs kind of unappealing to me sometimes the energy the passion the fire is there and sometimes it sort of seems to be fading but the thing is you know I'm not really going to stress this review or how I feel about this album and and neither should you mostly because even though we've known Jack white for a long time this is his first official solo album and in a way I see this as a new beginning for him the guitar solos a lot of the songs the guitar tone and the lyrics on this thing I think are still really great just felt like this could have been so much better I guess kind of feeling a decent two strong six on this thing but what did you guys think did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next Anthony Pham tanto Jack White blunderbuss bro [Music] [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review battles dross glop records stored a just happened this past weekend hope everybody had a good record store I got a few things one of which is the new high on fire record got that on vinyl double LP fantastic pressing really great album art I got that mc5 Afrika Bambaataa 7-inch I talked about in one of my videos and I totally completed my battles remix series like a complete nerd so now that I got all four of those remix 12-inches I figure hey you know it'd be a good idea let's review the dross Club album so battles is an experimental rock band that underwent some pretty big changes on its sophomore LP that got released last year gloss drop they had just lost a pivotal member of the group and they were kind of working through the change by bringing on a bunch of guest vocalists not only that but their tracks were feeling much brighter much more playful and upbeat to me the band was just taking its trademark tight sound in a much more colorful and bright direction on that second LP battles just had the intricacy of a math rock band which is not surprising considering the the group's ties to bands like Don Caballero and links but they also jammed like an improvisational rock group but these really hard intense relentless grooves it's almost nothing but fire on every track and the whole LP is just can to me I can't say no because of all those attributes gloss drop landed in my top 10 of favorite albums last year so of course I am totally interested in hearing a series of remixes for every single song from this album no matter how bad they are especially considering the lineup of people remixes these songs few I have have done reviews for Shabazz Palaces Hudson Mohawke the Field Jacket AMA I who was a guest vocalist on the last track from the album as well as code-nine and kangding Rey but-but-but I usually do not enjoy remix albums and I usually do not review them either for one there's usually not much in the way of a flow or consistency since what you're really talking about here at the end of the day is kind of like a compilation of different artists all remix in songs in their own way there's bound to be some stylistic clashing and rarely are remix albums so good that they appeal outside of the fan base of people who are extremely passionate about the album that is being remixed aka people like me but for a remix album Dras Club is pretty consistent I don't know how most of the people on this album ended up kind of cooking with the same ingredients I guess but a majority of the tracks on this album to me kind of ended up being very deep and micro house esque tunes with very constant rhythms that subtly subtly shift and progress over periods of six seven eight or even nine minutes some tracks are so faint with their changes and their sounds they almost border on being ambient not to say there is a variety on here those Shabazz Palaces definitely comes in and does its thing as well as Yaka Tama I which I will kinda talk about a little bit later I feel like I ended up disappointed with a good chunk of these tracks individually especially given who was remix in the song my life for what I thought code 9 would definitely put something together that was more akin to his dubstep roots it wasn't a bad remix I just thought maybe he played things a little too straight and I thought Hudson Mohawke would put together a serious banger on this album but he just whipped up a version of rolls Basie that sounds pretty much like the original but less is going on less original but less and I guess my even bigger disappointments with this thing are the moments where the tracks don't even resemble the originals in any way shape or form really to the point where I wonder what the remix and and the original really have to do with one another other than the fact that they're on this every artist on this thing is going to have a different remix in process and different thoughts I understand that but this album did get me thinking what makes for good remix and for me personally of course it has to feel different than the original noticeably different but also the point of reference the original needs to be so clear and obvious in a way that you end up seeing the original the remix material in a different light from a different perspective and that's where I kind of feel like the silent servant remix them and the cluster remix fall a little short because even though I'm sure it's somewhere there either influencing the keyboards being played or being sampled that point of reference that sonic point of reference isn't really there the track dominican fate has these lightly played keyboards placed on top of these quirky quirky beats there's not really a blatant sample on this track or anything like that it seems as if the keyboards and the drum machine which are pretty much the track itself were all original but still not really seeing that point of reference ultimately the song to me kind of sounds like a collaboration between OneNote Rick's point never and beach houses drum machine but I also feel like the my machines and an ice cream remixes would feel pretty far away from the originals too if it weren't for the fact that the vocals from the original songs are so obviously sampled and executed I will give it to Gang Gang dance and Brian Brian Brian I guess I was just kind of underwhelmed by a lot of these tracks the Shabazz Palaces remix I'm not as in love with now as I am when I first heard it the beat is very spacious as it would be on Shabazz Palaces last album black up palace ear Lazaro's vocals are doubled up soaked and reverb very bouncy trippy kind of psychedelic but the lyrics aren't that mind-bending or clever to me not as much as they have been with Shabazz Palaces tracks in the past you know it's not all complaints with this album though I did think the first several tracks were pretty solid the wallstreet remix has a really great groove and some swelling strings on the refrain that really make the track feel refined and the field remix on here sweetie and shag is great he totally brought that looping state of mind sort of execution making all of these cycling sections of sound feels so hypnotic and I thought the track future it was great too with this nice constant hip-hop beat backing up the chords of the song kind of playing in the foreground the thing is I did not think this remix album was terrible I liked most of the tracks but was really really only in love with a couple the biggest problem is that this remix album brings a completely different energy than gloss drop this album does not feel high-energy it does not feel fun it does not feel playful it does not really feel all that engaging in some points it does not feel high octave it doesn't feel like the entire world is is on fire and in M&M candy shell in contrast dross cloth is is just much more chill repetitive kind of relaxed with these very heady electronica tunes that may or may not even sound like the tracks that they are supposed to be remixed in or if you're a huge fan of some of the remixers on this thing kind of feeling a strong 5-2 ally six on this to be completely honest I mean yeah I thought it was thought it was likable to me but you know really mostly as a fan but what do you guys think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantino dross Club forever

you know there's some people are actually in comas and their faces really get frozen like that really come on man hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review Death Grips the Money Store Death Grips is a Sacramento based experimental hip hop trio featuring MC ride on vocals and Zack Hill and flatlander kind of handling the production behind things and the mixtape they put out last year ex-military ended up being my second favorite album of the year when it came time to do lists and the reason this landed is as second in my favorite albums of the years because it's such a forward-thinking hip hop album I'm not trying to say that it was really socially conscious or it's trying to save hip hop if Death Grips and ex-military were trying to save hip hop they were definitely going about it in a really weird way because that album to me just takes all of hip-hop's worst stereotypes and turns them up to a deafening val/val Vallon volume everything becomes extreme from the over modulation of really heavy bass and the beats to the overuse of violence and aggression in the lyrics and the vocal delivery with MC r I just really reaching levels of serial killers psycho insanity I would say Death Grips definitely takes influence from bomb-squad style production that was put together for some of Public Enemies best releases and songs as well as the really testosterone soaked third aggression that was on wu-tang's first album 36 chambers but Death Grips has taken these things so far that what they're making is no longer hip-hop but but hip-hop blended with elements of noise and industrial music in jittery electronica yeah the money store definitely has roots in traditional hip-hop but it is not an album for hip-hop traditionalists the beats for one are so freakin noisy sharing a lot of characteristics with the solo albums that that Zach Hill has been releasing over the years since since hella has kind of cooled down and the vocals the lyrics just gets swallowed and all of this chaos created by the instrumentals and the the screaming vocal delivery of MC ride just distorts the lyrics even further if you do concentrate really hard the lyrics on this thing are slightly readable you do kind of get a grasp as to maybe what sort of being said but Death Grips is fully conscious of this and how important lyrics and stories are in hip-hop which i think is is part of why the trio continues to post its lyrics in full with every single new song that they release and their lyrics worth reading into because they add a whole different different dynamic to the aggression that Death Grips presents the aggression and the violence that's that's glorified in a lot of hip-hop music especially in the mainstream with this album is just brought to such a high it becomes a grim reality not something to admire not something to like in his lyrics MC ride kind of paints himself as this character who is very violent paranoid intoxicated nearly all the time and living in extremely low life lifestyle kind of like the cover of this album it's something that feels like it's coming straight out of a really gritty graphic novel I can see all of MC rides exploits on this LP in the lyrics being depicted and really stark black-and-white images depicting bodies and bullets and blades and blood spray it's the kind of stuff that to me people would usually label horrorcore but because of how extreme Death Grips is sonically and in vocally they totally sidestep that label because now this album has kind of set the bar a little bit higher anybody walking down that road might as well be making Halloween music MC rides lyrics do kind of function beyond just gore though like on the song get got where he's kind of imagining police going after him that aren't really there and on the track I've seen footage he raps about the police brutality and violence that you see and that kind of fuels that that paranoia the track Lost Boys sort of seems to be this really dark tribute to anybody who's lost themselves in a gutter esque lifestyle Browne baggers thieves drug dealers highlighting with the hook just how far people can fall on the track hacker the lyrics are so out there and disconnected simultaneously name-dropping WikiLeaks Tesla and Lady gaga in a way that that kind of feels really glitchy and disorienting which the the song title kind of asserts and the track system blower kind of seems to be a bit of a double entendre obviously a car system comes to mind and that is referenced in the lyrics but with how violent MC ride gets with his words on a lot of verses in this track to me it kind of feels like he's also pointing his anger at the construct of systems possibly those tracks are great those tracks are fine but most of this album is loaded with violent violent make sure a parent is around kind of content blood-curdling images of cinder blocks being tied to feed and being tortured and blades again scars bubonic plague fire war bare-knuckle brawl z-- with people who are in punk wait sitting all the way through this album can be a lot like a Clockwork Orange and you're kind of tied to your chair and your islands er peel back and your being exposed all this horrifying soul rotting imagery sometimes the lyrics can be really over-the-top like on the track bitch please where the hook goes like bitch please you must be smoked Wow but that's kind of part of this really trashy unapologetic character that the MC ride depicts he's supposed to be an unlikable bastard I can't help but compare the character on this album to like walk a flock of flame except actually scary and aggressive and dangerous not this slick money-making gangsta image of aggression but no matter how gory the lyrics get MC ride is a character he is also a narrator he can't be him if you know what I'm saying be because I don't know of many drug-addicted cold-blooded killer Street dwellers who would use the words basilisk or lycanthropy in their rap verses the last thing I want to say about the lyrics though is that Death Grips just knows how to write a hell of a I got got got got oh it's such a long way down double-double every track on here is amazingly catchy which is a feat considering how ugly and harsh and unbinding this album is if you can withstand the force a lot of these tracks are gonna stick with you it's kind of like wanting to join a gang and then of course upon entry you get hazed and beaten up and abused but once you kind of make it through that initial rough spot you're in the gang and everything's cool on some tracks here MC rides verses and flow get really fast like a song get get get get God or double helix he makes used to be more kind of normal or quiet registers and his voice too and rapping on those songs which really gives this album a lot more variety in comparison with ex-military of course the lyrics no matter what register they're delivered that would not mean much if not for Death Grips production and I would say if there's one thing on this album that is done to perfection it is to stick with Death Grips usual style without bringing me into any major bouts of deja vu in relation to ex-military or the EP that came out before get down was the first single to come out from this LP and Death Grips I think really wanted to say hey we were gonna do something different this time around here is our quietest song yet there are these swirling synthesizers that kind of bleed into one another because of how grainy and lo-fi that sound quality is the vocals feel just claustrophobic ly close to the microphone they're these kind of twittering hi-hat drums in between some of the verses some very robotic lead vocal skips I love it the song fever by contrast the song right after is just pure hell the track is like listening to an alarm go off in the middle of a an underground government-funded lab where a genetically-engineered mutinous just broke out and is on the loose Zak Hills drums sound really ragged and his bass drum patterns on the psalm are insane tons of precision and the hook on this thing when the synthesizers come in it just sounds so slick just so freakin memorable the track Lost Boys takes a much different approach from the previous two tracks and is really airy and Atmospheric emcee rides vocals are just wrapped up in the atmosphere it sounds like he's rapping from the bottom of a low life well or all the terrible people he's rapping about live the beat is so austere on this track it skips quite literally like a broken record and is really hypnotic because of it the track right after blackjack is really mesmerizing too and the vocals have these kind of poltergeist s vocal sound reversals playing behind the rap verses that gives this song a really surreal quality and with this fence and the size are pulsating in the background with with some dissonant sentence as well it just feels like something out of a an 80s beast slasher movie Death Grips works on kind of topping it's dark and heavy tracks from ex-military like tachyon with songs on here such as system blower and the cage and Death Grips delivers some serious left hooks on this album too really surprisingly just when I thought I had their style pinned down song kind of example case in point I've seen footage which is this track that I feel like kind of was made just to tease the naysayers saying the Death Grips is not hip-hop because the song while staying completely Death Grips in just being abrasive being hip-hop being just so in-your-face the way the drumbeat works the distorted riff as well as emcee rides flow all call out to Golden Age hip-hop artists like Run DMC salt and pepper tone low and the track hacker as this beat that's kind of like this very danceable 80s style electro funk with MC ride I I would say kind of rapping but it sort of feels like spoken word too because he's really screaming just a lot of disjointed phrases and more than anything more than hip hop the track reminds me of like LCD soundsystem when James Murphy would set up a track with a really strong groove and then just go off on all these really insane ramblings but you know Death Grips has already wrapped over a link raised sample on ex-military so at this point really anything goes the track bitch please feels really kind of schizophrenic one moment you're hearing this rising fat synthesizer the next moment MC Wright is rapping in a Jamaican accent every few bars kind of presents a completely different sound it is just a blender of different ideas the track fucked that by far has the oddest groove onthis and thing right up there with Lost Boys man every track here musically just has its own personality just its own set of distinct characteristics there's just so much detail in these instrumentals I think that that gets so minut it would take hours to explain exactly what's happening with every single track but despite all this detailed Death Grips music does not really sound all that studied or wholly tiny or anything like that it's very fun music it's very straightforward noisy catchy overwhelming blood pumping music it is really visceral it is really in your face but once you kind of get a grip of what's going on and you adjust to the intensity it's easier to step back and see that the album required more of this than it did because not only is this LP really heavy and abrasive but it's also thought-provoking it's extremely layered and does not give up all of its secrets in the first second or even tenth listen despite being very loud to be completely honest I listened to ex-military a lot of times but this album still managed to kind of blow my mind Death Grips material so far has been building a really interesting new sound for hip-hop I'm not saying they're changing the game or anything like that I don't think that's the intention of this album at all instead the money store looks to kind of forge something for itself this thing is sitting on a throne of its own design and nobody's watching because the picture is just too horrifying to stare at from the cover of this album to the lyrics to the vocal delivery to the production everything about this LP is just unsettling is disturbing is surreal the words twisted and unforgiving come to mind too but so does the word rewarding to put it simply this album is to me a sonic portrait of a villain villains represent evil but the thing is each decade each generation is to come up with its own brand of villainy of its own brand of evil because the evil and the villains of the previous generations are going to to the current generation feel soft feel old hat things need to be updated Death Grips the Money Store is that successfully reinvented image of the villain or just villainy in general I'm loving this record freaking love in this record freaking freaking loving this record can't really say much else about it kind of feeling a strong 9 to attend on this LP what do you guys think of it do you love it do you hate it why why do you hate it why seriously Wyatt why do you eat it and why do you love it - why do you love it let me know Anthony Fantana Death Grips [Music]

this is amazing hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review moonface heartbreaking bravery this is the third release to come out of this montreal-based yes Montreal not you're saying Canada I promise the Canadians I would get specific and if you really look at the the buzz or the lack thereof or the took took took took to talk kind of surrounding this project it's it's not really taking off that well there's kind of been an aura of of failure surrounding moonface since it came out of the gate and it's something that I think Spencer himself kind of puts onto the project just take the titling of the first EP for example the Dream Land EP marimba and and shit drums or take the titling of the debut album Oregon music not vibraphone like I'd hoped I feel like both of the two releases that moodface started out with kind of imply that yeah this is my music but it's not really the music I want to be making but that doesn't really seem to be the case with this new LP telling just from the lack of self-loathing in the song titles an album title and from the fact that Spencer is not just going solo this time around he's working with a full band actually a finished band by the name of sin I hope I'm pronouncing that correctly he a point being I think Spencer may be making music he wants to make this time around and I'll be honest I did not enjoy those two previous moon-faced releases definitely not as much as I'm enjoying this and I think even Spencer himself would not blame me for it for me being a guy that's enjoyed Spencer Krug songwriting for a handful of years now it's great to hear him in front of the full band again especially since a lot of stuff for Spencer kind of seems to be in limbo right now this project has not exactly started off very well and the two indie darling bands that brought him to where he is today are in the midst of an indefinite hiatus right now and there's really no sign of them being sunset rubdown and Wolf Parade coming back anytime soon and if you read into the very personal lyrics that Spencer has written for this album and and really just taken them for face value I'd say Spencer just went through a pretty ugly breakup which is sad but in a way I kind of feel like this is revitalized what Spencer is doing with his music because he really is one of those singer songwriters that has a very unique voice lots of character lots of a broto and his songs and his very emotional vocal delivery kind of thrives off of off of sadness and will also draw his songs out musically in really interesting ways the kind of sidestep your average verse chorus verse structure usually a Spencer Curt track requires a few extra lessons to really get into the meat of it and I guess on some level understand it but he's still not beyond writing a track that kind of hooks me up first listen a track that comes to mind is the song paper lease which was on that Swan Lake album enemy mine and appeared on that last sunset rubbed down LP - and now as far as the sound goes on this thing it does not at first on the surface appear to be all that much different than your average album that that Spencer is involved with Spencer's voice sounds just as emotional as ever sort of bordering on being kind of over the top there's just a perfect splash of reverb on there there's lots of Airy synthesizers shimmering and guitars drums that have quite a bit of ambience on them not a lot of punch more atmosphere and Sanai from what I understand is is more of an mental group with huge influences coming from the world of krautrock and that does show up on a few tracks here tracks like teary eyes and bloody lips and shitty city both have very driving rhythms strong synthesizers very electronic textures to the effects surrounding those songs but most of what's on this LP kind of feels like the band conforming to Spencer's songwriting which cukoo cukoo could be a good thing for the fans I guess if there is a notable change because of the subject matter of this album the drama seems to be turned up a little bit more than usual in a good way it's like Spencer really wanted the emotions on this album to feel really grandiose with these great large movements and and fireworks style explosions of sound like the opener which is also the title track it starts off with these sparse piano chords very repetitive floor tom drum beat some bouncy reverb but it eventually just blows up into these glistening keyboards and of course Spencer's singing throughout the track and his lyrics are a focal point as usual he's kind of telling the story of how to me from from what I interpret he is not the bloodthirsty carnivore that his partner needs him to be in order to stay interested and over the hook Spencer starts talking about the kill the the prey if you will and it turns out that this person who is with romantically is in fact the kill kind of unsettling the second track goes for something really grand to the these piano chords there's just something so perfectly theatrical about those chords and they just it kind of reminded me of a wedding or something but then a fire breaks out and everybody needs to rush out all at once which is a terrible horrifying thought but that's kind of the juxtaposition that you're getting with with a lot of tracks on this album you have this element of love this element of prettiness of beauty but then comes the hatred and the loathing and the the very dark feelings that are pulled into place by a breakup after this track though my love for this album starts to kind of wane the very Crowley elements that seneye brings to the table kind of comes into play on the next track Shady City and I guess I wasn't that big krautrock elements that sentai brings to the table were the only real points of difference plus the selfie doesn't really bring a lot of the very out-there lyricism that I usually expect from Spencer however a lot of songs on here do bring a really clear and impersonal story so clear and personal that that I felt as if I was kind of bearing the burden with Spencer's I listened to at least some of hi hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and doing right now a question comment thing today my question is do we respect the past do you and I us music community as a whole respect the past and I mean the music of the past and I don't mean do we enjoy the past I don't mean do we like the past that's different I mean do we RESP ECT the past enough to honor it and not exploit it most importantly do we respect the past enough to not turn it into a spectacle to me the answer has always been no but I kind of had confirmation of that this past weekend when I saw a hologram image of Tupac Shakur performing on stage at Coachella and he was doing everything he was grabbing his chain he was rapping he was posing he was saying what's up Coachella performing with Snoop Dogg and apparently this performance this concept has been in the works for several months and there are now talks of possibly taking the Tupac hologram on tour either with dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg or with some more current rappers for kind of a wider tour but I have to wonder is this the way we should treat the memory of one of the most important figures in hip-hop music I guess philosophically you could say that this is really not such a big deal a hologram is just a representation of something and part of the reason this instance is such a big deal is because it's the first time it's being executed in this way on such a grand scale and when you boil it down I guess making a hologram of Tupac is in a lot of ways the same as releasing a posthumous album by Tupac or releasing some video footage or releasing a movie used to be in or something nobody had access to before or to take it further what about Kurt Cobain baby beans Diaries that have been printed and reprinted over the years I guess it's not the worst thing in the world I'm sure somewhere there is some sort of veiled intention to pay tribute to Tupac and his music of course this intention is veiled by money don't we already have tons of ways of tributing artists already through music and movies and art I'm open to new in different ways but isn't this whole hologram thing a little corny I mean watching this Tupac hologram dance on stage was a lot like watching the Fab Four dance together and play their instruments in that Beatles rock band game isn't this hologram performance kind of like a Disney World thing a Universal Studios Orlando kind of thing of course there's always the question as to whether or not to pot would have actually wanted to be turned into a hologram and saying stuff like hey what's up Coachella and maybe a slew of other things he's never ever said in his life once they decide to program more things into the hologram once it goes on tour but nobody asks those questions when there's time to kill and we need to be entertained and there's a buck to be made you know what happens when this technology becomes more commonplace are we going to see Kurt Cobain fronting Nirvana again on tour are we going to see Biggie rapping are we going to see a Michael Jackson world tour what if this technology ever becomes so cheap that some underground artists I have kind of a personal connection with get hologram like J retard and this hologram is punching people in the face on stage who mess with him while he's performing you know I'm sure this whole hologram thing was really expensive to do but it just added up to kind of a cheap thrill it didn't really bring anything for me to the philosophy of Tupac to his body of work to his greatness and his charisma or his memory I actually think it kind of tarnishes his memory because you have a ton of people now who didn't really grow up on Tupac whose biggest impression of him now is this hologram as much as I would hate for a guy like Tupac to fall into obscurity it's an issue all artists have to deal with no matter how good the music they made was and I feel like doing stuff like this is just kind of prolonging that pain in a really ugly way the best thing you and I everyone can do for music is instead create and praise art that we think is great as great as the music that we love from the past because the things we're not going to do anything that's memorable into the future if we take every single opportunity we can to be nostalgic if we're putting all of our efforts into reliving what's already happened it's a new world out there let's act like it what do you guys think of this whole hologram thing was this a tasteful way to bring up Tupac's memory are you excited about the prospect of a Tupac hologram tour or maybe even your favorite dead artists being reanimated through Holograms was this kind of a one-time spectacle thing or do you see this being more common practice into the future let me know Anthony Fantan Oh Holograms forever

good minstrel your music has touched my soul in way no other song has strong 10 hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review Quakers Quakers these guys are a hip-hop collective they have a new album out on the legendary record label stones threats threats threats throw records and this thing is a pretty hefty project it has a roster of of epic proportions at the base of this project is three producers 727 catalyst and fuzz face aka geoff barrow of portishead and on top of that you have 30 or so mcs spitting on an assortment of 40 or so beats that these three producers have have put together and you know i'll admit completely that I was very skeptical into this project i'm usually not really that big of a fan of hip-hop albums in this format these producer curated albums that kind of cherry-pick mcs and give each of them their own separate tracks kind of throw them all onto the same album in a mixed bag I usually don't find albums of this style to be that consistent cohesive coherent or focused a lot of the time for me the mcs that get invited onto these things don't even bring their best stuff either I mean you'd think that all the MCS that came together on producer curated albums from Jake one or mad labor 9th wonder would would end in it in a pretty fiery rat battle but just didn't didn't happen not the case to me these albums aren't as impressive as they could be because the mcs that you're listening to your only really getting a small tiny sliver of their persona the rhymes and the personality that they throw out it's really surface level and that's what pretty much happens on quakers because you have so many mcs on one album and they only had this little tiny sliver of time to spit on this beat that is one to two minutes long these guys don't really have a chance to go deeper with much of anything so most of the MCS on here kind of fall backwards lazily on this wu-tang style caustic humor braggadocio a shit oh shit the vocal samples and lyrics on this album even go forward to reference wu-tang a handful of times for me it's important to get something a little deeper than that from an MC when I'm listening to him or her rap especially since there are so many people on this album that are incredibly underground people that only really have a few notable features or mixed tapes to their name if that there are some bigger names on here like Prince PO and dead prez and there are some Stones Throw Records staples to affiliates from strong arm steady ma Dee aloe blacc guilty Simpson but even if you're a huge into underground hip-hop I guarantee that a good handful of people on this album will be new to you and to kind of go over the tracks they're a bit of a combination together and function properly the album starts off with sonata wats on the song big cat and he's got this really kind of heavy forceful persona in his flow that I like a lot and matches your dishes the dark beat behind him guilty simpson comes up on the next track and while i am not really a guilty simpson fan his hefty personality over this really husky horn hit in the beat is a nice combo and the album sadly starts to go downhill for me after that John Wayne on the track smoke is decent I think he picks a really interesting flow for that track over that rhythm but the synthesizers feel a little aimless track and are kind of overpowering tone 10 comes in with this kind of messy old dirty bastard swagger on the track what you want and it's a great beat but it's just making these really terrible similes throughout the track and it kind of ruins it for me everything from there up to track 11 really hits me as being kind of forgettable until I hear Chicago MC diverse with some really nice chemistry over his instrumental but Quakers kind of puts together this issue of deja vu for me by putting out an MC with a similar flow against a similar be on the track right after my biggest disappointment is toward the middle of the LP though or I think one of the best beats is is wrecked by one of the worst verses on here I'm talking about the track dark city lights these fat pulsating synthesizers are right there on the beat I love it the drums are crispy and just relentless the whole thing kind of sounds like it was sampled from some old 80s sci-fi soundtrack but then I cringe when the first lyric comes in your boy nidhi is back like Bonjour I learned that on the streets of Perry went on tour and that's for sure but we say for sure my chica kind of curvy and her hips Kong curve it kind of makes up for it with the track raid shortly after with lyric Jones who is this great female MC I haven't heard of before she had a really powerful voice and a forceful personality and she had me going right from the first line where she was saying extra extra no time to read it all text iya she had some clever lines on there she definitely kind of broke up the monotony of the album a bit on the track chicken livers FC the truth drops this really plain kind of lazy flow I I really wondered if he was even trying and even aloe blacc shortly after sounds way more unenthusiastic than I would anticipate him being the thing is on this LP because there are so many emcees trying to hit you and run there are so many songs on here that are about nothing nothing a few tracks have very obvious themes like the song soul power which talks about soul music of the 60s and 70s and the struggle for equal rights and there are lots of really kind of cute fighting metaphors on the track chunky Balboa but a lot of tracks on here don't tell much of a story and don't really add to any overall theme of this album the production though is is great it's very mad lib influenced though it is very great Madlib influence to beat making loaded with lots of tasteful funk soul and jazz samples with the occasional break that sounds like it was lifted from a really obscure soundtrack or some record that was just found when digging deep just very deep in some crates dusty old musty crates of course I thought the instrumental side of this album was way more interesting and engaging than the MC side but even as I listened to the instrumentals I kind of sit there and wonder what the potential of them could have been if they were just more interesting lyricists on here or if maybe a handful of the lyricists were able to kind of experiment with more tracks and maybe show more sides to their persona but overall this album is not really a precision cut it's not a steadily aimed sniper rifle hitting directly in the middle of its target it's really a blindfolded shotgun blast I'm really on the fence because I do love the instrumentals but I am so not into a lot of the MCS on this thing thing thing kind of feeling a strong for to a light 5 on this I don't know how you guys feel about this thing but that's pretty much me just one man's opinion I don't know how you guys feel about this
