ah I just finished watching that speech and now I'm feeling pretty based hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review black dice mr. impossible black dice is a Brooklyn experimental music outfit this is their latest LP their early stuff was was more akin to genres such as experimental rock and noise rock but these days their music incorporates way more electronics samples guitars slathered and the strangest of effects and all these sounds come together to make some of the oddest sound scapes I've ever heard black dice definitely produces music that does not hold too many musical conventions do not go into this thing expecting clear chord progressions or a lot of harmony much less lyrics or intelligible vocals instead expect some pretty noisy guitars playing very fart around riffs and leads lots of grunts and and mouth noises and grimy sampled beats pulsating in a very mechanical way considering a lot of the guitars have a very buzzing quality to them serve like a group of flies swarming around my head but the thing is the sounds that black dice chooses though they are noisy and they are strange for the most part they're very bright and and quirky almost cartoonish and and I would dare say fun there's no feeling of difficulty or harshness or massive amounts of depth that you usually get in experimental music like this instead black dice shoots for something that's way more kind of light-hearted they feel as as weird as Captain Beefheart but as playful as Deerhoof sounds on here don't feel really densely layered or heavy they're actually pretty easy to pull apart making this album very readable for an album that's that's comprised mostly of noise or what seems like noise black dice has been playing with this style for several albums now including repo and load blown and I would say mr. Impossibles is their most accessible moment yet in this vein the music isn't really subtly layered or anything like that black dice sort of puts all of the weirdness out there to be consumed on a first impression which isn't a bad thing the issue for me with this album is how the sounds black dice chooses mesh or don't sometimes to me listening to this album can be a lot like walking into a room with a cuckoo clocks hanging all over the walls in every direction all of these clocks making very different and distinct noises but they all happen to be making them on this one timed plane it's a congruent cacophony and to me there's nothing really all that impressive or memorable with how the sounds on this album clash or work together to tell you the truth some of my least favorite parts on this LP are the spots where the sounds seem like they're intended to to sort of work together like on the eight-minute track carnitas where the synth phrases and the drumbeats though they do kind of hit in an accessible way at first they get a little boring after a while other times like I said the sounds on these tracks sort of seemed to be on the same tempo coexisting but in a very separated and disconnected way there are some spots on here where the sounds do work together in a really fun way there's all sorts of tempo and sound changes throughout the track songs like pigs and the jacker those are fun tracks that I like a lot there's a lot of color and they're not long-winded by any means black dice definitely piss all over all the rules and expectations for recorded music but they kind of go a about it in this very one-trick pony kind of way all the sounds and colors sort of hit me all at once in this in this really exciting way it's kind of a rush but as I listen to this LP more and more and more the sounds really aren't complementing one another doing anything together they were just kind of abducted and thrown into this mix and they don't know where they are or who they are or who these other sounds are all they know is they just want to be left alone this record and black dice in general have a lot of personality and there's something to be said for that there are not a lot of groups that sound like black dice so I'm kind of feeling a strong five to a light six on this record but that doesn't matter what do you happen to feel on the inside in regards to the music on this release does it grab your soul shake it and then rip it to shreds and then eat it or does it make you on a hotwire a car and crash into the nearest tree let me know Anthony Fantana black dice mr. impossible

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here internets busiest music nerd question/comment thing if you visit a lot of blogs read music magazines or read essays or books on music or visit music forums I'm sure you've run across some people saying a certain genre was dead real hip-hop is dead Punk is dead Rock is dead discos dead and maybe you yourself have advanced this idea or thought hey you know what that person that person saying that genres dead whoo I'm noticing right now he is right or she and saying something as dead is really honestly seriously no joke becoming my least favorite thing to hear when it comes to people's talking about music because I think most people say it just to be provocative or feel like they're smert kind of stir up controversy and and push the idea that that things are black and white things are either alive or they're dead and that's certainly the case with people and living things depending on how you define dead and live but genres are not people and I firmly believe that musical ideas do not die never ever never ever ever ever ever especially in this day and age and not to say things don't change they do I'm just saying that life especially in the case of art is one never-ending grayscale musical ideas do a lot of things they grow and and fade in popularity they get hijacked by other genres or or recycled some evolve and start incorporating other ideas and sometimes they they lie dormant and make a resurgence a comeback but music does not just die though sometimes it may seem that way if you look at it from a bird's eye view not really reading into the details especially if you kind always tag the death of a genre with the death of a culture disco records do not top the charts anymore but the fact that the fashion and the lingo that also surrounded that style of music have been kind of phased out too is for a lot of people further proof that the nails are in the coffin but when you look at some elements of disco key elements of disco music you got to kind of wonder did the genre ever really die you got guitars with very briskly strummed funky chords tight bass lines with loads of octaves syncopated with the drums which are usually kind of thrown out of four to the floor beat bright horn sections lead vocals that soar and are soaked in reverb all of these ideas are still in use in music today and the thing is disco didn't even invent most of them a lot of them were picked up from funk and when disco was fading away parts of it went to the more danceable acts to come out of post-punk music parts of it went on to influence new wave and a lot of pop that came out in the 80s even the lead single off of Lady Gaga's last LP had a huge disco influence on it there were some artists that kind of sat between the fall of disco and the rise of of synth pop music and they sounded like it like blondie and punk music any genre that people perceived to be dead is basically the same way but what's funny today is that we've got the Internet and it's fragmented culture a little bit people are are able to sort of indulge and whatever they please they don't need to rely on on contemporary and in popular culture to be introduced to music you've got people who say you know what screw new music I'm going to listen to nothing but but 80s pop or classical or bluegrass or Tuvan throat-singing some people take it even further and say you know what I'm going to start a Dixieland style jazz band or even a tribute band to my favorite group that broke up 30 years ago or a tribute band to my favorite group that's still active today and the thing is today nostalgic musicians are rewarded with with fans and contracts and record sales look at artists like Ariel pink or Krystal stilts or black lips or Christian mistress they're just a few but there is a really healthy world of artists out there who rely heavily on nostalgia or old world musical ideas to kind of get by just because you're not running into a certain style of music every day or as much as you used to or ever does not mean it's dead because believe me it's out there somewhere living and breathing influencing and affecting people whether it's on record or at a live show so that's it I love you I hope you have a good day you're the best always question everything [Music]

how did you do this do what this hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd time for review dr. John locked down dr. John is a singer songwriter multi-instrumentalist session musician and iconic figure in New Orleans music especially when it comes to blues funk R&B jazz and psychedelic rock there's been a lot of versatility over the 20 or so albums this guy is released over the years he's recently been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as well unfortunately his music is not really garnering the net it used to but this new help you locked down is receiving some really positive attention and for good reason it's a solid album which we will get into later but but part of the reason I think this LP is catching some momentum momentum is because it's a little change in direction thanks to working with Dan Auerbach of the Black Keys who produced this LP and what Dan is doing for John on this LP reminds me a lot of what Rick Rubin was doing for Johnny Cash on his final albums Rick revitalized Johnny's sound not by going for something that was that was really clean and sleek slick and modern instead shooting for something that's that's much more earthy gritty the instrumentation on those final cash records just sounded so aged and weathered and Dan is basically doing the same thing I don't think the good doctor could have gotten a better production endorsement from a modern artist not only do I think Black Keys fans can very easily slide into enjoying this LP but the production Dan brings to the table just like an usual Black Keys fashion references the past which I think old-school dr. John fans will but it's got a really modern punch to it the opener the title track to this album starts with these birds squawking it's like I'm in a bird sanctuary this drum roll comes in building things up against these kind of tribal chants and then this clunky New Orleans style funk groove comes in that not only references old school dr. John but are just like the meters and Lee Dorsey - and over this funk groove to kind of back up the hook that's really metallic vibraphone and these backup vocals and and horns come in kind of giving the track a slightly lounge jazz feel I really love the sounds the extra sounds that come together on this track but the foundational stuff the guitars the drums the vocals they sound great - the drums had to have a kind of I guess ratty quality to them I want to see but not ratty in a bad way they don't sound like they're miked very close so you're catching a lot of kit annoys a lot of room noise but the drums still have a lot of crispness to them and the guitars which of course are played by Dan Auerbach have that trademark black keys tone to them the upright bass thuds away basically the instrumentation to me sounds like a beat-up old pickup truck it's souped up the engine growls the wheel wells are all rusted there's bugs caught in the grille the windshield is cracked but you know runs good and as far as the vocals go I know this gets set about a lot of aging the singers but I'm not biessing here I do think dr. John's voice has gotten more interesting with old age it is so raspy rasp rasp rasp his voice has always kind of had a raspy quality to it but now it's just more than ever and it's adding a lot of character in a very Tom Waits kind of way and dr. John still manages to carry a tune be very emotive in these songs and thanks to the lyrics on this P he's sounding kind of fed up with the world at large too there are all sorts of words on on this album referencing the present being an ice age Liars going to hell people doing drugs and losing their jobs revolution is the final solution it's a bit of a wake-up call because if you were to see the world from dr. John's viewpoint it would probably look like it's crumbling fast vocally the only spots I'm not really in love with on this album are the moments where dr. John's vocal melodies may be getting a little repetitive on the verse or the verses where he's not really so much singing as he is doing a bit of a spoken word thing I'm talking tracks like Ice Age big shot you lie but the production the songwriting and the instrumentation whether it be similarly sultry horns or a bright old-school organ oh that saves these songs from being bad for sure I understand these moments just aren't as captivating to me I guess because this album is solid enough to the point where you could just ride through the lows and it's not really a big deal because the highs are so high there is a good amount of variety on here - I like the brisk speedy tempo on the track getaway which is which isn't 3/4 and has a fantastic guitar solo from Dan on the end of it I love the slow brooding funk of kingdom of isness the balladry that's happening on my children my angels where the lyrics tried to be a bit of advice to the youth the next generation the track a leg wah really pulls up the New Orleans funk roots of this album like no other track does lots of sharp guitar leads very heavy very chunky drums and the clothes are on here God sure go takes a bit of a religious and a gospel angle to this album finishing things off on a kind of positive note overall it's a very good album it's it's not exactly new ground or mind-blowing for dr. John but it does sound great to hear and kind of revitalized restored in a really tasteful way so definitely check this thing out it's the kind of stuff that that swamps and and hard liquor and dusty old bars and and the sweat beating off the head of a lone saxophone player at some smoky nightclub where the maximum capacity is 50 people is made of definitely feeling a strong 7 on this thing what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana dr. John forever

finally got my carrot back Garrett hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review kindness world you need a change of mind kindness is the musical project of singer-songwriter multi-instrumentalist producer Adam Bainbridge he hails from England and this album has actually been co-produced with philippe zadar who has also been behind the scenes with other indie pop favorites from cut copy and phoenix and there's no reason right now not to believe that kindness could not sort of get that same sort of stature this project has had some attention on it ever since it released a debut single in 2009 a cover of the song swingin party by the replacements now if you put this record on you're going to run into a hodgepodge of sounds from the 70s and the 80s that we used to make fun of in the 90s and 2000s or or the aughts but now it's a new decade we're past 2010 we're getting deeper into 2012 and the resurgence of genres like new wave and disco sent pop funk and R&B are far under way so far under way I would say kindness is actually kind of late to the party because this album is coming after after chillwave one of the largest collective embraces of of retro recycling in a long time as well as artists embracing that disco and and danceable post-punk ideal like hercules and love affair or LCD soundsystem and the latest LPS from Toro y Moi and ariel pink have repurposed old-school grooves for some pretty eccentric pop songwriting now admittedly I was getting a bit tired of all this recycling but I think kindness is the new face that this party needs to to kind of keep things going there are tracks on here that have really brisk disco drum beats and bass lines inspired by artists like Sugar Hill Gang and there are other moments that feel like that ladies take on contemporary R&B from artists like Prince or Janet Jackson plus the songwriting in the vocal delivery on this thing can have a very sort of naive and vulnerable quality to them and for me there's no reason to believe that Bainbridge isn't conscious of the corniness he's dealing in which is why I think he put so much effort into trying to make some of these tracks some of them sound sort of unconventional progressive really working with with some linear song structures the opener on this thing morphs almost psychedelically for six minutes from one idea to the next and I see synths cape with a with a drum machine be at the intro with some pretty fiery guitar solos over it to a really beautiful horn interlude with piano there are some lyrical breaks in the middle of that saying let the music become a part of you or when we dance we're all the same and Bainbridge's sort of deadpan vocal delivery makes the the tune feel a little bit cultish I am a little on the fence with his vocal delivery there are moments on here like the opener where it feels a little flat just doesn't really have a strong personality strong anything really but then there are spots on here like that replacements cover right after the opener where it comes off heavenly sweet and then on the second cover song on this LP you take on Anita dobson's lost pop gem anyone can fall and love the vocals also feel kind of off they feel a little bit lazy and in this instance it's almost kind of a good thing because like in the way anyone can fall in love the vocal sort of give this impression that anyone can really sing this song plus the song is just wrapped in these and these really beautifully arranged flourishes of horns and and since sort of adding these nice subtle little harmonies against the chords as the song progresses the next two tracks on here boggle my mind a bit though the track G up is is definitely the most uneventful track on the album some smooth ambient synthesizer chords matched up with some very slowly played funk guitar chords and it's an okay track I wish a little bit more happened but right after that song is the most eventful song on the album G up really fast really upbeat lots of guitar leads strong funky disco bass line a really upbeat drum beat but then the track sort of fades out abruptly just before two minutes just as things are getting kind of heated thankfully it's not too long until I get to my favorite track on here that's all right the song opens up with this beautiful gorgeous awe inspiring horn and synth combo the synthesizer sounds so slick and rich and the saxophone just has the perfect amount of splash on it to just make it bounce and then when the beat hits and the synthesizer comes in that squealing synthesizer it's just magic it's intense it's heavy it's epic there's this vocal sample this guy kind of comes in the Buddhist bird strong composition hard groove fat husky synthetically manipulated baseline it just sounds so large and in charge I'd love to hear more of that from kindness in the future taking this very kind of simple meat and potatoes genres or really building them up into this epic ambitious thing kindness plays this style off really well even if he is at times kind of going through the motions following the blueprint like on tracks such as cyan or even the last song on here he still manages present something that's really enjoyable tight grooves catchy hooks it's kind of a mixed bag of style and quality still I'm kind of feeling a decent too strong 7 on this thing if you have heard this album what do you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I be reviewing in my next video what do you think hmm kindness world you need a change of mind

oh boy hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and time for a review willis earl beal acousmatic sorcery this is Willis Earl Beals kind of official label released debut album he's a Chicago singer-songwriter who's been self recording for for quite a while and just not first listen Beals musical foundation has a lot of characteristics that reminds me of artists that I already love and respect sometimes his tracks have kind of a Tom Waits characteristic really kind of clunky noisy percussion match with some really kind of bold intense and growly vocals and sometimes he has this Captain Beefheart characteristic about him where he'll be sort of doing some really abstract out there spoken word over some pretty noisy instrumentals other times he has a bit of a Daniel Johnston angle to his songs with a very DIY lo-fi self recorded aesthetic on to tape so there's that kind of warble e sound with the instruments and occasionally his tracks do kind of shoot for something that is a bit confessional like embarrassingly confessional and personal some of his tracks pull influences from blues music and gospel music whether it's from lyrical ideas or chord progressions all of these various influences really got me psyched for this LP plus there is some nice background kind of fueling the attention that he is getting sort of like Daniel Johnston or Wesley Willis or are Stevie Moore he sort of seems to be very hands on when it comes to promoting his work and creating artwork for his music as well and this really kind of hands-on and grassroots approach that he's been taking with with putting his music out there has made him a bit of a folk hero I guess but as I actually listened to acoustic sorcery I just did not find a lot I enjoyed and sadly I thought a lot of the songs on here didn't really feature lyrics I found interesting I thought a lot of the structures of these songs and the melodies got kind of monotonous I didn't think the instrumentation was was that great a lot of the time and I didn't think these songs were worth at tuneful the instrumental foundation of this LP is guitar vocals and a little bit of found percussion and all of that instrumentation is recorded onto a tape recorder so you do kind of get that tape sound and to me it sounds like then it's taken off of the tape and assembled or looped pretty quickly on a computer on a lot of these tracks the guitar or whatever is being played doesn't really sound like it's it's being performed it's just kind of cycling in a really uninteresting way underneath the vocals which I would be okay with if I didn't think the vocals were so kind of hit or miss for example the track take me away to me is actually a highlight on here it's a really riveting track with the vocal delivery Beale brings on that one it's really loud over modulated kind of rough around the edges and a Howlin wolf kind of way and I really like Beals over-the-top delivery on the song masquerade which is actually a bonus track for this LP where he's talking about going to this masquerade party and just how animated he is on that track just makes it killer makes it entertaining but most of the tracks on here like cosmic queries or evenings kiss the drama feels kind of forced the sadness feels kind of forced and these tracks kind of expose this album's biggest issue for me and that is Beale does not come off as being that great of a storyteller some tracks on here down a road that is Biel throwing out a bunch of abstract imagery that doesn't really connect in a very obvious way but I'm sure it does for him personally but the images aren't really all that out there not to the point where it would be thrilling to listen to them and they don't come off as that as that vivid either partially because of what he's saying but partially because there's no real mm behind his singing and then there are songs on here kind of like monotony where the lyrics are very personal very honest very focused on beels feelings but they're really not that revealing when somebody wants to write a song about their feelings you assume that they're just gonna kind of lay it out there on the table they are going to expose some kind of deep dark underbelly you're gonna get some kind of pure raw potent dose of this person's real feelings because a they have to bottle these feelings up during the day because nobody wants to hear about them or B they have to bottle these feelings up during the day because it would be embarrassing to share them and not to say that Beals feelings aren't legitimate on the track monotony where he kind of talks about being generally bored and not really all that sad not really all that happy kind of blase I'm sure he actually feels that way but the thing is the feelings he talks about on this album are kind of ordinary so it doesn't make them all that exciting to listen to there are some spots on here where I think Beale does come through is being really entertaining like on ghost robot or swing on low where the percussion is is really kind of loud and quirky and just over modulated and noisy and his vocals are kind of doing a spoken-word thing with some lyrics that are very fun very playful exposing the side of him that just does not take itself that seriously but those are pretty much the only spots on here that I liked for the most part I feel like this album just dragged it is just so dry it does not bring a lot of song it does not bring a lot of lyrics or personality because the influence is is so obvious I feel like I have to go back to a guy like Daniel Johnston and just point out that that the songs that that he put together especially the stories especially the lyrics in his tracks we're so dark we're just so depressing they were so clever and witty and not that I wish depression on on anybody or the kind of of mental problems that Daniel has fought with over the years I don't but this is the kind of out of box thinking that makes songwriting entertaining for listeners I just don't feel like a Cousteau Matic sorcery has it that's all so I'm kind of feeling a strong three to a light four on this thing what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next Willa sorrow Beale

I'm getting my ear I'm gonna go and get it jack I just said that next time you see me I'm gonna be a real-life jab hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review chromatics kill for love chromatics is a project that's released a handful of albums since its formation in 2001 but kind of hit it big last year with an appearance on that drive soundtrack that people are really making a lot of noise about now this is the first LP to be released since that really nice soundtrack appearance and it is a 90-minute and can can dream bedroom pop opus which admittedly is kind of what got me interested in checking this group out in the first place group I never heard of before puts together this 90-minute pop album they sound like they're pretty ambitious on paper but the issue for me is that to me this album shares so many of the negative characteristics the negative stereotypes that are usually associated with with self recorded music stuff like plain melodies sounds that are by no means vibrant or resonant or even really all that pretty all the sounds kind of melt together into this stew of pastel color blandness and the performances on on this LP are kind of weak to almost feel really effortless I guess the vocals are not that interesting they're not that engaging they do not have that much personality they don't have that much pitch or range either or passion they just kind of flatly deliver the lyrics one track after another and the guitar the synthesizers the drum programming there was nothing about them on us on this album in the whole 90 minutes that it's panned that really struck me as being spectacular I would actually even say the way a lot of the instruments are played on this LP it's pretty a stick some of the guitar leads just kind of slip in and out of tempo and not even really in in an interesting or an exciting way it's not like they're slipping in and out of tempo because things are going so fast things are getting so high and heavy it's just really kind of an obvious mistake that that shouldn't be there sometimes the synths suffer from the same problem and a couple of spots on this album feature auto album was just so aimless it actually kind of reminded me of the way auto tune was used on that flava flav single I'll never let you go this album does not have a lot I'm interested in but I would not strings and sampling and tape delay effects different kinds of guitars a theremin too but too many songs on here just sound way too similar for comfort for me like tracks 3 & 4 on here pretty much have the same exact drumbeat but played at different speeds and like I said none of the melodies on this thing or all that developed they feel a bit thrown together they feel a little off-the-cuff and as a result the melodies are definitely not helping and separating these songs I like what the project is shooting for on this thing you've got some program beats you have these guitars with the tone that reminds me of like power corruption and lies err a new order or maybe even like Joy Division something like that you've got some smooth grooves you've got vocals kind of slathered in reverb a dreamy aesthetic but just because this music is dreamy and ethereal I don't think that gives it a go to be kind of forgettable or kind of lacking in personality all these issues come up for me right from the start on the opening track to this thing which is actually a cover of Neil Young's into the black and never really heard a cover suck the passion out of an original so quickly the vocals are performed as if it's it's a chore the piano and the guitar strumming there's nothing really dramatic or emotional about them and it's such an emotional song there were a few surprises for me on this LP that I liked there were some very interesting ambience in interludes toward the middle synth Odysseys almost and the final track on here 14 minute track had some nice progression some nice changes a lot of the instruments in this laundry list show up on that track there is still that issue with me not really loving the the sounds on this album and actually thought the song lady was was pretty good too I still isn't into the vocals but the groove on that track was so smooth and and kind of dark really made me think of what would be a depressing disco song overall again with this LP it was just so plainly performed it was difficult for me to really get into it as I've already said I was originally interested in this thing because of the length thought that would bring some ambition to the table but the energy that went into making this much material did not really go into making the sounds high-quality making the vocals engaging making the melodies unique I wouldn't go as far as to say there's a lot of filler on this album I do sense that there is some nice progression that there is a nice arc to these 90 minutes that have been laid onto the cell P it just ended up feeling so lacking for me kind of feeling a strong four to a light five on this wasn't just was not feeling it but what do you guys think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantan oh oh chromatics forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd doing a little list right now as many of you know the 21st of this month April is Record Store Day a day when music nerds gather together to celebrate music in its physical form the CD the cassette the vinyl the dat tape all that good stuff and we also celebrate record stores being really neat places to buy music and hang out and unusual Record Store Day tradition a bunch of cool limited-run releases are going to be available for that day and there's a lot there's a lot of them there's actually a huge list of these releases linked in the description box of this video and I've picked 10 10 releases from this giant list that I particularly am looking forward to and maybe hope to procure number one Afrika Bambaataa an mc5 on one single 7-inch record a reissue of the song kick out the jams ya afrika bambaataa covered that song way back in the day the covers little horrendous but it's pretty fantastic and it's being paired with it on 17 inch the next release that I'm looking forward to is actually number four in the battles dross glop 12-inch vinyl remix series and the reason i'm looking forward to number four is because like a complete nerd I've been buying all the vinyl up until this point there's going to be a reissue of ten inches in a box set of the classic dub reggae release lee scratch perry 'he's Blackboard Jungle dub look out for that one there's also going to be a 10 inch of gorillas do you thing st. how could you think of sleeping at a time like this we can't even afford to live here because you don't have a job you already pawn my words hi everyone Anthony Phan tanto here it's busy it's music nerd and it's time for a review bad bad not good very hold on your partner you're you just started the review and you're you're already saying it's big just give it a chance bad bad not good BB ng - these guys are a young trio of jazz musicians from Canada this is their second full-length album and they really are coming into this genre with an attitude and their own way of doing things they just put out there this this rejection of the old-school Jazz ethos which a lot of people take issue with because there are a lot of sacred cows and jazz that you're not supposed to stomp all over in a way I think it's kind of a good thing because constantly praising the same forefather artists over and over again and also not allowing any new ideas to seep in the intent may be preservation but the result is always decay I wouldn't say bad bad not good as a complete rejection of the old way of doing things though between the instrumentation that these guys make use of piano bass drums there's actually some some guest saxophone playing on here the improvisation and interplay on a lot of these tracks and the fact that these guys reinterpret pre-existing material I would say the Jazz foundation is pretty firm underneath these guys it's just that these guys for the most part when they do cover a song it's a hip-hop song it's B music or an instrumental it's electronic music so while the execution is ultimately jazz the source material is is what ends up making bad bad not good feel new and current and different the band's last full-length album which I reviewed gave a positive review - did reinterpretations of everything from an Oz instrumental to Gangstar they even covered some some Zelda songs from ocarina of time and the forecast this time around is much different on the last LP original material was was pretty scan but in contrast this album a quarter of it is original material there's some odd future covers on here of course it opens up with Earl and then goes later into a medley that has been kind of kicking around and the bad bad not good Canon for a while this mix of title of the creators bastard and Gucci means lemonade toward the end of this LP they cover Kanye's flashing lights they even do a couple genes blade covers on this thing as well as a My Bloody Valentine covered and the whole album the song recipe is is different the mixture is different and the presentation of these songs is different this time around - these guys have upped the production quality a lot to me the pianos feel much more resonant much heavier bigger the drums just come through much clearer they don't always have that same boom-bap texture on them a lot more sonic variety on the drums throughout this LP the bass sounds nice and warm the electric bass there's a lot more upright bass on this thing - and the saxophone that appears on a couple tracks on here sounds great as well there's even a pretty distorted guitar on that My Bloody Valentine cover toward the end and there's just a variety of different keyboard sounds on this thing as well from the grande large acoustic piano that's on Ron decay or limit for your love the fat distorted heavy scents on Earl and sometimes there are these very smooth icy synthesizers that appear on a few tracks here and of course that really sharp sharp electric piano sound that was on the band's last album it sounds even sharper now like marbles hitting glass and like I said I feel like there's more interplay on this LP - Alex for example is improving on his drums a lot more on this LP throwing little changes into his rhythms not just playing it straight and when these guys jam they are jamming a lot harder on this thing on the last album some of the solos though I did like the album I felt like they could have gone harder they could have just dug into the song more I imagine a song is kind of being like a room and when you're playing are really passionate fiery solo you're just turning the furniture over and like throwing stuff out the windows this time around bad bad not good really destroys some of the rooms that they're fooling around in like on that drum solo at the end of Earl the bass solo on limit to your love the sax solo on UWM and the keyboard solos on that flashing lights cover are so simultaneously soloing and embellishing on the chords and the odd future Gucci Mane medley on this thing which these guys have been playing for a while has developed into a whole new animal really emphasizing the contrast between the bastard section of the song and the lemonade section of the song making the bastard part really slow dark heavy dramatic and then when the Gucci Mane spot hits they just blast into it Oh shoo it was bad bad not good is just tighter than ever and I did not think they would reach this level of intensity in their playing so quickly because they're really tearing into some of these tracks and making them their own these guys throw in a reworked version of the song rotten decay which was a single that they dropped earlier this year an original song and I'm loving this reworked version I feel like it has been incubated a bit and it's developed a little bit more the track is still lumbering and heavy but the playing is more precise and what the band is trying to do I feel like comes through a lot stronger with how they're slowing down the tempo speeding it up so it feels more fluid as the tempos moving the drums the bass and the piano feel much more together so the tension the track was supposed to bring originally it's just so much stronger the song limit love which is originally a Feist song but then became a James Blake cover is covered on here but they're kind of covering the James Blake version with these really heavy piano keys and then the Tom's on the drums are kind of used to imitate the wubble and the bass on the lead melody on this thing sounds great the sixth track on here Chester kind of feels like bad bad not good imitating a future garage tune with the with the chords and the keys and the way the drum beat is performed it kind of falls into a hip-hop groove later with just bass solos galore and it's really got a nice funky and smooth vibe to it that I love the next track UWM is definitely my favorite original on this entire thing the electric piano chords on here are so dreary and the drum beat has a nice boom-bap texture to it with this tambourine mix it with a snare that's a really nice touch I love the way the groove changes suddenly too and you got these ascending descending piano chords that the player again it just builds a lot of tension in the track in Leyland widdy's saxophone on the song when the tractor sort of smoothes out falls into a more chill groove is killer is playing is really smoky really sultry sexy and flashing lights is definitely my favorite cover on this entire thing bad bad not good gives the song the the really epic smooth and gargantuan since toward the beginning of the track that that it deserves but once they get into the jam on the song they are just blasting through it and this pretty much feels like the end of the album for me right after this and My Bloody Valentine cover view made me realizes kind of tacked on to the end and it doesn't really feel like any other track on the album especially production-wise the drums feel so sharp and tinny and don't have a lot of punch to them the pianos get swallowed in the guitar distortion a little bit on that track the bass is kind of strumming along to the tempo gets a little lost in the in the chaos I think too the jazzy guitar solos toward the end of the track are pretty nice it definitely didn't become one of my favorite parts on the album though another part on the album I didn't really care for the song vices the way the drums get so much more intense and speedy just filling up space as much as possible with fills in every direction but to kind of hear the keyboard playing the same smooth chords as that is happening not hearing and kind of get lost in that progression just building up with the drums felt kind of weird for me but other than that I don't really have a lot of complaints I mean I think these guys are doing fantastic things for jazz and and whether that's intentional or they're pretty much just doing this for themselves doesn't really matter I like that bad bad not good as incorporating more original material though sometimes I think maybe they should kind of let it sit and and incubate like I said earlier in regards to rotten decay because I love the way they progressed that song and lemonade bastard medley that they do is also proof that if they work on something hard enough they let it sit long enough it's going to become fantastic and I love that they're bringing in more sounds and more instrumentation this time around - and it's not just for flash it's not just for show it's actually to the musical element of these songs and bringing a lot of character to them - I'm feeling a strong eight - a light nine on this album I think it's fantastic and definitely going to be one of my favorites toward the end of this year but what do you guys think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantino bad bet not good forever [Music] [Music]

together in the aftermath of the seminal stoner metal band sweep high on fire has been releasing albums for well over ten years now I reviewed their previous LP that dropped a few years ago snakes for the divine which I liked but because of the slightly less heavy production that that album delivered it really hasn't gone down as one of the Bands most powerful releases but the ups and downs the something that made that record great and something that I feel like snakes for the divine was was missing a little bit and that is some serious variety among the tracks the opener on this thing delivers a really grim kind of melodic chorus that that I like a lot and one of the best guitar solos on the entire LP is toward the end of this track on the instrumental bridge just tapping in there just really noodley really intense and the track fertile green kind of separates itself with its speed the snare drum led drums on this one just feels so they've got so much push to them and they switch between this really fast beating these just intense fills that are pushed against these descending guitar chords they have a really kind of dark evil characteristic to them there's a really slow head bang and riff on the track madness of an architect and there is a gorgeous instrumental interlude that comes right after that track bright almost uplifting harmonized guitar solos toward the end of the track and the band every single time they hit the fourth bar of this groove that they're playing they subtract a beat from the bar and it kind of throws the groove off a little bit in an interesting way but they play it off so naturally and after a really great solid first half and I and I know this has happened to you too you just kind of think in your head man how can how can the rest of this album not be awesome well after the first half my favorite tracks end up being the the slower ones the track king of daisies is pretty much a legitimate metal ballad stoner sludge metal ballad and there are some real notes kind of coming through on Matt Pike's vocals something I really haven't heard him do this clearly for like a couple albums there are these ooh chorus vocals in there that feel kind of angelic but kind of like black hellish angel angelic and there are these very slow heavy guitar chords that are just like lighter worthy it's a track that feels like crushing and inspiring at the same time the song war-horn the closer on this thing has even clearer vocals and the lyrics just hit so hard and are so vivid telling this story about a war zone I thought this album was fantastic I didn't think high on fire was was going to come out with an LP that punched this hard after snakes for the divine but they did not disappoint for me at all I feel like this LP has the speed and has that direct cutthroat approach that snakes for the divine did but brings forth that overbearing overpowering production that that album should've had and these faster and more extreme tracks are levelled out a bit with a good number of songs that are either really heavy really slow or very melodic and kind of pretty some of the songs on here are pretty long but high on fire still could have gone the distance pushed out a few more tracks through a few more angles in this LP but outside of that I can't really complain I'm feeling a strong 8 to a light 9 on this thing but what do you guys think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana high on fire forever you

that'll teach you to mess with my root vegetables I deserve to pet the puppy hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's squeakiest chair busiest music nerd and it's time for you samu doe self-titled the zmuda Budo is a new band fronted by singer/songwriter and musical experimentalist Nixa Muto formerly of the books unfortunately the books broke up pretty recently and it wasn't too long ago that they dropped one of my favorite albums in their discography the the way the way out hold on a second there it is that was my second favorite LP of 2010 yeah and this is really Nick's first shot at putting out some official solo material ever since the book started officially releasing material now before this LP came there was an EP that got released and though I did like it I gave it a positive review I felt like after after the review still I was left with some questions what is this project really is it all that different from the books stylistically and now that I have this full-length LP in my lap I feel like I had those questions answered very very answered basically on this LP miksa Muto has taken his experimental nature just futzing with with lyrics with song structures with sounds and he's now applying it to a full band context style setup the focus has shifted away from from looped and and diddled rhythms and samples and found sounds so even though nick is not really shooting for a sound collage type of thing that books fans may be used to he still searches for avenues to do something interesting creating sounds that you're not likely to hear on on other albums and he does it with familiar instrumentation to just guitar bass synthesizers drums vocals and and some of this LP hits me with a really interesting sound right from the start on the opening track where the song opens up it's really nice hi-hat rhythm it's it's it's an interesting groove but then these vocals start singing out calling out very brightly over that rhythm and they're edited they're edited heavily to have this kind of skippy skittery effect i love the melody they're singing it's it's really bright it's really playful but man the editing on these vocals is what brings it to a whole nother level and makes it feel so different and just so new it does a great job of setting the mood for this LP and the next track grown man don't cry keeps spirits high as well track is proof the this whole album in in fact that experimental music does not need to be this serious boring thing it can be fun it can be exciting the sharp angular guitar leads on on this next track kind of reminds me of something I would hear on like a Dirty Projectors album but but much more bouncy there's a little bit of drumming thrown in throughout the track and as the song continues these synth arpeggios start growing and then getting louder and brighter and they eventually kind of fall into the mix just into place like Tetris blocks I feel like I could really express myself in regards to this song visually I kind of felt limited when when it came to words so so I just drew a quick picture and this is this is the picture redheaded boy some freckles and he's really excited to open up this book and when he opens it there's a rainbow just flying out of it crashing into his face and then it says science rules this LP is definitely something that that took some studying and some focus and some foresight to create and exploring as well but it's still just about as fun as opening up a book and having a rainbow crash into your face for reasons that completely defy all logic or if you want a musical comparison maybe you could say it feels like big science error laurie anderson writing pop and rock tunes so the next few tracks on this thing are actually from the EP that i reviewed earlier this year not going to go too deep into them because i've already discussed them the track too late to apologize actually drops a little bit of auto-tune in the mix which isn't that far-fetched considering how much a vocoder is on this LP at some points and you know even though there is this stigma kind of surrounding the tool call that the tool of auto-tune Nick uses it in a way that is a lot like the way that he uses vocoder so it's just as entertaining the next track on here hits me with something even even stranger though it puts a really great groove out there with this bassline that sounds like it was sequenced on this this eighties bass sequencer some really tight drumming on this track and some guitar playing and there are vocals over this track and I don't even know if I would call them them rapping but they're kind of wrapping there the vocals of a woman that sound like they're coming from a text-to-speech generator Nixa Mutoh had typed in these lyrics and then this robot woman voice is reading these lyrics out but then her vocals are edited so that they are rhythmically in sync with the muse so they kinda sound like they're wrapping it really kind of that make it kind of disorienting and this really kind of sad sorry descending guitar chord progression that's kind of depressing and the final song on here is a little anticlimactic but still very pretty the songs are great the sounds are really creative interesting and you know what I love the most about this album is just the production the recording though I was kind of on the fence with that on the EP I feel like I've come all the way around and I am loving the sound of these songs they just are not murd in effects like reverb or distortion or anything like that this album feels so raw it feels so crisp it feels so clean it feels so crunchy it has a bit of a DIY kind of quality to the recording but it comes through so clear this album has nothing to hide nothing to mask nothing to enhance it's just pure unadulterated loving gentle good-natured light-hearted weirdness I'm loving the sound of zum Udo in front of a full band and that's pretty much it feeling a light too decent ate on this album what do you guys think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next Anthony Fantana the Muto forever

I like critics you know I want even create me a critic hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review Meshuga colas Meshuga is a Swedish metal band this is their seventh full-length LP I've received a lot of requests to talk about this LP and it's not difficult to see why Meshuga has a pretty heavy reputation in the metal world they have a sound they have a style that has influenced countless groups over the 20-plus years they've been releasing material and part of what has built this Empire is consistency they've never really put out a terrible record a terrible record however they've never really ventured that far outside of what has been proven to work for them almost every studio album these guys have released has been a very slight variation on the same theme endlessly perfecting one single approach Jen's Kidman's vocals used to be a little bit more intelligible on the band's older stuff of course over the years with new technology the group's heaviness factor has increased but I gotta say on this new LP it's pretty much Meshuga as usual you know not much for me to report in terms of what this album really offers to to longtime fans sorry to disappoint the people who were asking me to review this but I think just constant comparisons to every single other LP Meshuga has released before this one would be kind of like splitting hairs I'm not trying to say there's not differences between this LP and others that this band is put out and we will get into a few of them later but I'd much rather focus on maybe trying to turn people on to this group so if this is the first time you're running into Meshuga or you've been curious about them you're in for a very heavy treat machetes world pretty much around the Rif which is nothing entirely new but the way the group approaches this that's what sets them apart first it's the guitar tone that these guys put out which is just like I said earlier been a result of constantly perfecting trying this one thing making it bigger making it better making a heavy hear the sound is a little more commonplace than it used to be but it's mostly because so many groups try to copycat this style the chugs that Meshuga pushes out there are so thick they're so bassy and when they Bend a string they really let it ring out it gives off this sound like one oh it's so guttural it's so thick and deep and mechanical it sounds like something being dismantled or destroyed or crushed the guitars on this LP are basically the size of the explosions in like a Michael Bay film the opener alone I am Colossus just gives me this image of a giant robot demon roaring out with fire and molten lava pouring past its jaws and all of the riffs are pretty much emphasizing just a really heavy groove and Michigan's grooves are really how they define themselves the group is always looking for some kind of odd time signature to play in or just seeking some kind of way to take a rhythm take a groove and just diddle it just throw it off and helping this out are the drums though the guitars on a Meshuga record are incredibly important I feel like in a way the guitars are there to kind of emphasize all the awesome stuff the drums are doing to me the drums usually steal the show on a Meshuga LP and this is no different the beats the rhythms are ever-changing always improvising lots of tasteful fills the drum sound fantastic whether they're doing something slow and primal like behind the Sun or kind of speeding things up and throw in a double bass drum in there like on the demons name I am it immediately a bigger fan of the slower tracks though where the band really hits just very sludgy molasses speed tempos and they let those guitars wring out and get really heavy they just feel gargantuan on those tracks now with all these guitars and drums and and Kidman's kind of mid-range growl covering every single one of these songs Meshuga kind of toys with the foundation of of what sort of groove metal new metal jump the  riffs but with some fantastic drumming some really interesting to tar tone a lot of heaviness and technical ability Meshuga is a metal band that puts out energetic tracks with heavy riffs that appeal beyond the aggression and actually make this sound this style something worth giving a second chance if you've already kind of written it off it's got a lot of virtuosity and though it is technical music it doesn't come across as difficult because Meshuga pumps these grooves out so naturally with so much ease with so much energy it's just easy to get into the track and maybe not even feel like you're listening to something that is all that complex but I did not come here to just simply praise the cell P because I do have some issues with it though there are some variations in speed on this album there's not really many variations in intensity or volume nearly every song here kind of shoots for the same level of those two things the last track is a lone guitar instrumental that's it's very soft very gentle kind of pretty but it's it's a little too late though there are some highlights on here that get me going break those bones maro dum yuge listening to this LP all the way through can be a little bit of a drag especially since the faster tracks on here feel a little bit too mechanical for me to to really get into the grooves to really feel them which is funny because that's not an issue I had with faster tracks from the band's previous material I definitely did not feel that way on chaos fear and another issue I'm kind of having is the guitar solos I know the guitar solos have never been a primary focus in meshuggaas music especially since these days the riffs have taken so much precedent but there are a lot of times on this LP where I wish the guitars would change things up at least a little bit and attempt to do something that is that is just as technical as the drums like the track behind the Sun toward the beginning of the song the guitars are just kind of playing this very lazy sort of atmospheric lead I'm not even sure what it is it's just kind of there to add another sound and toward the end of the track that's very kind of blurry and and boring guitar solo comes in and just does not really add that much and it's it's mixed solo it's buried I can barely make it out and the guitar solo toward the end of the demon's name is is not good oh man it's just tapping and it sounds like it's tapping at it at a completely different tempo it just kind of feels like tapping just a half tapping on the album because it sounds technical on on the surface but there's not really an interesting tap pattern or anything going on with the solo so as much as I do like the riffs on this thing the guitars really don't do much more than that to me chaos fear and destroy a race improve had way better solos the solo on the opener to chaos sphere is still one of the weirdest solos I've heard on a metal record and as far as style and variation goes throughout an entire album catch 33 had way more to offer so overall I did think this was a likeable LP but it will not be going down as one of my favorites in the Meshuga discography I'm kind of feeling a light too decent 6 on this thing but what do you guys think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next Anthony Fantana Meshuga colos forever [Music]

another track on this LP instead even as a soundscape I'm really not in love with this track especially since a lot of the effects cédric uses on this vocals on on this one kind of grate on my ears but those are really the only tracks on here where I'm really not into the textures that Volta is using in their songs for the most part this thing is just loaded with really really colorful rock songs rock songs that despite how many changes this band is made to its formula on this thing still display a decent amount of guts the song MalK walker and in my opinion brings that usual jam level intensity of this band but in kind of a pared down 3 minute and 31 second package and their moments on here where I'm hearing reverse drums reverse guitar solos found sound of like a crowd talking but I do want to emphasize that I think Mars Volta is still writing good Tunes though this six studio LP of theirs is definitely heavily heavily indebted to synthesizers effects the band is really trying to explore sound a bit more and I like it the tracks on this thing are as composed of chords and notes as they are textures and and futuristic synthetics and while this thing is definitely one of the most instantaneous and accessible records yet they've still layers so any sounds into this thing you can return to and return to and return to it and still kind of pick up little layers that you might not have heard before there are a lot of subtleties in this mix and despite all the positive things I could say about this album there's still no way this thing is going to become a universal fan pleaser because it's nowhere near as intense as some of Marv's Voltas earlier records and the gorgeous moments that this album does present are not plentiful enough to make even me kind of forget that and totally fall in love with this newer straightforward direction still I think with this record Mars Volta is on the cusp of something really interesting a really awesome hybrid of of experimental sounds and progressive rock and whether they're making songs that are accessible and catchy or long-winded and difficult that is a road I would like to see them continue down the album is pretty solid throughout starts off with some really great tracks and finishes with a fantastic one-two zette into knots one of the coolest songs I think these guys have written so far basically I'm feeling a decent too strong seven on this thing thought it was really good but what do you guys think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana the Mars Volta hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review the shins Port of Mauro the shins are a Portland via Albuquerque pop and rock band and this is their first LP in five years and a lot can happen in five years however on this record I would I would not say a lot did you know the shins have never really been one of the boldest or most experimental or most definitive bands in indie rock and yet they've they've still managed to be one of the most popular and they're formula for success has basically been to release a blend of acoustic and electric rock songs that are very straightforward accessible their songs that kind of paint stories and in very pastel colors and I do think their first LP has some some nice energy to it that kind of grabs me but I think they toned things down a little bit on their next two LPS and you know not to be brutal about it but I think with those two albums they were moving toward making music that was just kind of ordinary and and not completely ordinary you know I know a Shins song when I hear one but you know it's close enough to that where I would be turned off despite all this change over the years this is the first time I'm listening to a Shin's album where I kind of feel like I am listening to something mature but I might not even completely mean that in a positive way the mature feeling I get from this LP comes mostly from the production while the shins have never really written music that ignited a fire in me you know got me really excited or really passion the way their music sounded had a very I guess kind of earnest charm to it you know I'm not saying it's it's lo-fi or badly recorded but it was definitely the antithesis of making music that was overblown however on Port of morrow I feel like the band is kind of pulling out a lot of stops a lot of tracks on this album follow suit with this LPS first single simple song which just kind of delivers the regular shins style but with bigger sounds and and more sheen giant chorus vocals and arena sized drumbeats that I could totally hear being played before millions of the Super Bowl halftime show or something the song fall of 82 is another track that kind of has this very arena sized quality to it the verse is very understated kind of has this bar band groove to it to it some tinny guitar leads over and when the chorus comes it just explodes a trumpet comes in to back it up and okay trumpet but overall the the hook sounds pretty nice no way down throws a hook out to that that kind of turns the volume up a little bit the song bein switch does the same but with some glassy keyboards that kind of reminded me of Coldplay or something and that track also has a very quirky rhythm underneath everything with these sequence drums that kind of make me think of like bubbles popping some glistening acoustic pianos on that track too but the end result just kind of makes me think of music I would hear like at the mall or like in a grocery store of course like usual The Shins delivers them some quieter tracks on here like it's only life where James Mercer actually sounds pretty passionate singing on the verse even though the hook is is a little generic the song for full feels a little funky on some points maybe I'd say it's a bit of all country or something like that but my favorite on this thing was definitely the final track the title track to this album which is very kind of dark you usually don't hear the shins play with something this dark Merce singing in this in this falsetto vocal these pianos just feels so heavy on the track and the vocal melody is it's just so fueled by emotional pain overall I guess I kind of felt like this album was okay the shins definitely brings some some newer and bigger sounds to the table and that may be exciting for some older fans to hear that but I don't feel like they brought a newer and bigger energy to kind of fill that space which kind of brings me back to my earlier statement about being very mature because to me this album feels like a guy in his late 30s or early 40s in a suit who just kind of forgot how to have fun of course there are people who make it into that age who do still know how to have a great time or be exciting or kind of play it loose but the shins are so far from that it just becomes uninteresting even though some of the songs on here are pretty nice once you get to know them some sweet melodies some pretty good hooks they're not really coming through with that strong of a flavor or personality so I'm kind of feeling a strong 5 to a light six on this thing I don't see myself returning to it outside of maybe a few tracks but what do you guys think of it do you love it do you hate it Harry here you go right there why and what should I review next anthony Fantan oh the shins forever

montage set where he is throwing the beer of a poor soul onto the ground but it was it was free beer so you know no harm no foul after that zex Marquis came out and played they were pretty nice they're pretty nice in person and then we caught the drum keyboard duo zuhr CH who I was pretty surprised was only two people as they were making a lot more noise than two people would would normally make delicate Steve played after that as well as an afro pop group Jack and a bay they were pretty freaking awesome as well and then we had to get out of there in order to catch magnetic fields playing over at the ACL venue we came a little early and we ended up seeing the war on drugs live and they were actually pretty good as well very dreamy and ethereal in person just as much as they are on record but it was just awesome seeing them just play a stage that that large after that magnetic fields came on played a very solid acoustic set sadly it was maybe a little too quiet for the crowd because a lot of people were talking which was a bit upsetting but still many of the songs came through magic and then we rushed over to try to catch the zoo set that was happening right after that we only got to watch them play two songs sadly but they were two very good songs and then I think I caught my favorite set of the night with Thundercat him in his band fantastic musicians and they were just so tight playing so fast the grooves were so hard and even though his new album has kind of an electronic edge it translated to a live band setting so well oh it was just awesome we ended the night with a very short set from das racist main attractions came out and played with them for a little bit they played like three or four songs but it was still pretty fun on our last day of South by Southwest we decided to take it a little easy since we had an early flight to catch we went over to the terror bird showcase where Emily wells played check her out a very awesome one-woman show beats keyboards drums violin everything looped into some pretty nice tunes right after her came Beach Fossils they played a very energetic set and then the band we came down for Deerhoof who played a really awesome set third time I've seen the band live and this was easily the most energetic performance I've seen them give of those three times bus driver even came out toward the end of the set and wrapped over one of their songs and of course that was awesome and that was my South by Southwest for 2012 driving into the night saw a lot of great bands of course could not see every band I wanted to see sadly a lot of artists that I wanted to see were playing at impossible times playing at the same time as other artists that I wanted to see playing on showcases that were either early or late it's kind of the downside to a festival like this that has so much going on at once but I caught so many underground and unique artists in some really interesting small or or just very intimate spaces and it just made that little con all the more insignificant because I did catch some really amazing shows this week I want to thank everybody who's been watching the show and supporting me and made this trip possible I'd like to thank all the artists I caught live and here's to next year thank you for watching Anthony Fantan Oh South by Southwest forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet stuffiest music nerd and it's time for a review the men open up you open up a little bit of the men are in New York band who I reviewed last year when they made their sacred bones Records debut with the album leave home and the album had some great tracks on it but it didn't end up being one of my favorites of the year for a couple reasons for one the album didn't really have one consistent style or sound it felt stretched a little too thin because there was never really one angle they kept attacking so I never really felt like I got to know the band all that well I got to know their influences though the band would trip through the sounds of noise rock and post-hardcore and maybe even a little doom metal and punk garage rock psychedelic rock as well it's like the band had all these chips and they just kind of let them fall where they may instead of kind of playing them strategically the men seemed too in love with the world of rock music to just settle down with one single sound and like I thought this new album displays an array of different styles of music on it they even managed to toy with a few sounds I'm yet to hear them play with there are moments on here that just are rowdy garage rock with just a tinge of Blues in there country music drone acoustic ballads indie rock ballads instrumental jams stylistically the band is all over the place again but I can't help but feel like this time around they went into this album with a much clearer game plan like if they were going to play with as many styles as as they wanted to they were at least going to organize them make them so that they didn't feel like they were in disarray segue some of the tracks into one another put the songs that are stylistically similar closer to each other so the album has a bit more of a flow the album opens up with these garage punk songs that I told you about with these shit kicker guitar riffs and these baby girl lyrics the guitar riffs are all fuzzy and distorted and and damaged and over driven in lo-fi and just badass it sounds like they're being played out of amplifiers that are on the fritz like I'm seeing the band live and their amplifiers are just catching on fire because of hot and cold tubes and bad wiring it sounds a little generic but the band delivers it with enough energy to the point where it's it's pretty entertaining the second track is is the same way for me except there's a little bit more of a blues edge in that track it's got a very country and rootsy feel to it a little bit the song sounds like what would sound track a southern bar fight where beer bottles and pool cues and stools are our weapons and bodies are flying in every direction smashing tables getting thrown out of windows but right after that the album kind of chills out into this very slow and pretty and guitar led country instrumental which eventually slides into this guitar drone using the same tremolo effects that were making the song feel so country right at the beginning and it does this transition pretty well and an even better transition is is right after that it uses the tremolo effect to bring things into the next track where the BAM pretty much creates a guitar rock jam that is pulled straight out of the NOI playbook very kind of krautrock esque but it's got some really modern punked-out guts to it I mean the segues on this LP really make this thing feel like more of a journey more of an adventure the indie rock tune that breaks in right after this Jam kind of feels like an extension of that song and then after this the band kind of settles into a sweet spot with a trio of a very short and cat she tracks I feel like the band kind of breaks off stylistically at this point the album kind of loses its flow of it but the band churns out three of the most memorable songs that ever heard them rice so I'm really okay with it the LP ends with some solid jams and I feel like this album a lot like that Cloud Nothings album that came out earlier this year I just get kind of a really solid rock record that's memorable it's catchy fun enjoyable and just difficult to say no to even if it is a little derivative because the energy is most certainly there and the energy and the passion is really what's attracting me to these songs feeling a strong seven on this LP I feel like it's a huge improvement over leave home overall yeah it's a little less aggressive less noisy less abrasive and that may have attracted some people to the men originally there may be some fans that are disappointed to see those sounds kind of move away but I thought this LP had a much better flow some really nice catchy and positive vibes coming off some of these tracks and I don't know just overall it was a more enjoyable experience for me I just came away from this album wanting more whining repeat listens and just really looking forward to what these guys do after this so let me know what do you think of this thing do you love it do you hate it well why and what do you think I should review after this anthony Fantan oh the men forever

trying to just keep it together trying to just make it make all sense try to just laugh cough hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review the magnetic fields love at the bottom of the sea mad mad mad mad mad magnetic fields is an eccentric singer/songwriter project and band fronted by and founded by stephen merritt and over the years the band is kind of defined its sound with songs that feature simple instrumentation simple song structures but big personalities characters storytelling strange occurrences despite the simplicity there is still a lot of ambition coming out of the magnetic fields especially on prolific projects like 69 love songs which is actually 69 love songs it's not just a title or their previous three LPS where they kind of abstain from using synthesizers in any of the songs which were usually a mainstay in the band's music or maybe even the the first of those three albums I which all kind of have I at the beginning of the time a lot of the magnetic fields releases kind of have an interesting angle to them but I don't know to me maybe it's just not obvious but I don't feel like love at the bottom of the seed pushes the band creatively in any kind of interesting direction or create any kind of challenge the synthesizers are back and I'm sure a lot of older fans are excited to hear the return to the magnetic field songwriting process but I'm kind of on the fence with that incredible advancements have been made in the world of synthesizer technology and MIDI between the release of 69 love songs in 1999 and love at the bottom of the sea in 2012 but from the sound of this album you wouldn't know it than kind of embrace newer sounds the magnetic fields have kind of reverted back to an older sound and I don't mean like get lost or 69 love songs and older sound I mean more like the wayward bus an older sound but the thing is the old old stuff these guys have put out kind of has a charm to it because of the recording technology and the instruments available during that time love at the bottom of the seat doesn't really have that advantage it is an album that was recorded today it sounds like it was recorded today but it sounds also like it's trying to be as if it were recorded yesterday I'm not completely sure why but the weird and and and kind of playful synthesizer sounds and sometimes noisy synthesizer sounds at the magnetic fields incorporate into their songs just don't have that endearing cute charm to them for me on this it makes the tracks that I dislike on here even more dislikeable like infatuation and in the horrible party and it even semi ruins songs on here that I think are pretty good like your girlfriend's face I guess on older albums where synthesizers were back in regular rotation like 69 love songs and like it lost the synth sounds just felt so much less obnoxious it's not even just really the synths on the album it's also kind of the recording quality in the mix of these songs for me because things just sound so dull I guess and kind of claustrophobic like there's no breathing room between the instruments and there's just not that much fidelity and the vocals feel a little buried in everything as well which is kind of sad because I love hearing Stephan Meredith's kind of deep in husky voice you could say what you want to say about realism and distortion and and I but I feel like those LPS in comparison with this new one had much more fidelity and acoustics that were pretty rich and beautiful I know sound is not really the magnetic fields biggest selling point but I'm not really enjoying the sound of this album at all I did like some songs on here though but overall the songs did end up kind of feeling hit or miss for me I didn't find a lot of tracks on here to be all that funny or or witty or clever or maybe even that strange my favorite track on here was the first song to drop from this album and ruin dragged that track is pretty much a picturesque magnetic fields track that will always keep me coming back to whatever a new magnetic fields album is just in case there is another song that is that great on these are the kinds of strange character portraits that you catch on a magnetic fields album the song God wants us to wait features a woman kind of singing to her boyfriend just as they're on the
