are other songs on here that don't really hit me with an interesting story or angle that I find all that memorable or whittier clever kind of like going back to the country or the only boy in town or born for love or even the horrible party which was definitely absurd but this thing was only a 30-minute album but for some it just felt so much longer to me every single time I listen to it I just felt like I disliked it more and more and more and maybe that's because I got a hold of the tracks that I liked and I dislike pretty quickly you know this album lost its mystery for me really fast but the thing is the songs on here that I have really strong feelings about positive or negative aren't even really that many you know most of the tracks on here I just feel like are alright you know not that horrible that I would hate them but not so exciting that I'm rushing back to listen to them I think it's easy to accept this album as being really great really fantastic because a it's in a way a return to form the synths are back the songs are kooky they are short as hell all under 30 minutes and and B this album is coming off the tail of realism which was not a well-received album so I on the mend today hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd time for a review Big KRIT forever in a day Big KRIT is a Mississippi rapper who's been bringing back the classier side of southern hip hop in a big way for the past couple years he's been making mixtapes for a while but a little bit he really started making waves in 2010 when he put out his album crit was here and he gained even more ground with a Def Jam signing and return of forever in 2011 and the dude's output so far has just been incredibly consistent just really solid stuff he raps on his own stuff he sings a little bit as well and he produces his own instrumentals he is in complete control of everything that goes into his music so rarely do his tracks ever take an unpredictable turn not to say that there's not variety on here it's just that I rarely hear a Big KRIT track that I find out of character whether crit is gone for something really smooth and soulful like on the track highs and lows or really hard-hitting and energetic like the song country he's always throwing production out there that has this really smooth resonant bass crisp eyes and a real strong southern flavor the dude can produce and he's proven himself as a songwriter too because he puts some great infectious and extremely catchy hooks on his tracks too I think the weakest link in his chain for a lot of people is his rapping his flows on his records crit does not display himself to be the most flashy spitter out there though if you did check out the double XL cypher or the ve T cypher last year that he was involved in he definitely held his own against the other emcees that were there tons of technical ability isn't really what Big KRIT shoots for if you want to understand what big crits appeal is listen to the verse he dropped on that roots album that came out last year undone vivid imagery storytelling passionate emotions and it's all displayed in a way where it's extremely extremely easy to relate to for the listener whether big Cree is rapping about the worst things the world has to offer being successful or even just a fantasy car he really tries to put the listener in the passenger seat TT a lot of the time this gives Big KRIT songs really kind of uplifting and inspirational quality to them especially when he's rapping about how far along he's come in his career because he's really putting a real picture of success out there because it's not like climbing to the top is all money models and expensive alcohol success can be really fleeting especially in the music industry and unless you're completely clueless or really egotistical you're going to have a natural hunger to self-improve or maybe just have some feelings of self-doubt here and there that feeling is kind of displayed on the first track to drop from this album boobie miles which is a song titled after a high school tailback that was looking at a pretty promising football career just before it was ended by a knee injury crit takes the track through a series of sports analogies and ends up turning into a word of advice that if you're ever going to make it to where you want to be you've got to be focused you've got to be a relentless because you never know when your competitions gonna creep up those kinds of feelings play as big a role in crits personal story as those high end blissful feelings that come with success I actually think on this LP those feelings play a little bit bigger of a role it's almost like the further Crick gets away from the ways life used to be the more he gets nostalgic about it me personally when listening to this thing I was catching maybe a little bit more referencing to his family and his friends and his girlfriend as well especially on tracks like yesterday and red.i it's not a night and a change though because crits usual subject matters and lyrical topics make it onto this LP too but this overly sentimental attitude kind of comes through on the instrumental side of this LP to do here Big KRIT is sampling just a little bit more smooth jazz R&B and soul and it's given a lot of these tracks a really strong emotional foundation like the tracks boobie miles and yesterday are just built on that Hot Buttered Soul of guys like Isaac Hayes Curtis Mayfield and Marvin Gaye the song handwriting actually samples a sultry cut from Annie and Peebles handwriting is on the wall it's actually a track woo Tang Clan sampled as well on their 2001 album iron flag the track red eye has some really somber piano chords on it and that's not the only track on here that just has maybe a little bit more atmosphere around it some shimmering instrumentation some prettier sounds just some more high gloss Sheen the track me in my old school even has these reverb soaked flute solos kind of fluttering all over the place in between these cascading layers of string sections I think it's definitely the prettiest instrumental big Critias put together so far crit even invites guest musicians onto this LP to perform on on these tracks the song wake up has some are some more familiar sounds on this thing though like the track forever and a day the title track which sounds like a variation of the title track from big crits previous album same with the songs 1986 and country rap tunes those songs also kind of feel like different takes on crits usual sound but different enough to still kind of be enjoyable especially 1986 which has a really interesting change up in the beat toward the end of the track it's almost like it changes into a totally different song toward the end but one of the most exciting songs on here or maybe the most affecting songs on here for me is definitely packaged store the opening bar on that track about the preacher trying to pick up a prostitute with collection money from the church is just so dark and and twisted especially when it's kind of backed up with the light about snakes in the grass too in the last track on here the closer the alarm is kind of like this really just fiery intense philosophical wake-up call there's this really kind of operatic vocal toward the end of the track and this instrumental swell that's that's pretty gorgeous overall the album is great but if I had to get a little nitpicky with it some tracks did kind of pale in comparison to others definitely tracks like wake up and yesterday could have developed a little bit more got a little bit more detail into the instrumental as the song progressed some spots here felt maybe a little bit too lovesick I felt like the last track could have used a lot more lyrics but still I enjoyed this a lot this was great and between this Return to Forever and chritmas here this guy has been on an incredible streak it's only kind of making the build-up to his kind of major label debut live from the underground even more intense to me just feeling a decent too strong eight on this thing what do you guys think about it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana Big KRIT forever and a day forever [Music]

please don't smell please don't stop I don't want it to smell please don't snow hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review wizard wizard wizard is a new project fronted by rapper singer and multi-instrumentalist Kid Cudi and it also involves doctor genius a multi-instrumentalist and producer as well and dot is a guy that Cuddy has worked with before so this is definitely not the first time they've pulled material together and what makes the site project so different interesting and worth talking about is that it's real change in direction for Cudi Cudi is known primarily as a rapper and even though he's put out a couple albums so far his releases have pretty much been labeled as being hip-hop even though consistently he's been a guy who has led other genres of music influences stuff too because conceptually this is really Cudi's and indata geniuses rock record now rock music has been divided into a lot of different sounds and styles over the years but I would like to think that no matter how fractured the world of rock gets all the best albums in the genre have one common characteristic and that characteristic is fire it's passion it's just high intensity emotion it's not a tangible thing it's not really something that you can measure all that accurately with numbers but you know it's there when you hear it you hear it in the guitar leads the Jimi Hendrix plays on the opening to Purple Haze you can hear it in Joe strummers voice his voice that's sounding so breath you just gasping for breath on the track London Calling and you can hear in the build-up and the impact of the hard heavy distorted guitar chords on the Nirvana track litheium passion that when you hear you just get sucked in you lose control it's that passion that has made rock music such an important force over the years and this kind of passion or any kind of passion is exactly what wizard is missing 11 tracks and an absolutely no fire my issue is that wizard is trying to relive these rock sounds with absolutely no guts whatsoever and it's said because the album actually has a really good intro with these just rumbling synthesizers and these dark muddy guitar leads I thought I was going to hurt I thought it was going to hear like this combination of of progressive synth rock and and doom metal for some reason but then this programmed drum machine beat comes in and it actually sounds pretty good it's an epic combination but the album drops hard after that track with high off life the track starts with these handclaps and this generic guitar riff there's this beat that sounds like it was finger tapped on an on an MPC and Cuddy starts doing this weird stuff with his vocal delivery and he starts singing about his house in the hills or singing to his mom telling her not to worry about him it's just so unimaginative and there's no momentum whatsoever the guitar riffs on this thing just lay really lazily against this paste paste drumbeat that has no Drive to it it's just rock music but like neutered I don't even do drugs and and Cuddy's song about a drug-free lifestyle made not doing drugs sound really boring this flatness this lack of Drive this lack of excitement is an issue that pretty much every track on here suffers from the song love heart tries to get it up with this quarter note bass drum beat really kind of push things along but it just ends up flaccid and the song doctor pill sounds like a bit of an attempt to chase after this grunge rock sound and the message behind the song is fine kind of talking about prescription drugs and people expecting them to fix their problem but Cuddy's vocal delivery just kind of ruins it feels so ridiculous and he's just going around it sounds like something he heard on another record but then he just figured he could do it on this record and it would work even though he's putting zero energy into it I got a say on this record Cuddy does not sound like a guy who has put out two albums and been featured by Ti and jay-z and Kanye West instead he just sounds like a random dude who listened to a bunch of Nirvana and blur and then said I've got to make a rock album but in this albums sort of defense not every track on here tries to rock you know there are some songs on here that slow things down like I'd like the dream time machine but even that track fails to be even pretty I think the one track on here that was decent was teleport to me Jamie and and the reason that track works out so well is that it's a pop song it's more familiar territory for Cudi this really introspective song it's a little sad a little forlorn it's about a relationship but it just stops short of being fantastic and I think partially that's because of Cuddy's voice I never thought I would say this but I don't think Cudi is is that great of a singer and the reason I feel like I I never thought I would say this is because out of all the rapper singers out there today I thought he was one of the better ones whenever he would sort of take a break from his rapping to sing he was much more on pitch than most rappers who attempted singing his voice had some personality to it too but not enough to hold an entire album on his own I guess take the hook from high off fly for example his voice just sounds really strained really all over the place on that song and it's just smothered and distortion to cover it up the problem becomes kind of even more obvious when you take a track like where did you sleep last night which is an old traditional folk song but this version of the seems to be pretty heavily inspired by the Nirvana version of the song I don't want to say Cuddy's voices worse here than on the rest of the album but the fact that it's not that great combined with the drum machine B and just the muddy guitar and the the really plain bass line it sounds like something I would hear pumping out of the PA of a local bar during karaoke night some of the lyrics on this thing really make me cringe too and I really didn't find much of anything that appealed to me on this record it's it's definitely something for the fans definitely for the fans kind of feeling like a strong two to a light three on this record but what did you guys think about this thing did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantan Oh wizard forever [Music] you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time sorry that was kind of forceful and it's time for an album review christian mistress possession these guys are a hard rock band from olympia washington you can call it metal if you want to use the n-word and this is their sophomore LP it's their debut album for relapse records and these guys don't exactly play a new sound of metal a new style of metal their music kind of rejects all of the harsh and abrasive and overly aggressive sounds that the genre has evolved into over the years if you want a more simple explanation it's more like what would happen if metal as a genre had stopped evolving around 1982 the thing is these guys managed to incorporate sounds from metal music before that decade - yeah they have the really driving hyper melodic and accessible sounds of like Judas Priest and Iron Maiden but also they've got that really heavy brooding darkness of groups like Black Sabbath there's a little bit of rush in there too and and rush is a very minor minor part of this album's recipe and it's only a comparison that I make because of the vocals it's not like there are any insane or technical progressive rock time signature changes on this thing it's just the voice of frontwoman Christine Davis she's got a really smoky dramatic vocal delivery and it's got a very very light raspy nough stew it - and the cadence of her voice reminds me a little bit of russia's Geddy Lee I do think it's kind of an unintended similarity though now sometimes on this LP Davis is really not as aggressive as I would expect a metal vocalist to be aggression is not really her strong point but it's not really something I think she emphasis anyway her voice is much better suited for bringing feelings of darkness and enchantment and tortured miss she does have some nice versatility though there are spots on here like the track pentagram and crucifix where she's pretty forceful and on the flip side she can come off very dreary and forlorn like on the title track here now even though the vocals are sort of not going to jump out of the shadows and tear your face off like a starving Wolverine this album is definitely no slouch it's not a wimp some of these tracks have a lot of momentum to them like the song over and over the opener lots of Drive lots of punch on that song hard riffs a very fast beat - and the song black - gold has kind of the pedal to the metal - it feels even more intense with these harmonized guitar leads kind of galloping across the groove but there are other spots on here maybe those are my favourites where things are slower much more brooding heavier I guess you could say the title track feels that way to me that song to me just feels like pagan rituals pentagram dry out on the ground and blood candles everywhere people are wearing cloaks or maybe it's even more like a swamp and Davises vocals kind of like the the fog creeping out over the water with all these Tony Iommi guitar leads just wailing over the music I mean for a group that pretty much sticks to one style of rock there's a lot of variety here in in volume and tempo and mood the band even makes sure to change up its song structures as the album progresses the opening track is just really hard hitting just over two minutes kind of wham bam thank you man lots of energy as the album goes on the songs are getting longer and by the end of this thing lots of changes lots of different parts acoustic interludes that are really funky and and beautiful and build up into these heavy and feminine get our leads that sing out epically into the Starkist night so yeah the tracks kind of get little more progressive as the album continues you can see that I like this album but I still have to admit that this band is doing nothing new stylistically you know if you're on the hunt for a hot new band with a hot new sound or if music that kind of lives in the past usually makes you roll your eyes you're probably not going to enjoy this but then again there are some groups who are heavily influenced by bands or musicians from the past but still managed to drum up their own style or sound in a genre that most people thought was just done innovating the metal band ghost kind of comes to mind and you know if you don't think Christian mistress is is putting their own spin on this style of old-school metal then I would argue they are at least very close to doing so I think this album still manages to be really fun really energetic and catchy and really strong musically like the instrumental bridge on the track pentagram and crucifix is so intense it's camping yes oh that and the way the tempo slows down on the track conviction it creates a really passionate break in the song and I really love the Sinister guitar riffs that open up the song the way beyond between the great guitar solos and the pulsating riffs the fiery leads the bass lines that that hit the groove in all the right places the vocals and and the very good drumming I think Christian mistress is an old-school metal machine they're hardly amateurs who are just trying to copy for me they're more like connoisseurs trying to rekindle trying to find a lost connection I really think these guys were just faced with the unfortunate situation of being born too late so bluntly feeling the light eight on this album enjoy the hell out of it really fun LP really fun rock album and yeah what do you guys think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana Christian mistress forever

Hey it's track review hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review track review where we talk about the latest in rock pop electronic and experimental music arena and it's a track review of one of the most interesting tracks to drop so far this year probably ever will drop this year a collaboration between guerrillas james murphy and andre 3000 the track is do you think the music on this track makes the song interesting of course but each of these guys are in interesting spots and their careers to guerrillas for one is just hot off the release of their third full-length LP Plastic Beach one of my favorite albums of 2010 and LCD Soundsystem released its third full-length LP as well in 2010 this is happening and that album actually managed to be my favorite album of that year and to make things even more interesting James Murphy of LCD Soundsystem after putting out that album pretty much ended the band an andre 3000 rapper producer member of the seminal southern hip hop outfit Outkast hasn't released an album with outcasts in years but their music has done so much for hip hop people are just starving for new music from them even if it's solo stuff now the radio cut of this song was dropped last week and was kind of curated to be a part of this three artists one song series that converse shoes puts together it's where they kind of assemble some unlikely collaboration between some musical minds and just kind of see what comes out and I really have not been huge on the previous three artists one song tracks some of them featured collaborations from the best coast Kid Cudi and Ross stem from Vampire Weekend as well as Andrew W K Matt and K and Soulja Boy and to me the previous tracks in this series definitely had entertainment value but it wasn't so much because of the song be really great it was interesting because these songs just kind of brought a head-scratching collection of artists together collaborators that would turn heads and this track is no slouch when it comes to that Andre 3000 James Murphy guerrillas each of these artists have put out seminal albums and they all have their own strong eccentric and unique styles and I think they really set the bar for these converse collaborations on this track and also the bar for just unlikely collaborations in general and I am NOT talking about the four-minute radio cut that dropped of this song I'm talking about the recently released 13 minute version the extremely ambitious reputations of these three artists have built this track into pretty much a Frankenstein monster of their respective sounds and influences none of these guys feel underutilized they all get their spots on this track where they have a very heavy influence and sometimes their sounds blend together so well it's hard to tell which one of them has more command over a single section of this track and it's almost like they were conscious of how well it was going and how great it sounded they didn't want it to stop so they dragged it out and dragged it out and built on it and just turned it into 13 minutes the track starts off with these really kind of quirky synthesizers that feel very colourful very light kind of simple maybe even dorky and it's got that really cynthy plastic feel that you'll catch if you listen to gorillas Plastic Beach it's like gorillas is still on that plastic synthetic kick underneath this track there's really nice buzzing synthesized bass line and the drums set on this thing just the drums in general just a really nice cake to them lots of snap lots of crack lots of punch and damon albarn of gorillas kind of comes in starts singing in this really listless vocal delivery that you'll be familiar with if you've heard other gorillas LPS and I'm liking the lyrics to one of my favorite spots on here is when he's saying I'm a light at the mall when the power is gone I'm a shadow in the corner just playing along no matter how much I try to dive into his lyrics nothing really comes together or makes sense and I don't think it's meant to it's just a collection of disconnected thoughts and images that are as unlikely as this collaboration but it somehow manages to function and in this hook that kind of flies in James Murphy is right there in the thick of all of these vocals and the overall hook just sounds so cartoony but even though it feels slightly ridiculous you can't deny that the production is there it's great the hook is really catchy the beat is infectious it's like cheesy without the cheese and when andre 3000 comes in right after this it's almost like he sings a second hook when andre finally starts rapping after he sings this spot in the hook he murders this track that's an understatement he doesn't just murder this track he kidnaps it and he ties it up and then he brings it to his van and then he drives it down to his evil lair where he tortures it for like three weeks and then chops it up into little pieces and tosses it into the ocean serial killer style his spinning is so freakin fast it's hard to keep up and he's dropping some really funny and clever lines too I think my favorite line is the one he drops toward the end of his verse he says and if it aint hipper don't hopple then hush man they sound like man they stole your man they look like no bidding us and there are these robot vocals kind of coming in on his voice toward the end of that section of the song and it just gives the track this nice little extra texture actually while we're on that subject a lot of little extra noises and textures are popping all throughout this song a lot of detail into this thing but after this the track really changes the beat stays almost the same but the sounds just get harsher the groove is more driving it kind of sounds like a noisy post-punk tune sort of inspired by the fall something that I can see LCD Soundsystem producing these guitars are screaming and there are these electronic really abrasive electronic noises just wailing like it is tough as nails and Andre just starts getting really cocky but also kind of self hating he's really going bipolar as this track progresses talking about I'm the shit yeah I'm shit wow this track to me or at least this point of the track is almost like James Gorillaz and Andre had this like mixing board of emotions and they just just decided to turn every emotion all the way up into the red and just force all of them down the throws of the listeners hey love depression happiness excitement these guys took the most inaccessible part of the song and made it the longest part of the song perfect now the final spot of this song is kind of like the the depressing hangover after this all-nighter of emotional outbursts of the most extreme capacity there are these really weary background vocals just move and even though this spot to me gets kind of repetitive it still comes off as very dark I love this track I freaking loved it and I mean I know it's a pipe dream to want more material from these three guys collaborative material but I will just leave this track saying the obvious it's well produced it's catchy it's really an emotional rollercoaster tons of progression tons of character overwhelming engaging I've run out of words to describe this thing so I think the best way I can sum it up is this track just really bland dipping that's pretty much it what do you guys think of this track do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana guerrillas andre 3000 james murphy forever [Music]

Hey it's track review hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's track reviews where we talk about the latest in rock pop electronic and experimental music of the independent persuasion sometimes hip-hop in middle too and in this track review i'm gonna be talking about a track from wisconsin trapper milo and he has a new mixtape out titled milo takes baths now you guys may remember that last year i reviewed a mixtape that this guy put out titled I wish my brother Rob was here it ended up being one of my favorite mixtapes of last year and stuck with me mostly because it was just a very funny witty underground hip hop with lyrical subjects ranging from friends passing away to homophobia and hip hop the internet message boards lots of references to nerd culture mmm it made me excited to hear whatever this guy was gonna put out next and I was especially excited after I heard about the concept of the mixtape which is basically Milo rapping over nothing but instrumentals created by the experimental beat music producer baths now thanks to that review I did last year a lot of you guys have already been listening to this thing and enjoying it but I have to be honest and say I don't think I am as thrilled this time around as I was with I wish my brother Rob was here and I think my enjoyment dropped the hardest when it came to the track I'm gonna review in this track review for Prince ABBA kaliki of Nigeria needs your help now the song is about a topic that Milo hasn't covered in this much detail yet in one of his songs in Internet relationship but not just simply the act of loving someone or trying to love someone over the information superhighway this song actually kind of covers the sexual side of things and delves into the idea of seducing somebody online and trying to bring things to a physical level when the person you're in love with isn't anywhere near you it could make for an interesting song but I think Milo gives this track a sour start when he tries to experiment by singing the hook singing is always welcome if it's done well and I didn't think it was done well here at all it just feels so weak it feels so off pitch it feels kind of mumbly not all that emotive and for me this misstep the song never recovers from it and we're just getting started things get even worse when you think about what the hook is actually saying I've cried in my room on the nights when my girlfriend wouldn't show me nudes there are so many weird things going on here and this chorus to me just feels like too much information why would you tell me this this doesn't feel entertaining it doesn't even feel like a joke and it's hard for me to even sympathize he really paints a picture throwing in images of kissing the screen typing aggressively covering up pimples and unflattering things in these nude photos and the flame wars that would ensue on the message board that he frequents if anyone found out Milo even references his needle drop review as something impressive to tell this girl to kind of grease the wheels of seduction I know that last one is real and the others feel like they're in the realm of possibility but the entire track just kind of feels like a fantasy and if it's gonna be a fantasy why not get the news why be the guy crying in your own made-up world the track to me just kind of feels like shooting this online sexual encounter through a really intimate and sort of sexy lens when the whole thing really doesn't end up for me being alluring at all and and nothing I want to get intimate with so I didn't like it but in a way this is not too surprising for Milo because his material up until this point has been built on this really personal brutal honesty that sometimes leads to some embarrassing moments some awkward moments I feel like Milo is kind of obsessed with being humble in the same way little Wayne is obsessed with being conceited so obsessed that he kind of comes up with humble fantasies for himself well overall I thought Milo takes baths was pretty decent didn't exactly end up hitting me with the same strength my brother Rob was here did but I'm still gonna be looking for what this guy does next what do you guys think of this track what are you asking this tape do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantino milo forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd time for an album review pallbearer sorrow and extinction pallbearer is a name that not only brings me back to my younger years where I watched a lot of Pro Wrestling but it's also the name of an Arkansas band in Arkansas metal band this is their debut LP and there's not too much backstory to give on these guys other than that they landed a deal on profound lore records which is one of the best underground metal labels out there right now based on some of the great song writing on a three track demo that they released in 2010 and though this demo who was good the studio recording on this band's new LP brings their traditional doom metal sound to new levels of heaviness and melody I said traditional doom metal where low end frequencies reign supreme and when it comes to riffs the slower the better I'm talking about bands like Candlemas trouble and of course Black Sabbath but obviously making music in 2012 pallbearer has the ability to reach low heavy sounds that these groups could only dream of making when they first started releasing albums well the production the recording on this thing is fantastic the riffs are massive they're crushing kind of like Giles Corey the man not the album getting smothered to death by rocks placed on him by colonialists accusing him voyage craft the riffs just had this really grinding rough quality to them it's like hearing a never ending monstrous roar only having volume and only having having this is not going to be enough to you know get your album buy and keep it interesting when other sounds come into the mix I think that's where pallbearer really puts their own spin on this stuff really pulls together a personality and creates a style of traditional doom metal that I think will even appeal to people who are usually not into this kind of music the sounds of psychedelic and progressive rock make their way onto this LP and for a doom metal band pallbearer is incredibly incredibly melodic to the point where the melodies being played by the guitars on these tracks take the spotlight more than the heaviness of these songs the melody and the beauty of this LP comes out right at the start of the first track with this a acoustic guitar intro which is very somber very pretty then this wave of feedback kind of jumps in and then the heavy riffs start they are so gargantuan they're just panoramic sounding just surrounding me as I hear them the sound is almost tangible rumbling but over these heavy riffs these harmonized guitar solos just soar it's like sunrays peeking through all these dark storm clouds that's not all because the riffs that are being played under these really great guitar solos and guitar harmonies guitar leads are pretty lengthy not your average doom metal riff not down now now the riffs are as interesting to listen to on the opening track as the guitar solos themselves and there's some really nice drum fills on this track too I love the way the drums sort of play around the riff I love the way they syncopate with the riff from time to time there's definitely some good interplay going on another thing I think is great about the track is just the vocals there's some very cleanly and have a lot of drama to them they're a little strained here and there but there's some well and sometimes this harmony will pop in and it just sounds really moving especially when it's just escalating to its limit it's almost as if I'm listening to a heavier take on progressive rock acts like King Crimson or Jethro Tull and keep in mind this is all just in the first song which is 12 minutes long and really engaging from start to finish the following track though devoid of redemption is much more straightforward the riff is more repetitive but the band kind of throws a curveball on this track by throwing some psychedelic elements into the song after the second track the album hits kind of a dry spot I guess because the third song on here while it is heavy it doesn't really bring anything the previous couple tracks didn't already be and there's just something about the vocal delivery on that track that just felt I guess a little forced that time around though I know I am kind of making a big deal out of just one single song it is one of just five songs on this entire album and spans to almost nine minutes the next track on here an offering of grief doesn't really expand on the ideas of the previous two tracks either but at least has more variation than the third the final song on here continues to break things up a little bit more quiet interludes there's a keyboard on here that sounds a little bit like a Mellotron - and even though it does sound different instrumentally just kind of felt like window dressing I guess because of the core these songs are written essentially with the same exact intentions as the previous tracks pallbearer just kind of ran out of new ideas to introduce me to which just kind of made this album feel like it dragged on like it was longer than it it needed to be which is silly because it's not even 50 minutes long it drowns in its influences a little bit runs out of ideas a little too fast but still adds up to a very listenable debut album that I would recommend to anyone who's into this style kind of feeling a decent too strong 7 what do you think about it if you've heard it let me know love it hate it why and what should I II review next Anthony Fantino pallbearer forever

Slappy's hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review sleigh bells reign of terror sleigh bells is a new york poppin rock duo and this is their sophomore LP the band is pretty much singer Alexis Krauss and guitar player Derek Miller and I've been getting a lot of requests to talk about this LP not only because this band has been getting a lot of buzz this year but I have kind of a troubled past with sleigh bells I think I'm gonna come out and say their previous material has not exactly received glowing reviews from yours truly but it's whatever I wasn't huge on this band's debut LP treats but I will give it to this album for just being extremely extremely loud a really brittle ear-shattering style of loud it was just a combination of these early tinny distorted guitar riffs matched up with shouted female vocals and some really really compressed heavy drum machine beats all the melodies the emotions the songs just felt really really simple and in a way they had to be because I can't imagine a complicated or detailed song translating all that well through the extremely loud and low Phi recording that sleigh bells subjected its music to on trees this helped me definitely reached a new threshold of volume for pop music but I wouldn't really go as far as to call it experimental or trailblazing or anything like that because a lot of the songs on here were just so so shallow that the volume and the recording style just kind of ended up sounding like a gimmick it was really the only unique thing it had going now the sophomore LP reign of terror is here and I definitely commend these guys for tweaking their sound up a bit they have pulled their recording a style out of the lo-fi doldrum they've created a set of tracks that actually tries to stand past the sound that defined the debut album from these guys and really kind of prove their worth but overall I think sleighbells pretty much just ended up with a better recorded version of their last album a lot of the melodies on these songs even resemble melodies from the previous album and the sounds they're working with are still roughly the same the distorted tinny guitars the really cheap heavy drum machine beats the light breathy girly vocal delivery one of the few sounds on here that I caused being kind of new kind of fresh where these shouted background vocals kind of like in a chorus or in unison they kind of sounded like vocals a group of cheerleaders would scream their samples of roaring crowds just screaming as if sleighbells is like indie Pop's answer to arena rock and in a way I could see them being that because they definitely go for a loud bombastic over-the-top sound a lot like bands such as kiss did in their heyday and like kiss sleigh bells really tries to push an image to the last thing I was catching on here that felt kind of new was just all these layers of guitars because the mix is less lo-fi less claustrophobic this time around there's just more space to throw in harmonized guitar solos a little bit of riff counterpoint I guess some whammy bar solos though it is clearer it's still loud too loud and abrasive for commercial radio but still tries to shoot for that same kind of candy-coated accessibility this album is pretty much abrasive only because of the guitars and if you replace them with synthesizers or something like that I don't really see any reason this album couldn't get played on any commercial radio station even like Radio Disney even though I think this LP is just a variation on the previous album I did end up liking it more and it let me see sleighbells music in a slightly different light it's not exactly winning my heart or anything but the noise and the beats and in the hooks on this album in a way actually kind of reminded me of Nine Inch Nails a little bit you know except it's going for something that's a lot more gum-chewing hair twirling and shallow the whole thing to me just ends up sounding like a beer commercial you know it just feels as flashy as a beer commercial when I listen to this I just see bikini models and hot waitresses and guys shotgunning beers and like a bar band rocking out the only difference with sleighbells take on this is that the bikini models may have some skull tattoos the waitress may be wearing gold spandex American Apparel tights and chain-smoking the beers that are being shotgun der Pabst Blue Ribbon and the band that's playing might be wearing some Wayfarers and Ramones t-shirts still the new recording that sleighbells is working with in my opinion though it kind of takes the uniqueness away from this duo it does make their music a lot more listenable the beginning of this LP to me just kind of felt like usual sleigh bells but the end of this album cooled off a bit tone things down and I ended up liking it which isn't too much of a surprise since from the previous LP songs like rill rill were my favorites songs like DOA which is kind of like sleigh bells attempt at a valid and then road to hell which was pretty repetitive but very kind of alluring and sexy those tracks to me come off waist sweeter than the ones with just the the insanely loud guitars and it's not even that it's loud it's just that what the guitars are playing on tracks like born to lose toward the end of the track or demons the riffs just sounds so immature they sound like riffs that you play on your tiny little practice amp but the distortion button turned on and turned all the way up there are some improvements that I'm noticing with this LP and that is making me like this album in this bands music a lot more but not so much that I'm just totally head over heels for it sleigh bells has their own style and as long as they have that it's going to attract fans it's going to catch ears and it's going to stop people in their tracks and that's always a good thing I'm kind of feeling like a strong five to a light six on this but what do you guys think about it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana sleigh bells forever [Music] [Music]

perfume genius hi everyone you have to be Fantan oh here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review perfume genius put your back into it perfume genius is the singing songwriting project of Mike had rias this is his sophomore LP his debut album came out in 2010 on Matador Records it was titled learning and it received quite a few great reviews but it was just a few things about it that was keeping it from really I guess resonating with me the album has some really pretty piano I felt like the voice was there the personality was Lizz Lizz there the songs were there but the production the recording just felt really lacking I guess wasn't really doing much for me it was low five but not in a really flattering way I thought the cavernous reverb that was inescapable with this album really kept these songs just feeling distant kind of alien which were definitely feelings and emotions that we're looking to be portrayed on that album now with this new LP pianos mics very unique voice which kind of sounds like it's on the verge of weeping literally and reverb are all still a part of the foundation of perfume geniuses music but most of the kinks on learning are pretty much completely ironed out and though this album does have more going for it I think it's greatest quality is the greatest quality of learning as well and that's simplicity you know on some of my reviews I do get comments that are like oh Anthony Fantana hates simplicity this is too simple for Fantana and the thing is that's not always the case of not an enemy of simplicity on some albums less is more and I feel like that's the case here the elements that build the songs this LP are very simple and though there is progression there is change on these songs these alterations are usually very quiet very subtle and very minimal and that really works in this album's favor especially considering that there are so many feelings of loneliness and sadness and introspection being pushed by these songs the fact that you have mix that just has so much space so much room to think and feel and react it just reinforces those feelings the instrumentals on this LP just feel really skeletal and musically the album is is really simple to the chord progressions on this LP travel through really easy to play and kind of familiar territory there are moments on here like the track sister song which is the last track on here that borrows straight from an old full chord progression the song hood totally has a doo-wop thing going on with its chord progression and that track really takes advantage of that sound of that style with the lyrics to kind of going for this very heartbreaking confessional angle and a couple songs on here note ear being one of them have a bit of a gospel spiritual thing going on with the chords this album is not filled with flair and and mind blowing technical proficiency it's very straightforward it's very simple very quiet very raw very emotional and I'd say visceral so not only are the sounds on this LP pretty simple very beautiful but played very gently on most of these tracks as if they're afraid to make noises if they're afraid to to be bolder and be louder in fear of they might lose their composure like they're just trying to hold all these feelings back there are a few spots on here where the song sort of has this emotional outburst the floodgates really break open like on the song hood which gets pretty loud with some drums and piano breaks down and gives this really passionate loud vocal performance but most of the time on this thing and the track note here is an example this album is looking for ways to just handle all of this heartbreak all these really distraught feelings just looking for a place to put them or just a way to deal with them that though it's a problem a lot of people have had and that to me is where this album kind of finds humanity finds relatability now as far as the production and the instrumentation goes on this LP the recording is so much better Mike's voice now is right up front and center you can make out all of his lyrics for the most part and he does a great job of just projecting his emotions on to me whatever he's feeling whatever social sort of idea or emotion a song here is trying to portray I just feel it instantly a lot of the time on here I'm just kind of left speechless and choked up by some of these songs and what I find so funny about that is that some of the tracks on here just so freakin short one of the shortest on here is just one minute 49 seconds and Mike manages to pack a lot of song into just a small sliver of time not to say you get lots of sounds and lots of melody in one single track but Mike sort of builds these songs to be consumed in a short amount of time the verses are short of the choruses are shorter the endings are very simple and on most of these tracks despite the fact that they are a little short of breath Mike always make sure to pack into them an intro kind of a build up a climax and a very simple ending to me it's kind of like thumbing through a book of just short stories of musical vignettes or like of poems it just ends up feeling really passionate really emotional very intimate - and I think a great deal that is because of Mike's voice which just has this insane vibrato to it not even really a vibrato he sings really well has some great range but as he is delivering these vocals these lyrics he just sounds like he's holding back tears it sounds like he is shaking it's a strange delivery not everybody is going to like it but I do think this guy's voice does have enough pitch to keep the melodies going to keep me interested his voice isn't too monie or to breathy and the instruments the production on here does a great job of carrying the emotions along as well and brings some nice variety between these tracks too I love the really wery low-pitched background vocals on the song note tear it kind of sounds like Mike took his own vocals and then just brought them down a couple registers like digitally I love the very airy synth scape created in the background on the track all waters the track hood is is by comparison to the other tracks pretty upbeat and pretty loud and has some nice poppy piano chords and the song 17 has these very kind of ominous strings just lightly kissing the track they do interject a few times but most of the time they're just creating this very soft but eerie texture in the background it just adds to the tension of the song the opening track on here has a really nice noisy wall of sound that kind of swallows the track up toward its end and normal song is kind of a change of pace just because of its three-four timing and introduction of an acoustic guitar vocal delivery personality emotion songwriting and just memorable hooks great production I feel like this album is a triumph over learning in almost every respect I didn't come out of it with at least a few gripes though there are some moments on here that I think and a little bit too abruptly for their own good the track dirge on here is a little bit too repetitive and the track floating spit has a nice bed of synthesizers in the background just like all waters but the vocals are pulled backwards like they were on learning just to be really distant that track is a bit of a step backwards stylistically whereas all these other songs that are kind of upfront and painful and bold and loud and in-your-face just feel so good and memorable and and hard-hitting and I suppose another gripe that I could have on here that I think other people may have is the lyrics can lack some detail from time to time I know that I and a lot of people are into lyrics that really tell a detailed story really get into the Nitty Gritty of a situation and though Mike does display a lot of emotion and there are tracks on here that lyrically I think give good reason to be emotional especially hood which is kind of about knowing something or having done something that if your lover knew about they would just not want to have anything to do with you I'm sure most people have a moment in their past or a thought in their head that if everyone knew things would just not be the same and though the lyrics on hood are simple they just paint that picture perfectly I think the lyrics like the rest of this LP do a lot with a little but still you know it'd be nice to hear some words on here that I guess are a little less vague so I did love the hell out of this album actually feeling a strong eight to a light nine on this it's definitely one of the better releases I've heard this year and I'm really happy to now kind of be appreciating the music this project has to offer but what did you guys think of this thing did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next Anthony Fantana perfume genius

grinds visions hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd review Grimes visions Grimes is the montreal-based synthesizer pop project fronted by singer/songwriter Claire Boucher this is the third full-length album from the project and in a nutshell it's kind of the shorter and much better produced sequel to the projects last album Alf AXA and I guess I say sequel because I feel like Grimes is going for roughly the same sound on this LP but there are some notable sonic improvements but aside from the previous Grimes record there were a bunch of other artists that this record reminded me of as I was listening to it for one nearly every single one of these tracks is built on these really quirky old-school very rigid and rudimentary synth pop instrumentals that remind me a lot of artists like OMD Orchestral Manoeuvres in the dark or Depeche Mode just just and Claire's voice over these instrumentals it's really light and feathery very breathy and high-pitched in a way it kind of reminds me of a really artsy goth doubt Madonna the vocal just really reminds me of Madonna's first two solo records but the vocals are sung at a pitch that is sort of just shy of the pitch that you would normally hear Vogel sung at on an Alvin and the Chipmunks record and then the vocals are just slathered in so much reverb you can't really make out what they're saying and they have the resonance of whale calls now I know that combination of sounds and influences sounds kind of weird maybe like a joke maybe something that you're wincing at thinking wanna listen to that stop it but I actually think it's an interesting idea an interesting combination of sounds it's really clear if you listen to Grimes first LP listen to the second and this one that she's been slowly developing this style she's just been chiseling away just perfecting this aesthetic my issue is that I just wish the songs on here felt as refined felt as planned or developed or as unique a lot of the songs on this thing just feel really thrown together there are some tracks on here that don't even have a chorus you know they just kind of had this one single idea and then they end just shy of the two-minute mark as if there was just no possible way to progress the song past this one idea as far as the other tracks go some of their hooks just sounds so identical to the verses they might as well be the same part because it's not really like the synths or the beat will change all that much most of the time a lot of these tracks roughly are pretty much one instrumental idea with Claire kind of vocalizing over in a handful of different ways it's a kind of basic set up and it's something that I could definitely see myself getting into if I felt like I was more in love with the elements that make these songs up like the synth work and Claire's voice I think the vocals on here just feel so distant I never really get to know them and at first I was kind of turned off by the really high pitch that they sing at but I don't know after a while it just didn't bug me anymore and I kind of grew to like it my only real issue with the vocals on this LP now our spots like the track vowels equal space and time where it feels like Claire is kind of singing out of her range or something really stressing her voice or just not hitting the notes that she wants to when she's essentially soloing with her voice and as far as the synthesizers go there are just some bad synth parts on here just for lack of a better word just some bad arts it feels like some of these synthesizer phrases arpeggios melodies whatever were played by someone who had just learned music theory like at the end of the song Genesis where you're just kind of catching this scale like been in it in it in any been in it in it and there are other spots on here like the arpeggios on be a body or the synthesizer solos on the track of Bolivian or night music especially night music the solos just feel so aimless they're literally just kind of clumsily stepping up and down like a scale it doesn't sound like keyboard playing it sounds like keyboard practice some of the beats on this LP are pretty good though I do have to give it to Grimes on that especially with tracks like Genesis and Oblivion they have this old-school retro dance-pop feel but they don't feel too dusty or nostalgic and the track eight has this really hardcore robotic vocal sample in the track and these really hard-hitting rhythms and these high pitched vocals just swarming all over the beat I really like how hectic that song is my only issue is well well well well well well well well well hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review Goatwhore blood for the master these guys are an extremely blasphemous metal band from New Orleans and this is their fifth full-length album and the tracks on this LP just like go whores previous material contain a combination of sounds from the worlds of black metal and death metal now black metal and death metal started around roughly the same time in the 80s but death metal caught on first I mean really kind of caught on as a strong trend and as death metal as a trend was hitting its peak in the mid 90s that's one black metal the Scandinavian sound popularized by artists like mayhem or like Burzum that's when that stuff started catching on of course there would be musicians out there who would just combine both worlds now there's no single way to make blackened death metal over the years groups have experimented with with various combinations of the double bass drums the death growls the retched vocals the tremolo picked guitars the chromatic riffs maybe some keyboards too at the Styles roots sits artists like necro phobic but blackened death metal though it has always been pretty small it's never really gotten bigger than the two genres that make it up it's never really died out either and today there's a new breed of bands that are keeping the sound alive like anaal nathrakh Azarath behemoth portal as well and go whore is one of these bands now over the course of this group's five full-length albums the sound and the production and just the way these songs are written it's just all been getting tighter and catchy er almost making this style of music kind of accessible just like goers is album carving out the eyes of God the production is really punchy and the riffs are starting to get a huge huge thrash injection into them and I would even say on this album the thrash elements are getting even stronger I would say the hooks play a bigger role on this LP to go horror is just reaching this level of of just straightforward pure adrenaline simplicity that reminds me of that skeleton which album that came out last year it's aggression for aggressions sake which I can't enjoy oh that can be pretty appealing for people who are looking for an album that has virtually no BS whatsoever and even though this album doesn't really offer up anything but anger and anti theism I can't really help but get caught up in it whenever I put this thing on and really listen to it it just gets my metal face going you know the face I usually make them listening to a metal record or all the vocals are great really charismatic you've got some black metal wretches on here which sound like a wolf with it's just teeth showing and it's growling and you've got these death growls - they have a fantastic rasp on them really nasty stuff the riffs do have their upsides and their downsides the downside for me is that some of them feel kind of played out kind of generic like I've heard these riffs in just about a hundred different records but on other tracks on but with some other tracks on here like in deathless tradition and collapse of eternal worth there's a strong element of just melody of harmony in the riff and I really feel like that's where the black metal influence here shines through and kind of adds to the memorability of this album but memorable is not really a word that I would use overall to describe this LP because so many tracks here are so similar and execution so relentless that by the end of this 38 minute LP they all become kind the blur for me but there are a few spots on here that do kind of stand out past the wreckage like the really heavy slow intro on in deathless tradition there's an acoustic interlude that opens up the song embodiment of this bitter chaos not to say the riffs on here are notable it's just that they're so similar in in purpose that really pulling a riff out of this album to critique it or analyzer or describe it is kind of like sticking your hand down deep into a jar of assorted color thumbtacks to pull out the red one some spots on toying with sounds and ideas that appeal to most metal fans kind of common ground for the extreme metal world and that makes this album really easy to like I liked it every single time I listened
